I did have some difficulty getting my Ring doorbell to work with the Show 5, but fixed the problem by re-enabling it using the Ring app on my cell phone, followed by using device discovery on the Alexa app. I think the problem was due to having upgraded the Ring, which had continued to work without doing anything with the app. Full Ring capability has been promised for the Show series, but apparently is still a work in progress, since I can't look at history on the Show 5. I believe two-way audio does work now, although I haven't tested it. Anyway, the ability to handle smart home devices works transparently, and checking a camera by voice command is a real plus compared to bringing the display up on a cell phone or computer.

I found it disappointing that Amazon has still not endowed the Show series with such a fundamental capability as the ability to display Kindle book text. Mind you, the Show 5 will read Kindle content out loud, just not show it. Why? You can ask for recipes (e.g., "alexa, recipe for deviled eggs"), which will yield a large selection from the web (also showing ratings) where you can scroll and/or step through a selected recipe, either by touch or voice, pretty nice if your fingers are greasy. If you have a Kindle cook book, note you are out of luck for using this feature to display its recipes. The 5.5" screen at 960 x 480 resolution is about on par with cell phones of a few years back, not great resolution, but effective enough given its size. At that resolution I wouldn't use it to watch movies or expect much from photos. The Show 5 has a 1 Meg camera, pretty much a match for the screen resolution. Since the camera might give some people pause for siting the device in a bedroom, Amazon has thoughtfully provided a (physical) slider that covers the camera lens. There is also a button that turns both camera and mic off. In the same vein, the Show 5 has an ambient light sensor to significantly dim the display at night in keeping with using its clock functionality in a bedroom.

The sound system has only a single speaker, but does surprisingly well for such a small device. You also have bluetooth and aux out if you want more sound (or stereo). Also on the plus side I was able to access my Amazon playlists and get to the internet via one of the integrated Silk or Firefox browsers ("alexa, open silk" or "alexa, open firefox"), both of which are built in. One minus other reviews cite seems to have already been taken care of in the latest update, since I was able to use settings to have a clock display that doesn't cycle to show other things. My display now holds as a clock face with day, date, and outside temp. If you want more weather detail, "alexa, show weather" will give you hour by hour conditions. Showing a radar map requires using a separate (free) app, which to make Alexa aware you go to the Amazon web site and press a button to enable it. I should note the radar map downloaded is a (current) regional radar snap shot based on your location and is not zoomable, which makes it pretty weak given the lack of screen resolution.

Other than the inability to show Kindle text, I'm happy with the device. The price point is good, significantly better than the Google Nest (although each device has features the other lacks; the Nest has a larger screen, the Show 5 a camera). I wouldn't call it a 5-star effort on Amazon's part yet, but it is certainly worthy of a 4-star rating as delivered.

reviews.reviewTitle: Early adopter review. Will update as I play with the device
reviews.reviewText:
I pre ordered it and had it delivered on release day. Interestingly it took another week before I could write a review.
Packaging: good, well thought out and easy to open.
Power brick: I am not sure about this yet. The latest form factor for Amazon power bricks is a bit big & square with a hardwired pigtail that means they cannot be extended and the power brick itself is a bit of a large brick. However this is probably due to a universal form factor requirement to allow the power plug prongs for different countries to fit into the same brick. It works but... one good thing is no. Ore usb plug sticking out the front making it ridiculously deep and stick out from the wall too much.
Show unit: I plugged it in and the very first thing it did after I connected it to the internet was download new software. So I guess there were bugs in the release software. It took about 10 minutes overall but nothing hiccuped and it went just fine from there.
It has a pretty good screen resolution, I use it to view my Ring doorbell and it does that nicely, so resolution is sufficient. I cannot see anyone happily watching any videos for any length of time on it as it is just too small for that really.
I am still playing with the settings, I have it showing a clock and the weather, although the weather is a bit more primitive than I expected, it just shows temperature and a cloud or sun symbol, I was hoping for a bit more and maybe to access a weathe r radar app, but I need to do more app research (any hints anyone?)
The Alexa app is disappointingly basic for using to set the device settings, I thought it Luis be much more comprehensive, but you have to do almost all of it in the device, which as a bit of a lag on the touch screen. This I am sure can be improved with future software updates though.
Overall it is what I expected, I have not reached its full potential yet and need to delve deeper into its settings and options, but as a simple bedside device it works pretty well.
I hope I will be able to learn more about what I can get it to do.
If you get one you will probably not be disappointed, just don’t expect it to do everything that a smartphone or tablet can do and you will be happy.

reviews.reviewTitle: A great new addition to our home’s Smart gadgets.
reviews.reviewText:
Our new sandstone color Echo Show arrived yesterday. It was a breeze to set up. We like the larger clock face and it has a few options to change it if one wants to check those out? At 5.5” it is a little less than half the size of our older Echo Show so it is perfect for the kitchen, where we have placed it. This Show uses touch screen access so swiping left gets one to it’s menu options and swiping down gets one to it’s controls. Good screen clarity. It will also be a great bedside clock/alarm/radio. One can turn off the camera option for privacy and still access control to ones other Amazon devices. Video calls can be made on it so we are thinking that at Holiday times it might be fun to share our kitchen gatherings with other family/friends?
There is a port on the back for adding speakers. We like having the controls conveniently on the top of the Show. A USB charging port on back would be great if it ever added?

reviews.reviewTitle: Not supported in the Alexa app
reviews.reviewText: This device doesn't have support in the Alexa app. It's not part of the Setup a new Device options. Also when you do get it set up via the on-screen setup, the Alexa App keeps dropping it out of the device list dropdown. I edit an alarm and save the change and the device is removed from the dropdown list.

I've have this Echo Show 5 since release date and im not completely satisfied with this Echo

The Audio goes into these weird static and feedback phases from time to time (it's not my network as my other Echo 2nt gen does not have this issue) and then there these times where i have to pretty much yell at this one for her to hear me and get the proper response. On top of that i she doesnt recognize my voice so some features i cant use with this echo

Other than that i've had no issue with this device but i'm highly considering returning this one and just get a other Echo 2nt gen

Sorry Amazon i had high hopes for this device and was let down with it

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor design for video calls if that is your goal.
reviews.reviewText:
We bought a few of these for employees to use for video calls between them as some of them now work from home. The photo was taken by one employee as they set up and used the Echo Show 5. These are ok I guess for things like using as a high dollar clock or for other Amazon Alexa things, but they work very poorly for video chatting. If you look at his photo, the woman in the main window is using a ten inch Echo device. The other employee is in the upper-right corner using the Echo 5. He's sitting right in front of it, but it makes him look like he's sitting on the side because the video camera is in the upper-right of the device, and not in the middle above the screen as it is on the ten inch Echo.

The employee who has the ten inch model is always centered. We have relatives who use the round one (Spot) and it has the camera in the middle too, so they are centered. But the Echo 5 is always going to show you to one side. Might be ok if there are always 2-3 of you in the video as it would balance out then, but it's really odd because he said you have to turn the whole thing to the side so you're in the middle to the other person. But then you have to look at a turned Echo 5 so you look normally centered to THEM (if that makes sense). You would think between design and making it out to sales someone would have picked up on this? Anyway, if you have other uses for it there are no glaring bad marks, but since they do advertise it for video chatting, and that was our main purpose in buying these and it's done so poorly, I have to give it bad marks.

reviews.reviewTitle: 1st one didnt work. Will 2nd one work?
reviews.reviewText:
Apparently I am not the only one to have their echo show arrive today and not even work. No wonder they were on sale on prime day. Makes me skeptical about the replacement they are supposed to be sending. If it doesnt work or has any issues it will immediately be going back for a refund. Pretty sad to buy something cause it is on sale only to find it doesn't work. Not the first time it has happened either. Will update after replacement comes.
Update: first one wouldnt come on past the logo. 2nd "refurbished" unit comes on although there are a couple nicks in the screen even though its supposed to "act and look like new" thinking about sending back until they work out the kinks and then I can purchase a "brand new item"

reviews.reviewTitle: says it works with Blink xt, and doesnt
reviews.reviewText: I consider myself a bit of a techie, so I know how these things work. I bought this on Prime day, it was a package deal...came with the Blink xt camera, and I wanted to see my security camera over my business door during business hours. To add the device, you are supposed to use the Alexa app...unfortunately, the Echo Show 5 does NOT show up as devices to connect the camera to, nor will it show up anywhere on the app to add apps, etc. I ended up adding apps directly from the device. Nice product, but now I can't use it for what I bought it for. Very disappointed, and feel like they gave them away with the cameras because they in actuality do NOT work with the Blink cameras.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best bang for the buck in the Echo screen devices
reviews.reviewText: I've got a few Echo devices in the house, a show (2nd gen, big one), an Echo Gen 2, a few gen 2 dots, and a kid's dot. For the longest time, I was considering a spot for the nightstand, use it as an alarm clock. My wife and I went to the 4 star store in Littleton, and she pointed these little suckers out to me. EXACTLY what I wanted in size, shape, color, etc. It replaced my echo in the bedroom. In night mode, the display turned red and dimmed very dark, so it didn't lighten the room at all. I've not had the opportunity to use it for music yet since I've not owned it for 24 hours at the time of writing this, but I imagine it's better than the dot 2nd gen. My ONLY recommendation- if your bed is slightly lower than the night stand, and you're looking UP at the show, get the stand so you can tilt it down a bit and see it better.

reviews.reviewTitle: Horrible audio quality with gunky excessive bass
reviews.reviewText:
The bass is horrible. Voices in particular are like they are talking though a PVC pipe. The whole speaker is like a cheap sub woofer. I turned the bass + midrange both down to 0 and virtually no change.
Bose does a lot of post processing of audio like this in an attempt to form the sound a particular way for their speakers. It does not work. Apparently, Amazon does this too (and Apple, et al) but Amazon just sucks at it on its Echo devices! Way too much bass.
My Echo Show 5 is almost unusable for news or talk radio. Jazz sounds OK though but with bass and mid turned all the way down.
Could it be that, on kitchen counters and under cabinets with various stone, ceramic, and hard surfaces, the sound is just rubbish? They never tested it in a kitchen? Many kitchens are small or even narrow with few windows and with a lot of reflective surfaces.
If you care about sound quality, skip it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Constant advertisments on the screen, VERY VERY VERY annoying!
reviews.reviewText: I am not sure if I am going to keep the show. At first I loved it, but now it has more advertisements on the screen than the clock. It is Very annoying. I contacted support and this is the response I got: " there is no way you can remove the things to try on the echo show device as this is enabled on all the screen devices, whee as I will take your feedback regarding this and forward this to our alexa developer team so that they can implement some changes in future updates. " As of right now I would tell people not to purchase unless you want a screen that constantly (more adds than time the clock is displayed) has advertisements to try this, and news that. I have all the settings turned off but you are not allowed to shop the constant advertisements. I am about ready to return it because of the constant adds. Otherise the device actually functions great besides the constant advertisements.

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazing Device and a word about how myths grow on the internet like there are ads on this device
reviews.reviewText:
An amazing bargain at the $50.00 I paid. It replaced my echo dot 3 and functions just like like it but with a screen. A perfect size for my needs - sitting on an end table directly next to my man chair.

Moving on to myths - once they start -- they grow like wildfire just because every reviewer has to mention that very criticism just to dispel it. No there are no ads on this device and to turn off the suggestions (which innocently suggest other features on the Alexa platform - all of which are free - you simply go into setting and turn these suggestions off.

I'm sitting here, in my man chair with a lovely static display showing me the time, in smaller print the day and month and the temperature. Hasn't changed once since I changed the settings but frankly I found the suggestions useful and may turn them back on

We bought this item as a replacement clock when we got rid of our cable box. The new update has rendered it useless. The time is too small to see from across the room. If you select an analog clock face, the screen goes to a solid background color and puts a digital time in the corner. amazon changed it so it constantly displaces a “things to try” on the screen, reducing the size of any clock face you select. You have to swipe every time you want to see the time/clack face. which is pointless if your intention is to sit anywhere that is not next to the device. Unless Amazon fixes this, this device does not make a good replacement for a standard clock.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is best device yet. its more affordable and completely reliable.
reviews.reviewText: I have the spot but I think it's cool that it connects to the smart home device cameras and you can ask her who's at the front door or what's going on in the baby's room or what's the weather going to be like today and she brings you through recipes while your cooking and you can even call the spot or any other Alexa device by drop in and you can talk to people in other rooms of the house. I just think technology has come so far you don't have to walk clear across the house to get your child's attention or to find out what's going on outside instead of putting your own life at risk to go find out. Taking the time to run to the DVR or open the app on your phone is now aay simpler. It's as easy as Alexa show me the kitchen.

reviews.reviewTitle: A welcome addition to my existing Echo
reviews.reviewText: I bought this primarily to use as an alarm clock and it's rather obvious that is what Amazon had in mind with this smart device. It was incredibly easy to connect to my wifi, setup, and personalize with my own photos. You have options on selecting the clock face. Whole process took about 40 minutes. Be prepared to input your wifi password, and answer a few questions to complete setup. The speakers are rich....as good as the Echo (2nd gen) in my living room. It does everything a normal Echo product does (tells me jokes, answers questions, controls my connected smart devices, etc.). I used to have to shout at Alexa to turn off lights in the house from bed, but no more. I can speak softly to this little gem and I'm fast asleep. I absolutely LOVE that this has a "night mode" that softens the clock face at night so the light doesn't keep you up. It also is has a "smart light" that brightens about 15 minutes before an alarm goes off. Apparently, this only works during the morning hours. I seriously have zero complaints about this device. I bought the stand primarily to keep the fabric off the tabletop since I'm not the best at remembering to dust and I didn't want the fabric getting dust bunnies. The stand connects with a magnet and is quite secure. I think it gives it a sort of mid-century Jetson's look that I like. The biggest plus of this product is it has substantially reduced those "Damnit, I have to get up again to turn off the lights/turn down the thermostat. If I could just get a programmable cat feeding device that connects to Alexa, my life would be magical. Highly recommend if you need a clock and are tired of shouting at Alexa from another room.

reviews.reviewTitle: Some of us have more than one echo, Amazon
reviews.reviewText:
I used to have an Echo dot on the nightstand for alarms, music, and smart home ("Bedroom lights off!") control. But we kept a classic digital clock around for exactly one reason - waking up in the middle of the night and not knowing what time it is (you don't ask Alexa at 3am and wake up your partner). So I was thrilled to get the Echo Show 5 which is literally designed for exactly this combination. Plus it can now show me the weather, sports scores, and pictures of my kids. Awesome. Sold.

There's exactly one feature, though, which annoys me because I think Amazon is not showing proper respect to its audience. It is the "Things to Try" feature. The device will always - always - be showing "Try saying Alexa, tell me the weather", "Try saying Alexa, tell me a joke", "Try saying Alexa, how many ounces in a pound..." You're going to want the display on all the time, and you're probably going to have it rotate through things like sports scores, and showing your pictures. Well, "Things To Try" is always going to be there.

Why do I hate it? Because I have 5 Echo devices. I'm a software developer and I've got several skills published in the store. I do NOT need to be told, constantly, what things I can try. By baking this feature into the new device and making it front and center, Amazon's basically said, "We assume that the only people who will have this device are brand new to Alexa." I find it annoying that once a company like Amazon has your money, they stop caring about you and just pay attention to the new customers. There's advanced users who would prefer a finer degree of control over their device. Maybe some more customization features - better alarms, backgrounds... We'll never get that if Amazon just pays attention to first time buyers.

I thought that this Echo show 5 would be much better than the Echo dot. Well, I'm not sure that it is. With the dot on my nightstand I could see the time at any time during the night, with the Show 5, It changes the color of the numbers to a RED color, and it's very hard to see them. It also reduces the size of the numbers and as someone who wears glasses, I can't read the RED Numbers. To reduce the brightness at night there is a setup for that, but it automatically makes it so dim, forget about waking up and reading the time. For the cost, I am very disappointed with it. I probably will send it back.

reviews.reviewTitle: Affordable Alexa device that works with Ethernet!
reviews.reviewText:
Overall the Echo Show 5 seems to be a decent device. I haven't used it long, so that opinion may change. The biggest thing I like is the ability to use Ethernet instead of WiFI. I plan to replace my regular Echo by my bed. The less RF while I sleep the better. For the people wondering, the micro USB port DOES function for an Ethernet adapter.
I bought the ES5 and personally tested it. I tried 4 different USB Ethernet adapters and only one worked. The one that worked has a Realtek chipset (supposedly RTL8153) inside. When connected to my PC all I could find was "Realtek GBE". It came from Amazon and was branded Cable Creation. It was a USB 3.0 to gigabit adapter. If you search B01FJQGCB0 on Amazon you should find it.
The other adapters (all USB 2.0) didn't work. I tried a Plugable brand fast Ethernet (100mbps), a Plugable brand Gigabit (1000mbps) and the official Chromecast Ethernet adapter. The Plugable brand adapters both had ASIX brand chipsets. I don't know what the Chromecast one had. None of those worked. Besides the Ethernet adapter, you will need a "Y" OTG cable (one that has a power input) and a micro USB charger/power cord from an old phone or something.
The micro USB port on the ES5 does NOT output power, so the power for the Ethernet adapter comes from the power input on the OTG "Y" cable. My ES5 was a brand new one, that I deregistered (after shipment) from my Amazon account, prior to the first powering on. The new Amazon devices I have received lately have been pre-setup with my personal WiFi login info, which I didn't want the ES5 to have available to it, so it would HAVE to use Ethernet. Deregistering wipes the WIFI info.
I connected everything and powered it on. It picked up the "wired" connection right away and setup began. If the Ethernet adapter gets unplugged and plugged in again, the Echo Show 5 doesn't seem to pick it back up, without first power cycling the ES5. So when you first connect everything, make sure to power cycle your ES5. With those pieces, anyone should be able to figure out how to connect them.
I did NOT try the official Fire TV Ethernet adapter, but would expect it to work. Something to note about that, I believe the Fire TV Ethernet adapter is only fast Ethernet (100mbps) where as the adapter I used is gigabit (1000mbps) though you will only get about 200mbps through the micro USB port (USB 2.0 bus). That assumes the ES5 is even fast enough to use more than 100mbps.

My daughter wanted this device as an award for six months of hard work... she is disappointed that there is no Hulu support. I would upgrade this to a 4 or 5 star had there been consistency in features across the lineup.

Added Comment:
Should be noted that Amazon at least cared enough to contact me... sad thing is that the customer service rep didn't know that the Echo 5 didn't do everything as the Echo Show and then when I pointed out through the Skills tab that it wasn't an option they pointed a finger a the partner.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product overal - many reviewers' negatives are unreasonable
reviews.reviewText:
I am not going to re-state most of what has already been "reviewed" here other than to say I agree with most of the positive comments and find many of the "negatives" to be somewhat unreasonable. I would expect anyone buying one of these would have read the Professional Reviews from CNET, etc. and been aware of what they call serious negatives.

For example, the Show 5 has a 5.5” screen with 960 x 480 resolution. Marking it down because you can't watch HD movies on it doesn't make sense. While you can watch movies/videos on it, clearly it isn't designed to be a primary HD video device and if you couldn't figure that out before you bought it, that's on you, not the device.

Same with the complaints about the sound. Pro reviews say the audio sounds to be better than the Echo Dot 2/3 Gen and not as good as the larger Echo Show. You should not expect or be disappointed that the sound isn't Bose quality.

Don't lower the score because it isn't battery operated either. If you didn't realize that before you bought then you obviously don't know how to read item descriptions. You really want a battery operated, high quality, HD screen on a small screen device that you can carry around in your hand - get a Razer phone.

I will agree that the "ads" or "Try asking Alexa this..." is a little bothersome but I don't sit for hours watching the Home screen, so really it is a very minor nuisance and again not something to warrant a multi-star deduction from a review.

Now that I'm done ranting, overall the Echo Show 5 works well as either the "clock in the bedroom" Echo device and maybe the "Menu screen in the kitchen" Echo device although maybe in the kitchen you'll want a larger screen. It meets or exceeds all of my expectations after reading the pre-release Pro reviews.

The Good: sound quality is surprisingly good (I use it for rain sounds for sleep, amongst other things), the video quality is okay, and the build quality is good. Screen size goid for showing my security cameras.
The Bad: screen resolution is only "okay". I'd have hoped for 720p at least, but it's basically standard definition.
The Launch (the ugly): Amazon should have Echo launches down by now, but they still manage to screw the pooch on firmware hosting servers. They left them understrength for launch, resulting in my Echo Show 5 being stuck in a permanent update loop for 36 hours.

Mind you, I HAD to update the FW to use it. So it just sat there saying "updating" for 24 hours, after which I cycled power, but it went back to the update loop, so I started experimenting with power/button combos to see if I could induce a factory reset.

At some point I managed to boot it up with telnet active (I was tempted....) and eventually you d the right combo to factory reset it, and then it updated fine.

Lessons for users: Don't try to use it on.launch day and, if you must, figure out how to factory reset the device.
Lesson for Amazon: seriously, reinforce your update servers, this happens every time you launch a new Echo product.

One of the desirable features we thought we were getting based on the advertisement images, was the large font clock display. However, not only can you not get this to be the fulltime display on the Echo 5, the continual display of suggestions from Echo of things to try means that the clock display is seldom viewable. This is very disappointing and something we all should pressure Amazon to change. It is obviously something they could do with a software update and would not change how we interact with the device.

I used to like this device but Amazon changed something so now all it shows me is the time in a tiny font in the upper left corner, my alarm in another even smaller font in the upper right corner, and a bunch of advertisements like - Try "Alexa, what are my deals?" permanently affixed in rotating fashion across the bottom. It's no longer a smart clock as the clock function is almost pointless. Will be returning the device and continuing to look for something that does what I want.

For someone who’s only interacted with Alexa via an Echo Dot, it’s so nice having a screen for visuals to go along with that she’s saying. Originally, I bought the Show 5 to control my bedroom smart plugs and check the weather in the morning. After seeing the Show 5 in person I plan on keeping it on my nightstand because size wise it feels like a better fit than my large dresser. All that comes in the box is the Show 5, a standard Amazon power cable similar to the one that came with my Echo Dot, and some quick star guides. The Show 5 was easy to set up but a bit longer than expected because of a software update. It even plays a video of how to get started! It’s very lightweight and has a large rubber bottom to keep it from sliding around when touching the screen.

It picks up my voice very well, even from across the room. When you say the wake word, “Alexa,” there’s a blue line at appears on the bottom of the screen and it moves in the direction she things your voice is coming from. Swiping down from the top edge of the screen gives you access to the home button (which is the quickest way to get back to the home screen unless you say “Alexa go to the home screen.” It would of been nice to have a physical home button on top), brightness, Do Not Disturb and Settings. The settings are for things like the clock face( which there’s a lot to choose from so you can defiantly have fun customizing it to your liking), device options, and more. Swiping left from the right side edge of the screen will reveal more Alexa familiar settings like Routines, Alarms, Smart Home, and more.

The screen is very sharp and the colors all look good! I don’t know about using it in the kitchen for a recipe, maybe leave that to the larger Show. The devices’ size no larger than that of a portable bluetooth speaker, which for some reason I expected to be slightly larger but it’s a great size! Speaking of speakers, it has an aux port in the back to plug in external speakers although I found the built in speaker to work just fine. The sound is loud and can definitely fill a room with ease. I really enjoy that she provides a visual to go along with the voice command. For instance with weather she’ll show a slideshow of the current high/low, hourly forecast, wind, etc.

The light sensor on the front is nice so it can automatically adjust the display brightness based on the rooms brightness. It has a Dark Mode so in a darkened room the screen brightness basically goes all the way down. Although if you’re someone who needs to sleep in complete darkness this might be an issue. I noticed even at the lowest brightness it was still too bright for me to sleep and I figured out by saying “Alexa, turn the screen off” is the only way to make the screen black. I wish it was built into the Routine settings for me to add “screen turns off” during my goodnight routine, but maybe that’ll come in a future software fix.

The overall design is very visually pleasing. The fabric on the back is a nice modern touch and the front is glossy (would of been nice if it was a matte finish to reduce glare and fingerprints) so it’ll have to be cleaned often. I’m not upset at the size of the bezels although it would of been nice if they were a little slimmer. I have the Charcoal color and the camera cover is white which is a little strange because it stands out as a white dot in the middle of a black bezel but at least you know the camera is covered when it’s switched on. The screen is always on which is nice during the day and the home screen can be adjusted to show just the time/wallpaper or rotate through news, weather, top stories and more.

Overall the Show 5 has exceeded my expectations and I’ve very happy. There’s only a couple nit picky things I found but will defiantly start using Alexa more in my daily routine! Would highly recommend to a friend or anyone looking for a new Alexa device.

reviews.reviewTitle: If you are looking for a smart alarm clock, read this and save the packaging.
reviews.reviewText:
For all the folks that want to buy this to use as an alarm clock, please be aware that the "Try this ......" messages at the bottom of the screen cannot be turned off. I have an Echo Show-5 and turning this off may have been possible on an earlier version of this device but not this one. I have everything (that's right .... every single option) in the "Home screen content" menu turned off. The display simply remains a blank screen with time in small font in the top left corner and the "Try this.." message at the bottom. If I turn on "Auto rotation", the screen alternates between that and the clock being shown across the whole screen (which is what you expect an alarm clock to do). This was not the case for the first couple of months I had this device (bought in July 2019) - the display always showed the clock. Some update might have screwed things up because now I have to alternate between a blank screen (with the "Try this.." message) and the clock.

So once again, save the packaging and return it if you are annoyed by this.

reviews.reviewTitle: More of a Spot than a Show – no support for Hulu
reviews.reviewText: I have and have had every Echo device in the line-up since day one. When I saw this smaller form factor "Show" which was larger than the Spot, I was happy to order just to have a larger screen on my desk to monitor my outdoor cameras while I worked. I also liked the idea of a second screen to watch Hulu video as I work. Well, Spot does not have Hulu. And neither does this Show – which really should have been addressed in the description. But, perhaps that is a Hulu thing and not an Echo thing? I chatted with tech support about the matter and was assured that Hulu was indeed available on the Show 5. So, I performed all the hoop-jumping that one is obliged to perform when trouble-shooting a problem – all to no avail. I asked several times if anyone, anywhere, has ever successfully watched Hulu on an Echo 5. I never received an answer before she "escalated" the concern to the developers. That was three days ago and I have not yet heard back. At this price point, it is a much better display than the Spot – although as someone else has mentioned, the camera is in a weird place for video chats. But the ability to manually cover the camera with a switch is appreciated. So, all in all, a pretty good, affordable Echo Show (or should I say "Spot") option – but the absence of Hulu is a particular disappointment to me.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good for what I use it for
reviews.reviewText: My only gripe is that I use this as a replacement for my alarm clock. My issue is that I want it to play a radio station at the specific time each morning, but when you set up a "routine", you can't choose from all available sources. In other words, the device can stream my local radio station, but I can't choose that option when creating the routine. Otherwise, it would be a 5.

Love the hardware. But it displays nonstop "suggestions" on the screen all day long with no way to turn it off. What? Why would I want an eye-catching distraction sitting right on my nightstand?

It's ridiculous. I'll rebuy it once they let you turn that off.

We replaced an Echo Spot with the new Echo Show 5 and it is an improvement. The size is of the Show 5 is just right for bedside use or a countertop. You would want a larger version of the Show if you wanted to watch movies, but I am not sure who would do that. The screen resolution is good and we can clearly view the video from our home cameras using the Nest skill. The screen brightness is good when viewing directly. When viewing from an angle, you are able to see the time and not much else. The auto dimmer is sensitive and can be a bit dark even with the brightness at the highest setting unless the room is bright. We use one bedside and when completely dark, the time/temp becomes a dark red. The red is dim and readable, not disturbing. The sound is very good for such a small product. We have listened to music and watched music videos and the Show 5 has a good amount of bass and the sound fills small rooms. Using the Alexa app, you can use the equalizer to adjust the sound, if you choose. The installed clock backgrounds are limited, but you can upload your photos using the app. We found that you must use photos that are bright. When using your photos as the background, the Show 5 allows you to adjust where the clock is located on the screen to avoid blocking the faces of your loved ones in the photo. The new camera shutter is a simple but essential security feature for use in bedrooms or bathrooms. We do not need to cover the camera with tape in the Show 5, as we did on the Spot. Overall, the Show 5 is everything that I had hoped that the compact Spot would be, with better features and a lower price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sunrise option may not be available to you.
reviews.reviewText:
Don't use Alexia but bought this for the sunrise clock and watching videos to fall asleep. Sunrise clock option isn't available for me. You can't use sunrise option before 4 AM or after 9 AM. I clock in to work before 4 AM so this purchase was dumb, I still need to buy a sunrise clock. :(
**Added a star because I like using Alexa sometimes, and I can turn off the microphones easily when I don't want to use the function. My favorite is "Echo, play a movie." I don't have to scroll through options, it just plays something and since I'm usually reading anyway, it's nice not to have to pick.

Sadly I am going to have to return my Echo because the speaker is going wonky and sounds bad. I'm hoping Amazon will exchange it and updates will fix the other issues.

reviews.reviewTitle: Was great till update took large clock display away !!!!!
reviews.reviewText: I love amazon and their Echo products. I have several dots, the auto a spot and this show 5. It worked very well until the last update. Now the large clock display is gone and the clock is tiny in the left corner. Why would you do this Amazon? Why not give us an option to choose this. Also, I use to get Try Alexa notifications temporarily but now it’s constant it never goes away. I called customer service and they were like “yeah that’s new with latest update maybe it will change at the next update.” So mad as this makes this Show 5 useless to me it’s basically a door stop now and it’s passed the expiration to return.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hey Amazon you should "Try to allow users to TURN OFF SUGGESTIONS!" on all screens
reviews.reviewText:
This could be such a great device, but no... If you're not a fan of suggestions/skills showing on almost all screens, this is not a device you want. This will remain a single star review, even though it's a 5 star product until Amazon gets with it and allows me to disable the suggestions (paid upgrade or whatever).

Amazon I get it, you want Alexa in every home and you're willing to discount devices such as this in exchange for the ability to show off more skills. But I want the ability to turn them off and not accidentally enable Jokes about Dogs when I ask "Alexa, what's the weather in Italy?" because my wife was also in the background talking about our dog being funny to our son. Hands down, Alexa is the best AI in the market, but it's absurd you have to force skills down people's throat and worse, that they just ENABLE on their own due to Alexa misunderstanding.

Pros:
* Simple design and small. Fits great on my desk.
* Rotating home screen, shows me time, date, temp, calendar, etc...
* Camera Privacy (mechanical switch) - This is a 5 star feature for devices like this
* Full on support for Amazon Alexa Skills

Cons:
* "Try this skill" at EVERY rotate on the home screen, on some apps, on pictures...

reviews.reviewTitle: Display has major problem - Amazon won't fix it!
reviews.reviewText:
One of the uses of this device is an alarm clock - Problem is the display is blank except for small time display in upper left corner (too small to see) and annoying "Try -bla bla bla" at the center bottom of display. The support forum is full of frustrated people tired of Amazons refusal or inability to correct this problem. The forum also shows that this problem is "Resolved" - it is NOT.
The display problem was caused by Amazon with a firmware update, which means they could always roll this back and return the device to usability.
I am telling everyone to NOT buy any Show device until the display problem is fixed!

reviews.reviewTitle: Echo Show 5 - Best Bang For Your Buck
reviews.reviewText: I have been using various Alexa powered devices for several years, starting with the original Echo. I had my eye on the various Show models for a while but felt they were a bit pricey when my Dots and Fire TV did 75% of the same things. When the Show 5 came out I was really interested, so I waited for Prime Day to purchase it. Super easy set up - it did take about 10 minutes to download and install the various updates, but that is to be expected. Sound quality is very good, especially considering the compact size. The screen looks fantastic when looking straight on, but like some of the cheaper Kindle models the quality goes down if you are looking at it from an angle. Interface is very intuitive once you figure out the swipe up/swipe to the right stuff. I appreciate the built in camera cover. I also purchased the stand to go along with it. I'm using it on my nightstand currently (replacing the 2nd generation Dot I previously had in the bedroom). I was worried it might be too bright overnight but no concerns there either (it does have the ability to dim the screen). I was kinda disappointed it wouldn't dim via Alexa command, but hey... can't have everything. I also have it hooked up to my Ring Door Bell 2 so I can monitor what's happening at the front door while still laying in bed. Overall, I couldn't be happier with this purchase, especially at the Prime Day price.

I love this device!!!! I had been eyeing the Echo Spot for a while for its price point and ability to video call and then this Echo Show 5 compact was released: I liked the square screen a lot more than the round one on the spot. The larger Echo Show that I also wanted was just not in my price range- I had to be able to afford to purchase multiple devices for me and my kids so we all have a way to see each other and talk regularly with grandchildren since everyone lives in other states. I actually love the smaller size- it fits better in compact areas like my bedside and on my computer desk. I don’t regret this purchase at all! I love how easy I can connect with family and with the introduction deal and the Prime Day Deal I was able to gift one to everyone in my family at an affordable price. Everyone loves them! Bonus I can control my smart home devices from this all hands free: lights, appliances, gadgets, and Alexa devices. Best purchase this year!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great as a bedside clock and integrates with my Ring doorbell
reviews.reviewText:
I've only had my Echo Show 5 for a few days, but so far I'm very impressed. What I like so far:

1. It looks great as a bedside clock. I set it to a big bold blue digital clock face and I love the look. I tried the option to cycle through the colors but I found that distracting.

2. It works fantastically at night. My biggest fear was that it would be too bright at night and bother my wife who is sensitive to any light at all. However, it's nighttime illumination is as good as it can get, imo. I set the option to dim the screen at night. When my bedroom gets dark, the bright, bold blue clock dims to a completely black background and the clock numbers turn into a barely noticeable red color. The Echo Show 5 is only about 3 feet from my head, but in the dark it basically looks off/completely black. I need to focus on the clock to actually see the VERY dim red clock numbers, which is exactly what I had hoped for. From the other side of the bed, my wife doesn't even realize the Echo is even on.

I've read others complain that it is too bright at night. I'm not sure if their settings are different from mine, but I don't see how it can be too bright for anyone, and I like my bedroom very dark at night.

3. I have a Ring video doorbell. The Echo Show alerts me to someone at the front door. I can tell Alexa, "Alexa, show me the front door" and it quickly shows me a live video of the front door where I can see the person at the door, listen to the audio (if I choose) or unmute my mic and speak to the person at the front door. I think the only improvement I would make would be to immediately show me the live video of the front door without prompting from me, but I don't think it will do this.

4. I like the manual camera cover-slide. With this camera cover, I am 100-percent sure that the camera is non-functional on the Echo Show in my bedroom until I physically open the camera cover.

5. I wish it came with the optional little stand. Mine works fine without the stand, but it would be cool to have it. (But to me it's not worth $20 that Amazon is charging for the stand.)

6. Audio quality is very good.

reviews.reviewTitle: A nice addition to the Echo family, at a reasonable price... but...
reviews.reviewText:
I am not seeing that many beneficial skills for this new Show 5, however I presume more are on the way. For example, local radar is very hard to see detail and I was not able to "zoom" in on the more local area - it was two states wide.

Also, it appears when someone "drops in" they just show up on your screen and from that point they can (or could) even ease drop with the device being called should no one be there to recognize or acknowledge - Yes, you can turn off the camera by shuttering it but the microphone, which you can also turn off, emits a red light and mutes EVERY THING - it would be great if the device's camera shutter, when closed, also muted the microphone until acknowledged.

Also, there is no on-going light (as opposed to rings on a Dot) that lights up and stays lit for notifications (nor a screen prompt over than for a few seconds) that I can find.

The Show 5 has a ways to go and I hope some updates bring it up to speed - it's missing a few necessary features to make it a worthwhile investment.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is one of these things that, after you have it, you wondered how you made it without it.
reviews.reviewText: I have now bought four of these. They are perfect for the bedside table for a clock and does all the amazing things my Echo Spot did with a larger, excellent display.

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazon Tech ran away with this defect
reviews.reviewText:
I had the echo gen1 when it first came out. It met my expectation. During the Amazon Prime day 2 weeks ago, I bought additional two Echo5 in hope it would bring the best of amazon to us. It turned out to be the worst investment in Amazon product so far.

Initially, registering the two new Echo5 to the account without anh incident. In fact, the registration went very smooth. Just connected to the wifi network and the two got up and running, without much of the hassle. Alexa app (on my Samsung Andriod phone) recognized all devices without any hiccup.

I put each device in one living room and each bedroom.

The issue started a week later. When one device is playing in one room, we ask to play another room, it stopped the other room and play this. I followed amazon FAQ, created a group. It did not really work, when you ask for something, the whole house will hear the answers! :) :P

Suddenly, one Echo5 dropped off the account. Unable to reconnect or re-register back to the amazon account. Contacted amazon support, they literally gave up and dropped the chat! (See attached image) without saying much.
They found out that since my amazon account is using 2-step authentication, it won't let Echo5 log me in!!???? I disabled the 2-step authentication, still did not resolve the issue.
I asked for a refund.
Today, another old Echo (used to work flawlessly), now off the account as well. Hell! Not sure why. Contacted Amzn support, still no answer.....

Anyway, Amzn is too early to introduce this device.

Returned all amazon devices for now.

I love the irony of using an advanced tech device with a retro flip clock theme. The time display is much larger than on the bigger echo devices and has a variety of possible clock themes. I turned off a number of features, so am not seeing the ads others are complaining about. Sound quality is only so so, but not bad for the size. I particularly like the smaller screen at bedside since there is much less of an ambient glow than you get on larger devices. Much easier for my myopic eyes to see on the bed stand 👀. Certainly not the device you want if you want to use it to watch lots of videos, but can be used in a pinch!

reviews.reviewTitle: Look for Lenovo Smart Clock or Google Home Hub if you just want a connected clock
reviews.reviewText:
Bought this during Prime day sales, it is a very good deal for smart device, but for me all I wanted is a connected clock that no need for time adjustment like the traditional clock...

The setup is easy, the display is sharp and easy to read, the sound output is better than expected consider the size of the device.

However, there is a one thing really annoying if you plan to use it as a clock, there is a "feature" called "The Alexa suggestions", as the clock screen will from time to time rotate from the clock face you choose to tips/hints of what you can do with Alexa, though the time & date will still be shown on the upper left corner in a much much smaller font size, so you may not be able to read the clock is located with some distance away from your bed. To make the situation even worse, this "feature" can't be turned off at all! I understand Amazon is trying to encourage owners to utilize \(rely on?) the voice assistant features more frequently, but not letting the user to turn it off is really annoying. I also have Google Home Hub and it doesn't have the same problem.

Apparently there are users complaining about this in the support forum for months and I guess the problem can be fixed easily by a firmware update, but it looks like Amazon is not responding to the requests.

Alexa, are you listening?

They really need to fix this. A nightstand clock should have big numbers, easy to see from across the room. Every time I get the clock to take up the whole screen like it should, the time automatically shrinks to thumbnail size and places it in the upper left-hand corner leaving a small portion at the bottom for try this even though I have turned off all of the try this notifications, interruptions, weather Etc. I am left with all of this wasted space. I might as well hang my watch over the echo to tell time and I know that this is something they can fix on their end with a simple software update. I noticed others were complaining about the same issue but I chalked it up to them possibly not knowing where to go to turn off suggestions but I was wrong and the only thing I can think of is that not enough people are complaining about this for them to want to fix it or it would already be fixed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sort of an all purpose device but not great at any one thing
reviews.reviewText:
We have pretty extensive integration of Alexa in our smart home. We have gladly added thermostats, lights, TV and other modalities as they became available. Alexa has certainly become 'smarter' over the last few years and a useful addition to our home. Recently our cable provider upgraded our cable boxes--but with the upgrade, we lost the familiar blue clock that used to be included. Was considering digging out an alarm clock from a box in the basement when I saw that the Echo 5 was available at a good price over Prime day.

It functions well as an alarm clock and as a visible clock as well. The screen can be seen clearly across a 25 foot room, Because it is Amazon, the initial settings are a bt ambitious--flipping between weather, news, ads and all sorts of other junk. This was easy to change. All I want to do is be able to access Alexa and to be able to glance at the screen for the time when I feel like it. Having said that, the screen is about the size of a cell phone. You won't be watching movies or doing anything requiring detail. Note that there is no battery in this unt so, unlike a tablet, if the power is out, so is this.

The voice recognition is not quite as sensitive as standard cylindrical Alexa's-- there are less microphones and the ability to pick up your voice from across the room is less acute. Not bad though and still quite remarkable.

The sound is bass heavy but clear and surprisingly good. The unit has a camera and with all of the privacy concerns we all share, there is a mechanical shutter which can be used to physically block the lens--a great feature. Oddly, the camera is pointed way up-- if you want to use this as a two way video device,you need to hover above it to get your face rather than your belly in the picture. If you are using this to check in on grandpa from time to time you should take some pains to make sure that grandpa understands where the camera is pointed.

As the Alexa environment has added skills, the clunky method of invoking skills (Alexa, ask (name of skill) for...) has got to be improved and this complaint is obviously not specific to this model. Additionally most skills that are offered are junk. I am waiting for the day when Alexa can sustain a conversation of some complexity. I believe one of the greatest shortcomings is the lack of Google and reliance upon Bing for data.

I am pretty satisfied with this jack-of-all-trades device but setting expectations is important.

reviews.reviewTitle: Who knew such a small device could sound so big
reviews.reviewText:
After years of barely being able to see the fading LED bedside alarm clock, the availability of a deal on Prime Day prompted me to go ahead and buy an Echo Show 5. I was also thinking perhaps it could replace the Gen 1 Echo Dot we've had in the bedroom, and as anyone who has one of those old Dots knows, the sound from them is tinny and awful unless you hook them up to an external speaker. So we had ours connected to a Creative D100 bluetooth speaker.

Well, the Echo Show 5 actually sounds about as good as the D100. Maybe slightly less bass response, but not much. I was surprised that it sounded so good for such a small device--which is roughly the size of a normal smartphone turned on its side, with a triangular back that holds the extra electronics and speaker assembly.

One thing I like about the Show 5 that's an improvement over the Gen 1 and Gen 2 Echo Show devices (the larger models) is you don't have to look at that dumb "Try, 'Alexa (some command)" text. Just a nice big clock with the date and the weather. I wish the other Show models had this option.

Anyway, it's a great device, but I would offer this suggestion to Amazon for the next generation of the Echo Show 5: Add on-board battery storage, so that the device can still set off the morning alarm even if main power is out. It's okay if the display stays off to conserve power, but it'd be nice to be assured that the alarm will go off even in the event of a power outage, like is the case for most regular alarm clocks.

El Echo Show 5 trae dos microfonos pero cuesta mucho que pueda escucharte, encuanto a la calidad de video es acptable comparando el precio, el sonido para su tamaño es aceptable, lo unico negativo son los microfonos no son tan sensible como los demas Echos, espero que en una mejora del sofwer puedan mejorar esa parte, Saludo desde Republica Dominicana.

Echoes updated and now won’t display the clock, best display is time & temperature upper left, Try Alexa .... across the bottom. I wanted a full screen of the clock. It will do that. Spent 30 minutes on the phone with support, waste of time. They had me factory reset, now it is even worse. Just a waste of time. Not sure wants ‘Try Alexa...’ but NOT me.

Bought this during the Prime Day sale for my wife who said she needed a new alarm clock. Big mistake. This is the worst alarm clock ever. I'm focusing on the alarm clock issues, this is probably fine if you just want a clock or to replace an Echo Dot, which we have and really like. I traded in a Gen 2 Dot for a Gen 3 and like that even more.

Before I get started I'll add here I havent' had any problems w/ "ads". Dont' think Iv'e seen a single ad, and I know what ads look like we have 2 Fire tablets. The "Ask Alexa" lines show up on the bottom of the home screen occasionally, forcing the time to the top left, but it's fine, you can still read it.

The problem with the Show 5 as an alarm clock is almost entirely software driven. Seems like Amazon shipped this hardware without giving the software any though that all. Nothing makes sense.

The biggest problem by far - When you turn off your alarm clock, which you've set for "Every weekday", it actually turns it off off. It's gone, like it never existed. Even though you set it for "every weekday" and it says "every weekday" when it is listed, once you turn it off it's gone and Echo (wake up word I chose for ours) can't find it again. I've tried phrases like "Echo show my alarm history", "Echo, reapply my last alarm", 'Echo, turn on my last alarm", you get the idea, but all Echo ever says is "You dont' have any notifications right now". So I have to tell it to reset it again.

Which brings us to problem number 2. The Show works as a streaming device, it can play music for your alarm, which is a big selling point, but Alexa is hard of hearing. So you say "Echo, set an alarm for 5:30AM w/ Pandora", but the first couple of times you say it she'll only set the alarm, not the music, it takes a few times for the "Pandora" part to stick. Which would be fine, if the "Every Weekday" put worked, b/c then we'd never have to set it again, but since it goes away every single day, we have to go through this every day.

An extra annoying thing about setting music for the alarm, which I'm sure MOST people would do, is that it isn't an option under 'Setting/Sounds/Alarms". You can choose all sorts or alarms, even pseudo-celebrities like Tara Reid, waking you up in the morning. But there is no option under settings for music. None. Not even Amazon Prime Music or Amazon Music which would seem an obvious selling point. So rather then just choosing "music" you have to pick an alarm sound and then hope Alexa understands you want music added to your alarm.

Fourth minor problem. When you finally get your alarm set up, again, the way you'd like, sometimes the upper right corner of the screen says it;s set, but sometimes it doesn't. So the only way to know for sure if it's set or not is to ask her. I'm sure there's a rhyme and reason to it, but I can't figure it out. If it's set it should say so, period.

And here's the extra frustrating part. When I go into my Alexa app on my phone all of this is there. Every time I've said "Echo, set alarm for 5:30AM with Pandora" it's listed there. Many many times. And if I click on 1 I can just turn it back on. But the actual Echo Show 5 doesn't have ANY of this information. The Alexa device doesn't have the Alexa app info? How stupid is that. Why can't "Echo, turn on my last alarm" work on the device itself? Why do I have to go into my 5" phone screen to turn on my 5.5" Echo device? It makes no sense.

Hopefully the software will catch up to the hardware, and Amazon's software engineers will realize if you have an option for "EVERY WEEKDAY" then the Echo shouldn't turn that alarm off every morning. And if the device does turn it off every morning, simply saying, "Echo, turn my last alarm back on" should work. Or "Echo, show my alarm history/list" should show the list so we can tap the one we want without having to go into our phone app.

After all those issues it gets 3 stars for auto dimming, and night mode, which is very cool orange numbers on a black screen. But I bought it to be used as an alarm clock, not just a clock. If they figure it out - they can start by putting the app info onto the device - I'll review my alarm clock review.

I was excited to get this but it has been a bit of a disappointment. I had a dot in my bedroom already but wanted a Show that could function as an alarm clock and show me my calendar and show news as I was getting ready, show the front door camera, etc. (These are the sorts of use cases this device is being marketed toward, as a bedside device) It does these things, of course, but with certain significant drawbacks. First, the voice recognition on this model is quite poor compared to what I had. Previously my dot was across the room and worked pretty well from my bed. Occasionally it might mishear me. I put this model much closer to me, on my nightstand, but it still has a lot of trouble - it doesn’t always respond to the wake word and frequently mishears me. I often have to repeat commands two to four times before it understands me. Never had these problems with the dot. Second, the screen is annoying on my nightstand. At first it was intolerably bad but I read some other reviews, adjusted some settings, and now it’s just bad. On its lowest brightness, with night mode enabled and with a dark theme and all “ads” disabled, it’s still way too bright. I can ask it to turn off its screen every night but it’s a bit of a pain. I wish it could auto turn off at a given time or respond to my smartphone “goodnight” command, rather than be an extra step each night. Oh ya, and since I have to turn the brightness down so low to get any sleep, it’s too dim the rest of the time so I tend not to use it or else have to manage the brightness twice a day, in the morning and at bedtime. Bleh. So much potential but the little details ruin everything. I appreciate and have come to depend on my other Echo products but this could use some fine tuning from the user experience perspective. I’ll probably return to using my gen2 dot in this room and await further refinements.

Yeah, it's basically an Echo Dot with a screen. Able to get both visual and audio feedback.

All features can to utilized if you own a phone/tablet with clock app, and another echo device. But may not be as compact or have a portable form factor. Also the Echo Show 5 is somewhat more convenient depending on what you plan do with it.

The 5 in the name is not the the iteration rather a 5.5 inch screen size. Similar to non XL phones. Naming is probably in line with Amazon's Kindle Fire line of devices. In fact if you put a phone next to it, it may be around the same size (probably without the large bezels). Review photos, show it next to an iphone XR

First impression: Looks like an alarm clock. Has an always on display. Does not have a static clock display as it cycles through random trending news, weather and alexa voice suggestions along with the time and date. Your next alarm/timer countdown shows up on the upper right of the screen which is a very nice feature. No need to go into Alexa app or ask Alexa when's the next alarm if you forgot.

You can set a background screen saver of pictures through your Amazon Photo profile if you don't like the default backgrounds or want to use it as a digital photo frame

When using the activation word Alexa; it doesn't have the nice circular lights as the other echo devices, instead just a horizontal line on bottom of the screen. Would be cool if there's LEDs around the entire edge of device when you say the key word.

2 mics vs 4 on Echo Dot 3rd gen. But has 1 more than most older echo devices.

Doesn't have a physical Alexa button like the echo dot, so must use voice activation word; unless you link it to an Amazon remote.

Screen doesn't show text of what you say. Example: Google assistant on your phone will show you what it predict you're saying if you use microphone/voice feature. Will show you various slides relevant to what you ask it. Example: when you ask for movie show times it's easier to view a list on screen then having Alexa reading out audibly on an echo dot the entire list of show times

Device has a physical privacy shutter on camera. Camera is not really impressive at 1 mega pixel. It's not HD, but the person on the other side can recognize you (unless their vision is really bad)

Able to watch video on Amazon Prime, similar experience to watching on phone with lower resolution. Can watch youtube, but through silk internet browser. Probably never use it unless absolutely necessary like the 3DS or Wii U Nintendo systems if you own them.

Music. Able to view highlighted lyrics as song is playing if you're steaming music from Amazon Music. Karaoke style. Not able to do this with spotify music though.

Sunrise alarm feature. 15mins before your alarm, the screen will gradually turn brighter mimicking a sun rise. only works if you set your alarm between 4am and 9am and with auto brightness on (on by default) as it'll gradually increase to max brightness. Amazon probably only made it work between these times since your room may still be dark; as in a lighter setting the gradual light brightness may not have any effect. At night the screen will auto adjust to a black ground with orange text.

Tap top of the device with palm and/or fingers to snooze alarm. Cannot customize snooze times. Always set to 10mins

No battery. If power and/or internet goes out; alarm won't sound off similar to other echo devices. Unless you have backup power in your home or hook it up to a backup generator/battery.

Micro USB port on back is not for power. Micro usb port possibly for firmware updates without internet connection.

Power is supplied through a proprietary cable like most other echo devices. Wall outlet is huge and can take up an extra plug space especially if you use a power strip

Compared to Echo Show, it has a smaller screen/lower resolution and the audio is not as good. No Dolby audio. able to connect a speaker to it via 3.5mm cable. It may distort at higher volume. Has good bass, able to feel the vibrations on the table. Speakers are on back, so won't fill the room as much as the Echo Dot which has a 360 speaker. Fabric on speaker similar to echo dot and Google Home Mini

Able to link the ring door bell. only able to view live video. cannot view motions or rings. Takes about 5secs to load when viewing.

vs nest hub. depends on what echo system your household is using Google or Amazon

If you have a old phone/tablet laying around (use always on alarm app) and an echo dot, you can just put them close together to essentially do the same thing with some workarounds. If you don't want to jump through a lot of hoops, you can just pay for convenience

I have a house full of echo devices. Starting back with the 1st generation ones that came out. I was totally shocked and blown away by how well the microphones worked in them. I have echo dots that hear you precisely and they are located over in a different room. I waited on trying out this echo show but I recently got the Ring doorbell and the notion of being able to see who was at the door was intriguing. Plus being able to watch videos sounded appealing too. I got two of these echo shows and they both act exactly the same. I have been in the process of moving the last couple of months so didnt really get a chance to put these to the test. I have been using them quite a bit the last two weeks now and here is what I can say. They are practically worthless for having the microphone pick up what you say. I would say there is a serious design flaw in that they only pick up what you say when you are directly facing it. And even then if there is other noise happening they dont hear me.

I wish I was not past the return period because they are no good for me. I have put them aside and have gone back to using the echo dots that work great.

For the echo show engineers- You need to work on having the Echo Show be able to hear you from wherever you are at in the room. Here is a good example- Lets say I am preparing a meal in the kitchen. I want to look up a recipe. The echo show will do that. But lets say I move from there and want to stream music. If I am in a position where I cant directly be in front of the echo it is not able to pick up what I say with the microphone.
Also- I havent discussed the speaker quality yet but it needs serious help.

I really like these products, but it is so frustrating that you can't turn off the "Things to try" suggestions on the screen. You can google all you want, set all the sliders and app settings you want. It simply does not go away. At one point it did, but there must have been an update and I now I wish I could return all these products.

For those who don't care what ad pollution is on their screen, this is a great product. For those like me, who want to see exactly what you desire, stay away.

PS. Amazon does not care and probably won't until more people just dump their product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does not support Amazon Recast TV just an FYI
reviews.reviewText:
Despite product description on the Amazon Recast, the Echo show 5 does not support Amazon Recast. Been on with their tech support team and they can't figure it out either and in fact, hung me up multiple times because they don't know what to do. Great Amazon Tech support. Will rethink twice again before buying something version 1 from Amazon again. Giving it an additional star because it does have good speaker if you want to use it as a music device. That's really about all it can do at this point.

Update: Lowering to 1 star for the poor Amazon support. They will transfer you around at least 10 different times, I have the Chat Script to prove it. And then they will ultimately hung you up. 10:17 AM PDT Lalitha: Let me connect you to a member of our FireTV team. It will only take a moment.10:17 AM PDT Pranali(Amazon): Hello, my name is Pranali. Please give me a moment to review the previous correspondence.10:20 AM PDT Amreen Afsha(Amazon): Hi this is Amreen and 10:20 AM PDT I am a member of the kindle and echo escalation department and I will be assisting you from here on. 10:21 AM PDT Amreen Afsha: i see you are having issues with your fire tv reccast and since i am not trained on that i would have to transfer you to the correct department, then he hung up on the chat completely.

$50 for this seems like quite a deal. Needed a bedside alarm clock and this fits the bill perfectly. Seamless Plug and Play functionality is so easy to overlook these days as it's simply expected, and this couldn't have been easier. A little creepy that it knows who you are when you turn it on but that goes with the territory. Bought a cloud cam during last year's Prime Day (also an amazing product for $60). I asked Alexa to show me footage from the Cloud Cam and up it popped in 3 seconds. Pretty amazing to be watching the feed from an IR camera in the dark at the snap of a finger from a different floor of your house. Sound is deep and full enough to adequately fill a bedroom provided it's not huge and you aren't an over-bearing audiophile. At $50 it's an absolute steal, at $90 it's fairly priced.

UPDATE: After using this thing for a day or so I have to qualify the last sentence and say that for $50 this device is literally like buying a $10 bill for $5 and at $90 it's still a solid deal. This is a easily a $100 device...the more I listen to the music on it the more it impresses me. The pricing of this says to me that Jeff Bezos desperately wants to be in your bedroom...hey, enjoy yourself Jeff you kinky bugger, you earned it Also,. I am reviewing from the perspective of an alarm clock/bedside utility/lower to middle-end speaker device; for use in the kitchen or as a dedicated home entertainment device I would suggest the Show with the larger screen or for strictly music the Sonos One.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor Voice Recognition / Defective Speaker / Poor Amazon Replacement Policy
reviews.reviewText:
Ordered 3 of the devices during Prime Day sale, but 2 of the 3 have issues - one with a microphone that doesn't correctly pick up audio or recognize voice commands, and a second with a speaker that crackles and loses consistent audio (tone/volume varies wildly) The 3rd device is perfectly fine, so this is a quality control issue ... and luckily I have the 3rd device to verify that it was not an issue with placement or interference.

Attempts to contact customer service and obtain what should have been a simple replacement have been unproductive and a waste of my time. Hoping for a return authorization / label and new replacement devices to be shipped, but continuously told to wait for further assistance - first was told this would be solved within 24 hours, and then told by the end of the week. Both time periods passed without any proactive follow-up from Amazon customer service. After 4 chats/phone calls totaling nearly 2 hours, I am ready to give up and return all of the devices and switch to a Google home device instead - expect better quality control and customer service (and likely no need for service based on friends and family feedback on the Google devices.)

reviews.reviewTitle: Dont get if this if you are nearsighted and were hoping for a cool nightstand clock.
reviews.reviewText: I loved my show 5 until the other day. They did something and my nice large clock display is gone and the home screen is replaced with the date and time tiny in the corner. I loved being able to see the time without my glasses. Now I have to say "show clock" to see it. I have found no way to make the clock go back to being the home screen. I did love the way the screen adapted to light. I could still see it but it was muted at night and when it starts to get lighter it adjusts the brightness to fit perfect. But unless the fix whatever they broke...I'm very dissatisfied with their update if that's what it was.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice at first but ultimately disappointing
reviews.reviewText:
[update 2] Truly regret getting this device. Now, during the day, it gets stuck on the "try asking..." screen where the time is in small font. It will cycle to the time after I give a command, but then goes back to the try-asking screen. Tried resetting and evrything possible...my next move will be to sell this POS. I loved my Amazon Tap and that has been running great for years, but never buying an Echo again. 0 stars.

[update] Today, the alarm didn't go off while it was playing music. The alarm should take priority over anything else it's doing!! Not acceptable! And Amazon wouldn't even allow me to exchange this defective unit for the same one! Yeah, I did the whole reset/restart thing, but my confidence in this device is very low now and will not likely get another. Looking to get a Google Home Hub next.

I was skeptical before purchasing the ES5 as other devices like this (from Google, Lenovo) got much better reviews. But I bit on the Prime Day hype and got this at a great price. I have an Echo Tap, so I thought it would at least be a step up in quality, functionality, & features. Won’t go into how frustratingly long it took to arrive, but I was excited when it finally did. And the first few days, I did love it: it’s cute, works well as a bedside clock (lens cover always on, of course), small footprint even with the stand.

But then the annoyances started to built: if you want to use your own photos, you have to upload photos to Amazon Photo, plus the transitions between pics are abrupt when they should be smooth. There’s no access to youtube and watching amazon prime video is extremely limited. Videos are not that big of a deal since I have my tablets where videos are better than on a tiny 5” screen, but it can be an issue if this is for your kitchen where you want to watch recipes and such. I thought Spotify would work better, but it’s the same limited functions as on my previous Echo. Plus, when you play Spotify, there's so much wasted space on the screen AND you lose the clock!

But the biggest issue I have are the “Try this...” messages that pop up. Yes, I’ve done the whole settings thing to supposedly turn them all off, but they’re still there. Anytime you ask Alexa to perform a task, the screen switches to a task screen, then switches back to the clock for about 10 seconds then switches to a “try this...” message for about 3 seconds. After that it stays on the clock face...that is until you ask Alexa to do another task and it all happens again.

Despite its shortcomings, I’m keeping it. Meh, it’s a fifty-buck alarm clock that works with my smart home. And I figure I can trade it in when (if) they come out with an improved version next year. But if you’re considering buying one, PLEASE don’t pay more than fifty dollars...it’s not worth it.

So you should probably know ahead of time, I am an Alexa addict. ADDICT!!! I am a flight attendant and the first thing I think when I walk into a hotel room is "Alexa, lights on." Then I realize there is no Alexa and I sigh. I wish I could figure out a way to easily take Alexa with me while I travel. (And yes, I travel with the FireStick, but it's just not the same Alexa experience.)

Having said that, I love this Echo Show. It is just the right size. When I'm on a trip, I can pop in on it and call out to my kids to come to the Alexa so I can talk to them face to face from my Alexa phone app. The picture takes a minute to clear up on my phone, but the calls work out well. It also only shows the ceiling when you pop in on it, so you don't have to worry that anyone who video calls you will be able to see anything (or that government can see all of your moves). There is also a little button that allows you to physically cover the camera with flap so no one can see on the camera if you don't want it. I actually want to get one of these for my bedroom because my husband works nights and sleeps during the days. He's accidentally slept in when he was supposed to be picking up one of my kids from school. If we had one in our room, my daughter could have popped in on it to see that "Dad" was sleeping and either yell at him to wake up (because he doesn't hear the phone when he's sleeping) or realize that she needed to take the bus home.

We also use it for recipes, lights, the thermostat, to control our TV and to learn words to songs. I love that it shows the current weather outside all day and will flash to the week's weather forecast as well since we live in Chicago and the weather changes hourly. Soon I plan on getting the Alexa microwave and maybe one of those smart faucets to let Alexa control that too. Some part of me fears that Alexa will one day be the AI that sends Schwarzenegger back into the past to kill John Connor, but at the same time, I'm loving her too much to unplug her. I feel like we are living in an awesome "in-between time" of when technology is our best friend and when the robots turn on us. I'm going to enjoy the "in-between time" while I can and just hope that the robotics companies stop programming attack robots (like you can watch on YouTube... lol.)

I highly recommend getting one. It's much easier to use than the Google Home box (which we also have but ended up shelving).
I bought this to replace my eco dot. It was a great investment. Came out of the box ready to go. Just plug it in and it automatically connects to wifi from your older device.

Its just more junk not yet fully ready.
Tech support is just as bad !
When it’s facing away, there is no way to see if she heard you.

I upgraded from my Gen 2 Echo Dot to this Echo Show 5 and I like how compact it is and how clear the screen is. It's a great little device with some nice added features that you can see and hear very well. I really wanted to give this 5 stars, but there are two things that are extremely annoying (to me), that I'm told cannot be changed, that keep my rating lower.
