1. The bottom of the screen constantly shows tips..."Try saying Alexa (insert tip here)." There is no way to turn off that feature. Being an Echo device Veteran, this is both distracting and annoying, since the screen is constantly flashing different tips, which causes me to look at the screen. I currently have it right next to my computer screen, so it's a pain not to be able to turn that feature off.
2. I love that this device works with my Ring security cameras and you can ask it to show you the camera...however, there is a delay from the time you ask, until you see the camera view. I have the best wi-fi and super fast internet here, so I know that isn't the issue. The delay isn't good, especially when using this device with a Ring Doorbell. By the time you see who's at the door and try to speak with them, they are already leaving. I would love to see an option to automatically launch the Ring Camera video on the Echo Show, when motion is detected. That might improve the delay problem it currently has.
Otherwise, I am enjoying the Echo Show 5 very much and my favorite feature is the manual camera shutter, which let's me block the camera lens when I'm not using it. Great feature for added security.

I got this to replace the Echo Dot in my bedroom and it works perfectly as a bedside alarm clock. I have quite a few Echo devices now including a couple Spots and I can't see any reason for getting a Spot over this unless you really need the smaller footprint of the Spot. It simply does everything the Spot can do, but with a larger screen, cheaper price and better privacy.

I was about to get another Echo Spot until I saw the Show 5 up for pre-order and I'm glad I procrastinated up until then. With my short sightedness, it would have been difficult to see the time from bed had I gotten the Spot, but the Show 5's screen allows the time to be shown in big numbers. I can also answer the door if someone rings my Ring Doorbell Pro or I get a motion alert and see much more detail compared to what I can see on the Spot. Having a physical cover over the camera, which the Spot lacks, also brings better peace of mind.

As one would expect, the sound on the Echo Show 5 is not amazing, but it gets the job done for what it would mainly be used for. For music, connecting a dedicated Bluetooth speaker(s) would be a more preferable option.

Lastly, they need an option to disable the Alexa "try" suggestion cards. It wouldn't be hard to do and yet they prefer to leave it in and annoy customers and lose sales despite the massive amount of feedback given on the subject. Instead, they spend the time to add an additional side swipe menu screen, which I don't find much use for personally, though I suppose it would be useful for someone that is mute.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for a bedroom or side table
reviews.reviewText:
We use this in our bedroom in place of an alarm clock. We had an echo dot in the bedroom but wanted to upgrade so that we would have a clock. My wife hates anything that has a screen on it, she thinks they control too much of our lives; I actually think she was destined to be born in the middle ages but was born in the wrong time period. She actually loves the Echo Show 5 because she said she was always asking the Echo dot what time it is, now we just have to look at the new Show 5. This is really nice when waking up in the morning to see quickly whether you need to get up or you have more time to sleep.

We haven't done anything special for the setup other than change the background of the clock. At night it automatically dims and does not scroll through the different feeds, it just stays on the clock. During the day we let it scroll through the feeds, but we like seeing the news stories and Alexa suggestions. In the App it is super easy to turn these off though.

Setup was easy, but I had one problem with my Philips Hue lights. For some reason a new group was setup in my Alexa App named bedroom (I stated the Echo would be in my bedroom but I'm not sure why Alexa created a "Bedroom" group). My Philips Hue lights have a group named bedroom. Therefore, when I asked Alexa to turn off the bedroom lights it would default to the Alexa bedroom group and would say that the bedroom didn't support that function. After a little digging I deleted the Alexa group named bedroom and everything started working again.

All functions, at least that I used, work with Alexa. I set my morning alarm to wake me up to classical music. The voice recognition is good and I don't have to yell at it. I thought the speakers would be better just based on the reviews. However, compared to other items this size and cost the sound is really good, much better than a typical alarm clock.

My plan is to load pictures to it and have it scroll through pictures during the day to be like a digital picture frame.

All-in-all I think the Echo Show 5 is well worth it. In our house we also have various echo dots, an echo, and an echo show. The Echo Show 5 has been a good addition.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cute, but not ready for Prime Time
reviews.reviewText:
UPDATED 7/29/19 AMazon Deliver notifications also not coming throughI Also the photo timer (you can set each phjoto to show for 2, 6, or 10 seconds DOES NOT WORK! It's as if the little Echo has a mind of it's own. THis one for 2 sec, this on for 45 sec.

I got this on prime day for peanuts, so I really can't complain, but I'm goint to anyhow! This cute little job sits on my desk in my home office and I get to enjoy it all day long. And while it is cute, it’s not even as good as a regular echo dot!

The biggest crowd pleaser with this tiny echo show is the little tiny screen. I was so looking forward to seeing my photos one, after another, after another. Unfortunately, after setting up a couple hundred pictures, I have discovered that it only plays the same 25 or 30 over and over and over and over and over......... seemingly never showing the other 175!

Then I find out that my notifications are not coming through. Both my calendar and my "Amazon delievered your package" notifications are not coming through. They work on the echo dot I have. The calendar announcements are voice spoken and the delievered announcement light up the ring of the echo in green. They work on the echo that I have sitting next to the Echo SHow 5 (it was my baseline for comparision). Even Customer Tech Support couldn’t figure out this one.

So while I do like my echo show (although I would be royally pissed if I had paid full price) it would be nice if they would fix these two and I’m sure a few other glitches that I haven’t discovered yet.

I’ve only had it for three days, so I’ll update this in a few weeks and let you know if Amazon has fixed any of the above.

I purchased the Echo Show 5 to replace a 2nd gen Echo Dot that I attached to an old iHome digital clock radio that I connected via the aux jack. The sound of this setup was descent but the footprint on my nightstand was too much. This made the Echo Show 5 an attractive alternative. Its small form factor and use of a display was definitely appealing. I ordered the Echo Show 5 during Prime Day for a great price. For that I am happy. However, while there are some positives, there are some negatives for me regarding this device:

Positives -
* Small footprint
* Attractive style of fabric design
* Auto-dimming available functionality
* Loud output for size

Negatives -
* Booming sound (Despite adjusting the Equalizer in the Alexa app, the sound is very bass heavy.)
* Downward firing speaker (The location of the speaker may be the source of the booming sound. This also making placing the device on a solid surface a must to get the most sound).
* Alexa microphones (While the 2nd gen Echo Dot had supported by seven microphones on top -- six in a circle, one in the center, the Echo Show 5 only appears to have two microphones on its top. This may be what is causing the Echo Show 5 to not hear my commands. Its so bad that the Echo Dot in my living room will respond before the Show in the bedroom).
* Screen interface is a little slow, but manageable
* Rubber bottom (The gray rubber bottom was placing marks on my nightstand as though I was rubbing an eraser across it. This problem was solved by adding felt pads to the bottom. I used thicker pads to try to improve the sound for me).
* Access to YouTube is currently limited

Overall - The device is okay but am hoping for some improvements in a version 2.

reviews.reviewTitle: Comes with 5ft power cord instead of 6ft cord (6ft is provided with even the Echo dots)
reviews.reviewText:
I got this when it was on sale, so price was not an issue. This is a nice introduction to the Spot echo system and allows you to get an idea of what having a touch screen on an echo dot buys you. It only has 2 microphones so it does not pick up and understand my voice as well as the 3rd gen dot that I replaced it with. It is nice to have the clock face with weather displayed when not in use. Also nice to have album art and/or lyrics when streaming music. I would give it 4 stars, but instead of including a 6 foot power cord, they tried to cut a few cents and cut the cord to 5 feet. I needed that extra foot. I had to swap the cord on one of my echo dots which does come with a 6 foot cord. Why would they do that. Minus another one point. Sound quality is OK. Some functions that are easily changed in the Alexa app for the Echo Dot have been removed and force you to use the touch screen on the Spot 5 or are missing all together compared to the Dot. If I ever get a video door bell it will be nice to see action at the front door while in my office. So I'm future proofing a little here. The 1 MP camera is a bit disappointing compared to the 5 MP of its big brother. The screen is quite grainy compared to most smart phones and tablets these days. Some of the down grades and short cuts make this more of a toy, but does help to keep the price down. I would not pay full price for this, so I would suggest that you wait for the regular sales throughout the year if this is on your list but you are hesitating because of the price. At the sale price it is easier to forgive it's short comings.
Update:
Changing my review from 3 stars to 1 star. After the last software update, the Show 5 will not stop displaying the "Try 'bla, bla, bla'" try this , try that, nag screens. Yes I have "Rotate Continuously" turned off. I also have everything else turned off. Enough is enough, I bought this to display the clock in full screen not to be minimized to the upper left corner so Amazon can push their useless "Things to Try". Unless they fix this issue, which is one of the biggest complaints by other users, then I would not recommend this or any of the Echo Shows. I should probably send this back and give a Google Nest Hub a try.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good stuttering start with a clear, but unfortunately necessary, upgrade path and capability
reviews.reviewText:
This is a really nice piece of technology to improve upon and greatly surpass the alarm clock radio, which was my primary requirement. After some futzing around, I was able to set via voice an alarm to come on weekdays at 6:20am to my local PBS radio station via the TuneIn integrated app. I have a favorite photo as the clock background and the clock dims marvelously in response to ambient light levels. Additionally, it is a regular interface to Alexa via voice command. As a replacement for my old radio alarm clock, it wins hands down. Although setting it up took quite some (unnecessary) doing.

There are three input and status checking mechanisms: voice control via local or remote Alexa; the Alexa app on phone or tablet; and, the touch screen. The absence of a meaningful written manual means that one is left to experiment with the currently limited and inconsistent trio of interfaces, each of which seems capable of different things. There is no one ring to rule them all, as far as I can see ... yet.

The adverbs scattered about above - yet, currently, etc - plus the "futzing" indicate the strengths and weaknesses of the device. Clearly, it is early days and the users should help drive the improvement of the interface. I have already sent my list to Amazon ... no response! As a repeat early adopter - I received mine on day 2 of availability - this is partly my own fault. But Amazon needs to provide much better written information about menus and capabilities of the device and of the role of each of the interface mechanisms. I really truly lament that thousands of people will be fleeced of their money on a totally useless book called something like An Idiot's Guide to Echo Show 5, which will promise, but totally fail, to reveal the tricks. It should not be this way. Amazon lost a star because of this. There is not even a website or any useful guidance to menus on screen or in apps. Maybe they expect someone else, through sheer exasperation, to set up a Stack Exchange page. It won't be me.

However, and in absolutely no way forgiving of their omission, the mere existence of an automated online upgrade path for the device is one way to ensure that it updates and upgrades to achieve it evident potential. Of course, this all presupposes that someone actually tells people what has been done.

I want to set up and control my device. I do not want to hear another pirate joke from Alexa. Amazon, please get moving on the documentation and the capabilities. Then you might get one more star.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent as an Alexa alarm clock
reviews.reviewText:
This is the best alarm clock I've ever had. There are a lot of reviews for this device, so I'll just list a few things that I'm really impressed by:
- The clock face is customizable and very easy to read from anywhere in the room. The screen has no distortion or discoloration from any angle, so it is easy to see from everywhere.
- The screen adapts to the surrounding light. At night, when the room is completely dark, the screen decreases to almost black with just red numbers for the clock. Perfect for checking the time in the middle of the night, and more comfortable than my older LED numbered clocks.
- The alarm clock has a slow volume increase, so if I can wake up to the softer tones, then I can turn it off before my wife wakes up. If I'm sleeping really deeply, then it will increase until I finally wake up.
- You can set a recurring alarm to every day or every weekday, and it's easy to skip a day on the schedule by just saying "Alexa, skip tomorrow's alarm." There is a small notification in the top-right corner that shows the next upcoming alarm.
- The music alarm can be sourced from Spotify, Amazon Music, or Pandora (probably other sources as well), so I can wake up to a particular song or to a station if I want to wake up to a different song of the same genre.
- The touch-screen is very responsive, so when the alarm goes off in the morning, you can speak audibly to turn it off, or you can reach over to swipe "Dismiss" or swipe down to snooze.
- Some of the skills that are designed for Echo Show are great. I recommend playing Jeopardy or looking up recipes.
- My wife is very grateful for the physical camera shutter as we keep it in our bedroom.

Some things that I don't love:
- Every once in a while, it will forget the recurring alarm, so you have to reset it. It's a bit of a hassle to explain to Alexa when you want the alarm to go off on what schedule to what music station. Small complaint for how great everything has been.
- The screen is small, so I don't recommend trying to watch shows or movies on it. It would be similar to setting your phone on the counter and watching a movie on it.
- Others have mentioned the scrolling screen. This is not a big deal to me, but you can limit what scrolls through, so it's pretty much just the weather and a few suggestions for what to try. This has been a deal-breaker for some, but I'm not certain why. This doesn't happen at night (at least as far as I've noticed) when the screen is black with red numbers. I suspect that the Echo does it to avoid burned images in the screen; if that's the case, then I'm grateful for it.

Bottom line: I highly recommend it as a very smart and very useful alarm clock and Echo device. It has its limitations, but frankly, for the price, the limitations are minuscule compared with the benefits of it. We did have it in our kitchen previously (I thought it would be nice to be able to look up recipes hands-free), but we didn't find it to be that useful there, so at least for our situation, it has been an excellent bed-side alarm clock/Echo.

reviews.reviewTitle: Show 5 review from a Spot owner
reviews.reviewText:
There is a lot of details already in these reviews, so I just wanted to add a few points. TL;DR is I'm very happy with this upgrade.

My primary reason for wanting to replace my Spot on our bedside table with the new Show 5 was my own poor eyesight . . . I wanted to be able to know what time it was by looking at the thing with my glasses off. That problem is happily solved with the Show.

First off anyone who is seeing lots of ads hasn't spent much time in the setup. I mostly want to see the time displayed, and it wasn't hard to tell the device not to be constantly showing other stuff in the full screen (which might include stocks, weather, tips / suggestions, etc.) I do still get a row at the bottom of the screen suggesting Alexa commands to try, but it's small and not intrusive. If it was showing big ads on the screen I'd send it back, but that is not what this is.

My second point concerns a problem that I had and managed to resolve. After I replaced the Spot with the Echo 5, there were multiple times when I started to get something similar to static from the device, kind of a distortion. It made Alexa sound like she had a lisp, and music was noticeably distorted. A reset of the device would solve the problem temporarily but then it came back after a while. At some point I realized that I had replaced the Echo itself, but not the power adapter; I was still using the adapter from the Spot. When I swapped this for the adapter that came with the Show 5, this problem disappeared and it now sounds fine. If this always happened I think we'd be seeing more complaints about it, but if you happen to encounter this issue I highly recommend trying a different adapter if you have one. The old adapter still works fine for the Spot, and I think the specs for the adapters are the same so I don't have an explanation for why this matters, but there you are.

Finally I wanted to comment on sound quality for music, since I know that was one of my questions when pondering this upgrade. The Show 5 sounds significantly better than the Spot. There are a lot of small bluetooth speakers around these days that sound much better than it seems they should for their size, and the Show 5 must be doing some of the same tricks. It's not quite as good as my Bose Soundtouch (which I connect the Echo to via bluetooth if I'm spending significant time in the bedroom) but it's close.

I will say that the Alexa app still seems to have some rough edges working with the new device. Sometimes the new device disappears from the app device list altogether and I need to restart the app. But that's minor IMO and I'm sure will soon be resolved.

So in conclusion I'd say it's a worthwhile upgrade especially if you have another place to put the Spot. I now have it as a clock sitting on my computer that can tell me how to spell things.

I see there are a lot of complaints and for the most part I do not understand ,most of them. The constant scrolling is 100% a pain and you can turn 90% of it off. It is 100% worth the price to either upgrade from the spot(trade it in, will knock about $30 of the price) I feel it is exactly what it is suppose to be. A spot with a bigger screen at $40 less. It is 100% worth the money. You want more quality pay the bigger price and buy the show. You want a really cool bedside clock that has 100s of more functions then a regular clock you can not go wrong here for the price. If you want to pay $90 but expect $300 in quality well good luck.. I will say though the Mics are very very bad. I use it as an alarm and when the music plays I really have to yell at it for it to respond

reviews.reviewTitle: Revised Review - The best echo show yet marred by annoying "try" feature
reviews.reviewText:
Revised review:
The software on this device is infuriating. It simply will NOT display the numerals of the clock large and in the center of the screen 24/7. Instead, it frequently (FREQUENTLY!) makes the time display small and shoves it in the corner while it suggests that I "try" this or that feature. I've read all sorts of posts about this issue and have dug into the menus both on the device and in the app and there's no way to turn this "feature" off. Amazon, listen up! If this is going to sit on my nightstand and be my primary clock, IT NEEDS TO DISPLAY THE TIME! As it stands now, the display is useless. I'd be better off with a regular Echo, or no Echo at all. A $12 digital clock works better than this device. What a total waste of money.

Original review:
I wanted an Echo alarm clock but wasn't convinced that the spot was really useful due to its small screen. My eyesight is pretty bad so I need something with large numbers so I can read them at night. For a while, I used my gen 1 Echo as a clock, just using voice commands but that got old fast. I was thrilled to see this new form factor Echo and bought it as soon as it went on sale. It's the perfect size and has all the features I want in a nightstand device. On top of that, it actually sounds really great and the mics are very proficient at hearing me, even from another room. They're so good that my gen 1 Echo seems to be hard of hearing in comparison. I like the choices of background images and especially like the camera cover. The only thing missing is YouTube.

Bottom line - this is like having a smart phone on your nightstand with a dedicated speaker. What's not to love at this price point?

When I first got this device 3 months ago I mostly liked it, but then it started displaying "Try asking Alexa.." almost continuously instead of showing the big clock. But for the past week that is better and now I only get Alexa suggestions about once a day. Maybe Amazon is paying attention to all the reviews complaining about this.
Original review:
Every time I look over to see the time, this screen is showing a message about something I should try out with Alexa. I have all the home screen notifications turned off but you cannot turn off Alexa ads. It appears that Alexa ads have taken over all Echo devices with a screen.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love the echo show 5 for monitoring my ring security cameras
reviews.reviewText: I purchased the echo show 5 so I could view my ring doorbell and floodlight cameras without having to use my cell phone. It works perfectly for this reason. When I ask Alexa to show me either garage camera (floodlight) or backdoor camera (ring 2 doorbell) it responds within 5-10 seconds. I get the camera feed(s) for at least 10 miniutes (haven't really timed it). I can watch my dog when she goes out and even talk to her (freaked her out at first but now she's used to me being invisible). At this point, I get only 'live views' and not any recordings or this is possible but I just don't know how to request a past event. The ES5 allows the microphone to be activated on both the ring doorbell and floodlight, but I can't turn on the floodlight or the siren (features available in the ring phone app) but I'm sure these software features can be added at a later date. The camera views are surprisingly sharp and clear even at night. The sound is amazing as I can even hear birds singing or crickets chirping! At night, I use the echo show 5 for an alarm clock (it's about the same size). There's a setting that allows the display to be dimmed at night but the normal display really doesn't bother me at night. I replaced a dot with the echo show 5 and basically use it the same way except for the ring video views. I've had no wifi connection problems but I upgraded my router and added a wifi extender when I got the ring devices. Highly recommend the echo show 5 to use with Ring security cameras.

It is much smaller than I thought. I have the previous model and it doesn’t compare. However it’s affordable and serves its purpose. I have it in the kid’s bedroom. The larger model in the family room. The screen size is equivalent to my IPhone. But we like it.
I bought two when they were on sale. Gave the other to my mom. She’s struggling with the brightness but it’s probably something that can be fixed.

I totally love this echo 5! So much that I have spent a lot of time trying to get on here to write my review. I have several other echoes that I like, but this one is the best!
I just love the size of it because my bedroom is in the basement and has a shelf/ledge around the room. It fits perfectly on it and I can see it quite well from the bed. The other benefit is the price as I was trying to save up for the higher price ones.
Just last night I had a little bit of a time getting to sleep. I asked for a story and then some relaxing music. It worked like a charm.
What fun these days are with such cool devices, so “Jetsons”! Try one of these it’s great fun!

We have Echo Devices in every room, outside and in the car.
Also have apps on our phones and Fire HD's
This is our first stand alone Echo w/ Video capability as it really isn't a priority w/ us.
It performs all the functions of the other Echos well.
(Thanks to others here who described how to tweak the Display Settings!!)
It even flashes the Hue Lights in the house when the Timer goes off... as do most of our others.
Phone Function works GREAT as does Drop In. I just Dropped In to the Echo Auto.

Some of the comments have me confused.
First off the laws of physics say the size of the Echo Show 5 dictates how good/loud/deep the sound will be from the device. There is a 3.5mm Audio Out Jack.... use it! I hooked it to an old powered Sub/Stereo PC speaker array I had laying around and it sounds fine on Pandora and Prime Music.
Secondly it, as well as your phone, was never intended to be a Video display platform.
I use our 65" 4K TV or my 32" 4k PC Monitor for those chores.
Haven't tried Video Calls yet but that's on the menu.

We got this and a Smart Plug as part of a Prime Day Deep Discount Deal and I'm pleased.

As Background, I have many echo devices, including the original show, the spot, etc. My expectations going in were a smaller echo show device, with a limited sounding speaker and downgraded video display , was I wrong! For the size of this device, the sound is excellent, the display is crisp and the size is perfect for my office desk. It would work well as alarm clock but the echo spot is less intrusive so keep that in mind. The overall dimension is approximately the size of large mobile phone(6 inch or so).

Sound: Like I stated earlier, the sound is excellent, the bass is very good for a device this small.
Video: The display is good, I played a few music videos from Vevo and I was very impressed.
Cost: Very reasonable, as the cost is lower is $40.00 less then Spot and $140 less then the Show.
New Interface: A swipe right to left, brings up a new menu with 6 functions, communicate, smart home, music, video, routines and alarms. This is much easier to use then the older software version, I hope they roll out this version to the other devices.
Overall: Very Impressed!

reviews.reviewTitle: Upgrading to Show 5 was a mistake
reviews.reviewText:
I upgraded to the Show 5 from an original echo dot.
Big mistake.
This thing is hard of hearing. What was easily understood by the old Dot now requires shouting and over inunciation. And then it's still iffy.

Then there's the screen.
All it does is show Alexa tips and tricks and a little clock.
If you're watching something on it, you'd better remember the season and episode number you're on because, when you ask the Show to turn off a light or *anything* else, it stops what you're watching, exits that app, completes your request, and then stops. You'll need to reload the video app, navigate or request the specific episode you were on, and hit play again.

This thing has a terrible wifi antenna. My old Echo Dot never lost connection once in multiple years of use. The Show 5 sits exactly where my old Dot was and loses its wifi connection every single night. Every night.
And if you're like me, you have rain ambience playing while you sleep.
And when it loses wifi connectivity, the sounds stop.
Then you wake up and ask the show 5 to play rain sounds again.
And Alexa gives you a six paragraph response about how she lost her connection to wifi and how you can take a dozen steps to get it back.
It's great at 3am.

Avoid this garbage at all costs.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor viewing angles plague an otherwise great device.
reviews.reviewText:
It's much more inexpensive than the Spot, but that comes at the expense of cheaper materials, too. The glass is so cheap it bows to your every press and alters the color around your finger. Not only that, but the viewing angle on this device is so unsatisfactory that whomever designed this product had to be looking dead center at it during the entire design process. It's clear that, in order to make this product cheaper than the Spot, they had to use cheaper materials than the Spot. Having had both devices, the Echo Show 5 is more superior in features and design but the Echo Spot is made with better materials and durability.

Edit: knocked it down to 2 stars for its inability to understand me from distances which my Echo Spot never had problems hearing me. (just speaking to it by my bedroom door while my fan is on, which is about 10 feet.)

It's clear that, though the design of this is more convenient and the camera blocker is invaluable, the Echo Spot was manufactured in a manner far superior to this device.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent quality sound , pic and touch screen !
reviews.reviewText: I love this product , the sound is excellent quality same as the picture , very responsive to my orders and faster to check my security cameras instead my phone , I love the touch screen and the fact I can see the videos of my music and the lyrics on the songs , it does everything as the echo dot plus the fact to have the view . I also can personalize , already put the pic of my husband and I and at the other my daughters graduation pic . At night has the automatic sensor light so is not bother at night and if I want the see the time is there with soft light . Too bad my first two where at regular prize but I’m so happy just order two at the special prime day . I highly recommend .

reviews.reviewTitle: FIX THE BUG IN THE ALEXA APP!!!
reviews.reviewText:
The Echo 5 is a sharp gadget. However the Alexa app doesn't show any option for the 5 but it found it. Also, I bought this to go with my Hue lighting and it works sporadically, at best. There is a serious bug that allows you to connect for an hour or so a work flawlessly but then all devices show up as unresponsive. You have to re sync the bridge every time. Unfortunately I bought this mainly for this purpose and will be returning if not rectified.

EDIT: All of the sudden the app has been working flawlessly for a week. Way to go Amazon!!!

The first Echo show 5 I recurved had a hot screen that was hot all the time. This resulted in a return and replacement for me. It was my hope that by doing this, the screen on the replacement wouldn’t be hot and the sound quality would be better.

This was not the case at all. I’ve returned the second Echo show 5 and replaced it with an Echo Dot. The Echo Dot has superior sound quality, understands what I’m saying better, and is much cheaper.

My final thoughts:
-The “Try Alexa” text simply needs to be an option you can change in the settings. There is absolutely no other way around this. There is NO reason I should even be seeing it when using a subscription like Spotify. It makes no sense. Why would a customer want advertising they can’t remove on a speaker they paid too much for, during use of a paid subscription, all from a company that is also a monthly subscription (Prime)?
-the screen being hot is very concerning, and even if amazon finds this to be normal, it is uncomfortable when trying to use the touch screen.
-Why on earth is the sound quality a downgrade from this product when it costs more than the other Echos?
-This becomes a $90 paperweight.
-I enjoyed seeing my calendar on the screen until I realized I could never turn the try Alexa ads off.
-I’ll wait to buy one when these issues are fixed.
-I probably will never buy one again. I doubt these issues will be fixed since the majority of reviews are positive for this Amazon Advertisement Hub.

Let me start by saying I love Amazon devices, I probably have too many already, but decided to give this a try and see if I like it, and for the most part, I do.

I use my devices mostly for music and video, and that is where my biggest complaint is, no YouTube, no Netflix, and
no Vudu. If they could somehow get those on all Echo Show products, they would be the best of the best.

The sound quality is great for such a little thing, highs and mids are pretty clear and has superislngly a good amount of bass.

The video quality, is great as well. regardless if you watch new movies or old shows it looks great.
Its a little larger than the Echo Spot, but its still a managable size for a bedside table or even as an addition to a desk.

Overall It's great, I already love it, and enjoy the features, I just wish they would figure out a way to add YouTube, Netflix, and Vudu, because if they do.. It'll be perfect.

I own two of these. I guess I should have thoroughly read the reviews before purchase. I want only the clock to be displayed. But unfortunately the screen alternately displays the clock and things to try. Turned everything off in settings including rotation but no luck. Display alternates between clock and things to try. Fix it AMAZON.

I Have 3 Echo Dots, the original Alexa, 2 echo Shows and this device. I love my Echo Show as it displays song lyrics as the song is displayed. I have had this smaller Echo Show for 4 days, and I like it and HATE it at the same time. I have the “lyrics” turned on “Alexa turn on lyrics” and the lyrics are displayed for eabout 60 seconds, then vanish and the clock takes over. I have spent hours trying to fix this stupid glitch and have given up. My Original Echo Show will display lyrics continuously for days on end. This does 60 seconds and then they just disappear, and that’s annoying as can be!

UPDATE: how to fix- swipe the screen down and change the Do Not Disturb setting and the lyrics will stay on the screen!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good overall Alexa device with some comebacks.
reviews.reviewText:
This echo device has many pros but some cons. The device is a great size, not to big and not too small. It also has good speakers and is very responsive to the ambient light in my room, adjusting the brightness of the display accordingly. The device adjusts to a very dark but still readable setting when you sleep, so there’s no need to worry about it keeping you up at night. Additionally, you can say “Alexa, turn off screen” to turn the screen off. There are a lot more features on this device as compared to the echo dot family as well, making it very convenient to use.
However, there’s some problems with the device as well. First, the display is very sensitive to touch, if you press the screen with minimal pressure, the screen shows a wave or small bubble around your finger, just like you would see on a laptop screen or tv screen. Second, the microphone is substantially worse than the one on the echo dot, which can sense your voice even when it’s playing music very loudly.

reviews.reviewTitle: Please Give Me Control Over The Content Displayed On My Screen
reviews.reviewText:
Overall I like the device other then I have little to no control over the content displayed on the screen. If I wish to play music, view a news feed, or any of the currently available content you are hit with a "Try this or Try that" message at the bottom of the screen.

Please give me control over the content displayed on my device...

Thank you.

reviews.reviewTitle: Things To Try messages won't go away. No way to stop them.
reviews.reviewText: I thought that by buying the new, improved Echo Show 5, I would be able to turn off the absolutely irritating "Things to Try" messages that fill the screen. No such luck. You should be able to define what you want on your screen, but for all the settings you can tweak, you can't stop these stupid Things to Try suggestions that are constantly on the screen like TV commercials. Until Amazon comes up with an option for removing Things to Try from the display, my review is One Star.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product, not the best camera design
reviews.reviewText:
So we are really late to the Alexa bandwagon as we like our privacy and didn't feel the need to have someone listening in....... With the changes they have made now however we finally felt like it was safe enough to buy an Echo Show 5 (and a couple of Dots). I love that we essentially have a whole home stereo now as I can have my music play across all of the devices. (Great for cleaning days!) I've seen some reviews that have mention poor sound quality but I think it is at least the equivalent to a good quality Bluetooth speaker. I like the announcement feature as I can track my husband down when he is upstairs and I'm downstairs. Lol. I also love that I can drop in throughout the day to check on our dogs while we are at work and I love the Guard (security) feature that you can turn on when you are away. It alerts you if the devices detect the sound of glass breaking or smoke alarms going off. That was an unexpected plus as we hadn't heard anything about that feature.

There is a lot more that you can do with one of these devices than we realized. We spent an hour playing a Song quiz game where Alexa plays a bit of a song and you have to guess the song title and artist.

We like the "drop in" feature pretty well but even with the security features I'm leary of having anything but one of the Echo dot's in our bedroom. There is a slide that covers the camera so I think it would be fine....but just incase I will limit the Echo Show to the less private rooms in my house.
The camera is decent on it and it picks up our voices from a decent distance without us feeling like we have to yell to wake it up. Video quality when you do a drop in will depend on the speed of your internet.... mine isn't great so it takes a minute for the video to be clear but it works...

Now for the negative: Ugh, the location of the camera on the top corner. The way the Echo Show 5 is designed it kind of tilts back. So if you want to drop in and be able to view someone sitting or in my case my pets then it has to basically be tilted forward and down (you have to buy a stand and are pretty limited on options there) .... so it basically looks like it is getting ready to fall over..... (We have ours sitting on a short bookcase and had to purchase a stand for it.)

Overall:
If you don't have one of these products I would highly recommend going to Best Buy or whatever is near you and talking to someone/playing with a demo version. I really didn't think I would like it as much as I do but I now have two Echo Show 5's and two Echo Dots (3rd generation).

(With the holidays coming don't forget you can buy them on payments sometimes on Amazon vs paying in full at a store! (It depends on your Amazon account I think so I'm not sure if that is an option for everyone.))

Disappointed. No YouTube or Hulu. Only Amazon Streaming. Sound quality disappointing. I can view my security cameras. So, that's a plus.

Other than being an alarm clock/weather station, I really am not happy with it.

***10/13/2019 UPDATE***
My original review rated it 2 (TWO) stars. However, I am downgrading it to 1 (ONE) star.

REASON:
Unless I am facing the screen, even if I am a foot away, my other echo devices in other rooms will hear me, yet this one does not. In order for it to respond, I have to be facing the screen. Even if I am a foot away.

I was mistaken, you can watch YouTube through the integrated browser.

Still incredibly disappointed with this device.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worthless as an Alarm Clock, No way to keep Clock on Screen
reviews.reviewText: I have been very happy with my echo dot but wanted something with a clock on the front so I purchased this. Unfortunately you can't keep the clock on the device at all times. Even if you turn off all the other screens it will constantly cycle between large clock and the Try This amazon suggestions with a tiny clock that is difficult to see. This could be a very good device but I do not recommend it until they fix it.

I have two other Echo devices, so I'm used to them and know how to work with them. I got the Echo Show to use mainly as a bedroom clock, but that was a poor decision on my part. The main problem has been mentioned in many other reviews, and that is that this device wants to show me everything except the one thing I want it to always show - THE CLOCK!! Whenever I look at the "clock" from across the room, I'd really like to see what time it is. Apparently, that's asking too much from this device.

I know all about the tricks to disabling the scrolling Alexa suggestions, and they do work...for a few days. However, every time there is a power surge or flicker, the thing automatically goes back to the scrolling Alexa suggestions. They just won't go away!! What's even more annoying is that when you successfully shut the suggestions off, this thing likes to minimize the clock face ANYWAY. For whatever reason, the clock face and the outside weather like to jump to the upper left side of the display and leave some random picture its place. Then I have to go back to Google to find out how to get it to JUST SHOW THE CLOCK. Once you figure it out again, it'll work...until it decides you need to see something other than the clock. This morning it kept telling me to ask Alexa about Albert Einstein. I don't care what Alexa knows about Albert Einstein. I just want to see what time it is!!!!!

By the way, the sound is really terrible on this thing. On my original Echo, the sound is quite good. With the Echo Show, I tried adjusting the equalizer settings, but it still sounded awful. I've since disconnected it and replaced it with a simple clock that actually shows me what time it is. Siri is now playing music for me when I go to bed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sunrise alarm feature doesn't work after 9 AM
reviews.reviewText: I was excited for this product because it combined everything I love about the Echo series with a sunrise alarm. Since receiving it, however, I am VERY disappointed. There is an absurd restriction - you can only set a sunrise alarm between 5 and 9 AM. How is this helpful?! Why is it necessary?! Why not allow a sunset alarm for after 9 am?? What if you have blackout curtains or work a night shift? This seems like a very easy fix that would give users more control over the product. Very dissatisfied.

Love the Echo Dot gen 2 and 3 we own so why not add a Show 5, was my thought. WRONG.

First my device doesn’t work, won’t play music and amazon said it’s my network or account. Yet my other echo devices on the same account and network are fine. They said they would get back to me in a day and never did. Support has no experience with the show 5.

Second the screen really adds nothings! Too small to watch videos or use for anything other than a click. I guess the 10 inch screen may add value but not the 5.

Save your money for the 10 inch or just get an Echo Dot.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great As A Bedside Smart Clock Radio
reviews.reviewText:
This Echo Show replaced my old and obsolete Logitech Squeezebox Radio that I bought in 2009 that I've been using bedside as my "clock radio." So far I'm very impressed with this device, especially for the low cost and functionality.

I like the customizable clock faces and the Show's ability to act as a digital picture frame at the same time. It uses my vacation photos stored on my local network as the background for the clock face, changing the photo about every ten seconds (this can be adjusted). I use the Show to wake me in the morning, either to one of the pre-configured recordings or any music I like. For instance, I can say, "Alexa, wake me at 5:50am to 90s music and bam, it's done! I can set as many alarms and timers as I like. I can also snooze the alarms simply by touching the top of the device. And I can easily cancel the alarm just by using touch, so I don't have to wake my wife by talking to Alexa.

Speaking of talking to her, it is so cool how Alexa understands me even when I quietly whisper to her, and she whisper's back!! That is a really neat and appreciated feature because again, I don't disturb my wife if I want to listen to something in the middle of the night. (I use a set of Anker Liberty true wireless ear buds for this.)

Using the Alexa app on my iPhone, I can easily "drop in" to the Show 5, video talking to my wife through the app. And I can watch music videos and even stream Amazon Prime content to the screen, using it as a mini-TV while in bed.

The other cool thing I like is that the show displays the lyrics (when available) to the music it is streaming. And I can have it tune to any radio station, including my Sirius/XM radio stations.

I've only set up some limited home automation so far, but I can use any of my Echo devices to open our garage doors and turn on certain outdoor lights (through their Kasa WiFi wall switches). The next thing I want to do is set up some kind of video doorbell that is compatible with this device.

Another nice feature is it has an on-screen keyboard option so you can type in a question or command for Alexa so you don't have to speak it. This is nice when you don't want to make any noise to awaken your bed partner.

The only suggestions for improvement I have so far are:
1) Add the ability to set alarms for specific days of the week, say every Monday, Thursday and Friday. (Even my old Logitech Squeezebox could do that.) Right now, you can set recurring alarms for weekends, every day, or weekdays, but not for specific days. That would be really handy for me because my work schedule requires me to wake at different times depending on the day of the week.
2) The viewing angle of the screen could be a bit better. It's not bad but if you start getting away from center when viewing the screen, it fades out pretty quickly. I'm ordering the ezbnb Show Anywhere metal stand to see if this helps with positioning the screen for optimal viewing.

In summary, this thing is a bargain for what it does. If you are looking for a great "smart" clock radio that is small, attractive and fits nicely on a nightstand, look no further. I think it is a bargain and I'm sure the firmware will continue to get updated with even more useful functionality and features. I have no regrets that I bought the Echo Show 5.

reviews.reviewTitle: Glitchy and won’t keep large type clock showing. UPDATED NOV. 6, 2019.
reviews.reviewText:
I liked this product in the beginning, in spite of not being able to dismiss the annoying “Try” suggestions at the bottom of the screen. It worked fine for a couple of weeks. Then, I’m assuming, there was an update that completely screwed up the home screen. I have always had it set to show the large clock with Amazon photos as the background and the weather in small type in the top left corner and the date in small type below the large type time. Now I can’t get the large clock to show for more than a few seconds. I didn’t change anything for that to happen. And I’ve tried everything since this started to try and fix the problem. I searched for an answer online only to find a large number of people having the same issue without any solution. In the advertising for this item the large clock is always showing, which is misleading since that isn’t an option for more than a few seconds before it reverts back to the tiny type in the upper left corner. It also has glitches sometimes where the numbers and letters sit on top of one another. (See photo) Until these issues are fixed I give the Echo Show 5 only 1 star.

UPDATE: The clock issue, which was my biggest problem, seems to be working right now. *knock wood* So I’m changing my rating to 4 stars. I did have to turn night mode off for this to be fixed. I have tried all of the suggestions from other reviewers, btw. So just because those instructions worked for you doesn’t mean it works for all. Hopefully these issues will all be worked out in updates. But for now I’m happy enough with the way it’s working to say it’s worth purchasing.

I waited for awhile to post this review in order to give the unit some time to perform. While I must say that I love it, there are a few things that irk me. I’m using it on the nightstand to replace my 1st Edition Show, as the larger unit cast way too much light next to the bed. The smaller form factor is much better in that area, particularly with its night mode, and the sound is great for my purpose.

My first unit kept losing its WiFi connection (about 2-3 times a day) in spite of the fact that it was about 15 feet from a wired Amplifi HD mesh point, and showed a very consistent 90% signal. The 1st edition Show never once lost its WiFi the entire time it was in place. To their credit, Amazon replaced the first with a new one, but it still, on occasion, loses its signal, albeit about 1-2 times a week, that I know of. There’s absolutely no reason for it to be doing that, other than something different from the 1st Edition with the internal radio hardware of the unit.

Also, I frequently am away from the house for a few days at a time, and I normally set my two 1st Edition Shows, as well as this Show 5 to turn the screen off during that time. The two larger Shows’ screens stay off for the duration, but the Show 5 screen will not stay off for more that about an hour or so before mysteriously turning back on. Sometimes it’s after only about 5 minutes. I have been testing it while home, and it consistently does that with no intervention from either me or any Alexa commands. Whether or not the camera is covered make no difference.

Other than those two things, it performs well, and I like the Show 5 a whole lot. I just wish the above two irks were somehow resolved.

Primarily I use my Echo Show to listen to various radio programs, although it is certainly not limited to just that. I haven't been able to find a radio that tunes in well to "my" stations, but there is NO problem with reception with the Echo Show. Many reviews mentioned how annoying the "ads" are on the screen, but they don't really bother me, as they are not actually what I think of as ads, and sometimes the display shows something newsworthy. So, to me, I can overlook the annoyance and focus on the positive. I haven't yet put photos on my display, but I hope to do that soon. It is nice to be able to ask Alexa questions and have her "guard" the house for me and play games (although without Amazon Prime, the games can be somewhat limited, just as the radio stations/music are). One thing that can be done on the Echo Show that can't be done on the Echo Dot is to see -- for instance, the multiple choice answers to certain questions are shown on the display, lyrics to shown are frequently displayed, and that's a good feature. For me, there's too much bass, even when I turn it down all the way, but maybe it's just me.

The one thing I do not like, on both of the Echo products I have, is the inaccurate weather. I've even contacted Amazon Echo/Alexa specialists about this, and I was told that even if you enable a skill such as Dark Sky or Big Sky, the Echo still "goes through" AccuWeather, which makes no sense to me. I've found AccuWeather to not be very ACCUrate. And it actually irks me to look at the screen and see the weather displayed as a temperature I KNOW is wrong. Typically, the temperatures here are approximately 10° higher than the display shows or what Alexa claims to be the current temperature. If someone could figure out how to fix that, I'd be quite happy with the Echo Show.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best overall Echo Show device for most people
reviews.reviewText:
update 9/19/19
Reading some of the other reviews on the 5, I don't think that a lot of people understand how Echos/Alexa work. They seem to think that the 5 is just a high tech stand a!one alarm clock, which it isnt.
One review said that the weather function was inadequate. If that's the case, just enable another one. There are too many for me to count.
another said that they returned theirs, and were going to wait for an upgraded version. Alexa is the same on a every device, and is being continual!y updated.
One review said the the 5 doesn't have YouTube. It does. It's kind of a kludge, but it works.
A lot of reviewers gripe about the ads. I don't even notice them. My wife likes the suggestions, and often responds to them. Amazon sells stuff. If you don't want to see the ads, just don't look at them.
A.m.s co.plain about the video capabilities. They are fine, although I can't get Hulu to run on it either (works fine on my gen1). TBH, I prefer to watch them on side screen tv. Or my Fire 10 tablet. But I had watched videos on it, and the interface is fine once you get used to it. But watching a whole movie on a 5 inch screen isn't really ideal.

I have decided that the sound is better than it is on the Spot. Maybe a bit better than my 3 gen Dot, but not by much. The Cot actually sounds pretty good. The regular Echos and my 1gen Show both sound better, but all of them are enjoyable to listen to.

I still think the Spot is a better alarm clock. The 5 is great for the kitchen, and the Show is in the !living room. That works out well for us. I am retired, but I would have loved to have a 5 on my desk in my office! When I want a spelling, or a definition, or a sum, or to put an event on a calendar, or a news update, or need to know it's one of my staff's birthday, all I would have to do is ask. IMHO, that would be wh ere the 5 would shine.

Update 8/14/19
The Show 5 is still working just fine. My Spot has returned to my bed stand, though, as the Show 5 takes up a bit too much room. Its not that the 5 is really all that big. Itv is about the same size as a 1990's era clock radio, but my bed stand is rather small. And I like the clock faces on my Spot better. Several YouTube reviews state that the Spot has been rendered redundant by the Show 5. I disagree. Each fits a unique niche. But I agree that the Spot should not cost so much. The Show 5 is a much better value at the current pricing.

Prior to buying this, I already owned a Echo Show and an Echo Spot, as well as a regular Echo and several Echo Dots, so I think it is fair to say that I am familiar with Echo devices and Alexa. My review of the Echo Show 5 will be comparing it to those other devices.
The Echo 5 has a fairly small screen, which is about the size of a large smart phone. The resolution is fairly low according to the specs, but that is not readily apparent when viewing in. I can watch the Echo Show screen across the room. With the Echo Spot I have to be quite close to watch it (yes, I watch videos on the Spot. The screen is tiny but it is fine if you have it on your night stand). The Show 5 is somewhere in between. You can see it easily across your desk. It is great on a kitchen counter. It is NOT a small room TV replacement, like the regular Show could be.
The sound on the Show 5 is about the same as the Echo Spot. Much better than the gen2 Dot, about on par with the gen3 Dot, but not as good as the regular Echo or the fill size Show.
Alexa on the Show 5 is exactly the same as on the regular Echo Show, which is not surprising, as Alexa is in the Cloud, not on your device. It seems to me that the Echo 5 has a somewhat slower response time, but that is REALLY hard to tell. As the devices are cloud based, the response time might well have more to do with the Wi-Fi connection at a certain location in your house than the device itself! Regardless, response times on all of the devices are acceptable on my DSL service. BTW, the Spot does not have the same functionality as the others. It has no browser, so no YouTube.
As far as value goes, the Show 5 is by far the best value. It does everything the larger Show can do, for half the money. If you bought it for $50 on Prime day, as I did, its a steal.
So is it for you? That depends. If you want a large screen and great sound for your living room or den, then get the full size Show.
If you want a bed stand clock, the Spot takes up less room, and I think that its perfect for that role. I REALLY like my Spot! If the Spot and the Show 5 were the same price, I would recommend the Spot. But at a significantly higher price? I am afraid that, without a sizable cut in price, the days of the Spot are numbered!
But if you want just one Echo show device, or if you are just entering the Echo community, the Echo Show 5 is by far the best choice.

I wanted to like this echo but I was disappointed. The idea that I can't keep a clock I choose on the screen at all times without intermittently being bombarded with alexa suggestions is ridiculous. And yes, I turned off continuous rotation. Not only that, there are several bugs, including turning off the alarm while in snooze mode.
Try harder before releasing a product Amazon.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice clock, but has a few glitches.
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this to replace my bedroom dot and bedside clock with a single device., and for that, this definitely does the trick. The interaction is pretty much the same as a standard dot. All the usual commands still work fine. The big difference is of course the visual feedback. For example, when I say "turn on bedroom lights," it does that, but it also gives me a visual of the dimmer setting. So if they are on, but turned down to zero, I can easily see that, and then manually turn them up using the switch, or on the visual on the show 5, or using my voice. So for some things like that, the expanded functionality is great. So I really like the visual helps and the added quick access for my smart home features.

One thing I don't like is how bright it is at night. Even using night mode, this thing still makes my room very bright. Plus, depending on which clock background you use, the letters in Night Mode might be red, which is OK for night vision. OR they might be blue/white, which is very bad for night vision. There is the option to say "turn off display", and that works fine, UNTIL you have to interact with the device - OR - if you cough, then the device wakes up and starts listening, and the screen turns on again. Then you have to say - loud enough for it to hear you - "turn off display."

Also, even if you use the sunrise feature, and you have the display off - it doesn't come on when the alarm goes off, until you physically touch the display or you use the wake word. So the intelligence behind turning the display on and off could definitely use some work. Even with the do not disturb on during night hours, it will still wake up occasionally and I have to tell it to turn back off. Then in the mornings, with an alarm, it doesn't come on. So definitely some glitches to work out.

For me, it would be nice, if you could set a time for the display to be off and stay off. Maybe even in a routine. Then if you wake up, and need to check the clock with a voice command or a touch, it would be great if the clock would come on for a few seconds and then the display would then go back off again so it wouldn't disrupt my sleep too much. That would be nice. Also, it would be nice if you could set the delay time before it switches back to night mode or the display turns off - like on a cell phone; a simple screen timeout. That would be super nice.

So Pros: Sound seems a little better, more full, than a standard Gen 3 dot. And the visuals are great. You can even watch a movie - but not sure who would want to on such a small screen.

And Cons: Way too bright at night, even in night mode. Not enough adjustments for the screen at night. Wakes up too often with the display coming back on and staying on. And no way to automatically turn off the display during set times. The "do not disturb" function doesn't really cover enough.

reviews.reviewTitle: FORCED “Things to try...” CANNOT TURN OFF! FIX THIS PRODUCT AMAZON.
reviews.reviewText:
The fact that Amazon forces you to view “things to try” and there is not a non-workaround way to turn them off is maddening. Basically “Try, BLAH BLAH BLAH...” will randomly pop up on your Echo Show 5. There are ways to cut them down, but NOT to eliminate them. I wanted a clock that would do a couple of more cool things like lightning control and weather. Now I have a ROTATING AMAZON BILLBOARD. I don’t want to try ANY of your suggestions Alexa... I just want my clock to be a CLOCK. I don’t need ANYTHING else displayed, unless I program it or ask for it. Amazon could turn this off easily, but so far they have refused. They are hoping this blows over and we just “live with it”. Be vocal and call in to Amazon so they fix this. Otherwise, they will just force you to accept popups on your alarm clock. This item was RUSH released to be available for Prime Day. It was simply not ready for Prime Time. Wait to buy until these stupid prompts are removed.

Will update if the prompts are removed and give it 4. It can’t have 5 because while you can connect any Bluetooth speaker to your Echo, you can only make an “Amazon recognized” Bluetooth speaker your “preferred speaker”. This means only preferred speakers can be designated in your speaker groups. So when I play music “everywhere” it auto disconnects from my $1k+ Soundbar in favor of the Echo Show 5 speaker. While using speaker groups, there is no way I know of to make it manually connect because it prefers the Echo device. Amazon is forcing you to buy their authorized devices to make this feature work.

Amazon is a great company so it is kind of sad that they are doing these kind of monopoly moves. I thought they would fix these issues much more quickly, but it has been over 3 months. I still have hope though. Come on and make this product into what we want it to be.

Amazon has changed the clock so that the time is displayed in small numbers in the upper left hand corner. Every so often the large numeral display appears in center of device. Then it goes back to the small corner display. On the bottom of the screen there are suggestions that appear on ways to use Alexa. Please reprogram so that large clock display remains on screen.

reviews.reviewTitle: I like it on the nightstand better than the echo spot
reviews.reviewText: I love my new echo show 5. It has a bigger footprint than the spot did on my nightstand. But, it’s much easier to see the numbers. I like that it dims itself while I’m asleep, too. And, I believe it’s the only echo with a screen that has a built-in shutter to turn off the camera. I’m not sure I like that it’s mostly a fabric covering which is more susceptible to holding dust than is plastic. All-in-all, I’m very pleased with this new addition to my echo family (I have one of each type, including the roav alexa device for the car). One fun fact is that I used the drop in feature during my evacuation from hurricane Florence to see if I still had power...hopefully there’s no next time, but if there is, i’ll have a couple of my devices aimed at the windows so I can see more of what’s going on.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great for most but has limitations for video calling another person outside of your account
reviews.reviewText: So, all in all I think echo is an awesome device and with these echo show & echo show 5 by adding well it open many possibilities. I've been an Amazon buyer and a Prime member for many many years and love my echo's (I have a total of 9 throughout my home) One in each kids room which makes it easy to let them know it's time to dinner as you can call each individual device. I had a great idea that since my family lives all over the USA we could use echo shows to video call each other. it does work but be aware, if you have more than one device, each device will ring if someone outside of your home calls. so at night when my sister wants to discuss a health issue with our mother who lives elsewhere. she tries to video call to show me her medicines and all 9 devices ring which wake my kids. I tried many things and according to Amazon there's no way to call one particular device for one home to another even though you can call one particular device from within your home. great devices otherwise but not if your looking for a way to talk to loved ones far away. I think this should be an update as if it can be done within the home, why not individually or maybe have a setting for each echo that says "don't ring for out side calls".

I LOVE Echo Show 5. My only problem was deciding where to put it! I have an Echo Show, and the dot, and all the others in every room of my home! The 5 is the perfect size ... but this means that one of my devices will have to retire. Thank you Amazon for making my life easier in every corner of my home! XO
would have to repeat myself over and over for it to understand what I was trying to say. Would eventually just get my phone out and look up or buy whatever i was asking it so no point in having it.

Sounds good, looks good, works fairly well... Just one BIG problem as it constantly proclaims "Try saying" messages along the bottom of the screen over and over and over...

Edit: unless you speak English with a Hindi accent, you will have little success commanding this device. When speaking directly at the device from two feet away, an Echo Dot in an adjoining room behind me is more likely to reply. This device has cost me thousands in repairs and lost productivity as a result of its tendency to modify commands and control devices inappropriately. The "support team" is limited to a few standard actions and unable to diagnose or repair issues, and the "development team" is more interested in creating new "fart jokes" than in addressing customer concerns such as servers that crash while performing routines, poor speech recognition, and unauthorized acquisition of "skills" or third-party programming. In addition, the data speeds through the Amazon servers are so restricted that features such as the viewing of security cameras are spotty at best and often fail completely.

If all you want is a toy and have no concerns about privacy or identity theft, then this may be the gadget for you. If you want a tool to assist you, this device is not yet ready to provide reliable service and seems to be making little progress toward improvement.
I love the new Show. The sound and video quality is far superior to my old Spot.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great smaller version of Echo Show!
reviews.reviewText: After looking at Echo show devices for awhile I finally decided on this one to best fit my needs best. Size is great for bedroom and living room use on night stand and end table. Big enough to see clearly and not to big to look out of place. I am still discovering all I can do on it but my main objective was security camera monitoring and it works great with my Netvue cams recently purchased through Amazon. It alerts me to motion and picture quality is GREAT! The added advantage is I have access to so much more information and it looks great! If you are thinking about it I would highly recommend Echo Show 5. Not to big, not to small, just right!

reviews.reviewTitle: “Try, Alexa” screen or card as they call it Are TERRIBLE”
reviews.reviewText: I’m disappointed in the screen quality. Looking straight ahead direct, it looks fine, If you’re a little to the left or right you can’t see anything. Regardless, my giant complaint with all Alexa products are the advertisements. You can’t tell me Amazon hasn’t read all of these complaints. The “Try, Alexa” screen or card as they call it is beyond annoying. I agree with many of these other users… If Amazon doesn’t fix this with a firmware update I may switch to the Google products.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just not what it should be
reviews.reviewText:
When I bought it I was promised certain features like Hulu and Netflix which just aren't there. And my understanding is that it will not be added although the three different people I spoke to about it all gave me different answers. Very frustrating. It would work just fine in the Firefox browser except there is no desktop mode in the browser so I can't access many websites same problem with the Amazon browser no desktop view. It also has terrible microphones most of the time it doesn't hear me. And it doesn't get my location correctly no matter what I set it to.
Overall huge disappointment.
And the worst support, the staff is unknowledgeable in support.

I bought this to show my front door camera (Ring) whenever motion was detected. It announced that there was motion but I had to say “Alexa show the front door”. But it only shows for 10 minutes and I have to re-initialize it. NOT HAPPY! If this gets improved upon then I’ll order the better product.

**Updated Again - “Things to try” home screen is back, and as useless as ever. Fix this, amazon!

*Updated Review: It looks like amazon has fixed the “Things to try” screen from rotating in and staying up. Now, whatever clock face you choose, will stay up on the screen, right where it needs to be. Hoping this will stay this way, permanently, in the future. If it does, this is a very nice device. The screen size is perfect for a bedside smart clock device. Any smaller and it would be difficult to see. Larger may be overkill for bedside use. I really like the Echo Show 5 and find it very useful.

*Original review: I’ll change my review when amazon fixes the “Things to try” screen that permanently shows on the echo show 5. You choose a clock face, for what exactly? To have the device stick it in the upper left corner, too small to see? How about let’s “Try Alexa, fix this dang device so people can actually use it.” There’s already a dedicated Things to try section in the settings we can scroll through, if we wanted to further explore this. Come on!

Amazon amazes me with the products they put out. Every time they do I want to buy it!

If I could get 3 more of these on sale I would, one for all the kids. I like how compact it is and the fact you can do video on it. I can drop in and say hi to my family and see what they are doing.

Some of my favorite features are:
- Alarm clock
- Making lists, like for groceries which as really come in handy
- Calendar reminders
- Timer
- Music
- Able to play calming sounds when we go to sleep and tell it to turn off after X minutes
- We don't really watch shows on it but you can
- Sometimes we ask it to play funny videos or tell a joke
- Horoscope
- News
- Controls smart switches - able to turn lights on and off without touching them, close the garage, lock the front door, etc...

As much as I like the dot, I really like being able to visually see my family when I am out of town. Not to mention some of my other outside family members have it so we can video them as well without needing to use a phone.

It is no Bose sound system but works well enough and gets pretty loud. Nice to be able to tell Alexa play a song or station or have a surround sound system through the house by creating a speaker group.

Alexa, you will forever be a part of this family!

The echo show 5 is pretty great all around. The sound is very clear and loud and distorts very little at max volume. The screen is the best and the worst thing about it because it is great to see tidbits of information and can give you a very convenient look at your cameras. But watching videos on the small screen is a bit of a nuisance for wikihow and prime video but that being said I enjoyed throwing a movie to have it in the background while I did stuff around the house. The privacy shutter is a great addition and the variety of clock faces is very nice and they are full screen clocks which was a big gripe for the full sized show for many. In my opinion it's well worth it to update any echo dots you have for one of these instead and it's definitely more appealing than the echo spot (although I still love my echo spot) and it's much cheaper than the spot. However if your intention is to use this as a kitchen assistant for cooking because of the screen I would just go for the full sized show. This one is best utilized in a bedroom or office.

reviews.reviewTitle: Really needs to lose the "Things To Try" crap.
reviews.reviewText:
So I went into this purchase fully aware of the annoyance reported by others of the "Things To Try" thing. I think that this device would be a top-notch A+ product if we were allowed to turn that garbage off. I did turn off the scrolling "feature", so no it doesn't constantly scroll across my screen, but when I listen to my Sirius/XM Radio the "Things To Try" is ALWAYS on the bottom on the screen and is so annoying. Just let us turn off "Things To Try". Please. This really is a nice little device, I like everything about it, except that stupid "Things To Try".

Update: Have used product for 3 weeks now... and am growing every more irritated at the constant scrolling of "Things To Try" garbage. I have tried all the suggestions of how to make this stop, like turning of scrolling, etc.... but the stupid Things To Try keep coming across the screen, I can't turn it off and it's annoying AF to try to look at my clock for the time and instead the screen is telling me how to ask Alexa for a peach cobbler recipe. IF I WANTED A PEACH COBBLER RECIPE I'D EFFING ASK FOR ONE YOU TWATWAFFLE!!!! Please let us turn this stupid "feature" off!!!!

I picked up the Echo Show 5 on Prime Day and so far I'm really loving it! I got it mostly to easily see my Ring camera from my home office desk but there are some other features on it that I'm enjoying - hilariously Relax My Cat really does work! As I'm learning to use Alexa I'm liking it more and more. It's nice to be able to turn on my lights with my voice! I can see this quickly becoming a great tool to use for so many things.

However, I am going to echo everyone's gripe I've read. The slideshow as the home page has GOT TO GO. It's distracting, it's annoying and I wish there was a way to stop it. I'm hopeful Amazon will listen to the complaints and do something to change this. I haven't dug into it but I'm curious if there's a way to force night mode on it?

Overall its a solid device save for one quibble with it.

ETA: I mostly got it to stop. Go to settings, home & clock, home content and turn EVERYTHING off. The clock will rotate once to a "try alexa" screen but then stay static on the clock of your choice. Took a bit of back and forth to get it to stick but it's SO MUCH BETTER than the constant slideshow.

I have enjoyed my Show 5. I have it on my desk in my office. I enjoy the rolling news stories and the weather updates. I mainly use it to listen to music, podcasts, audio books. I like that some of the "skills" allow to display the lyrics. The speaker is great and is the primary reason I purchased this unit.

Cons:
1. I do not like the suggestions of what to ask Alexa to do. You can not turn them off. That should be an option for the user. For this I take away one star.

2. There are a limited amount of skills that utilize the screen. YouTube should have it's on skill. I can use the browser to go to YouTube but if I need to stop for any reason I have to go all the back in. For this another star deducted.

I wish the user had the ability to add shortcuts, or app icons particular skills on the home screen (like YouTube, a web link, photo album, or playlist)

I'm sure the skills and ability will grow with time. But right now it's not that much more useful than the regular Echo.

I was recently gifted an Echo, and in becoming familiar with all that can be done with Alexa and the other smart accessories, I was interested in the possibility of live video communication with family members that live in other cities and states. I purchased an Echo Show 5 to gain further experience with the equipment. Subsequently, Amazon had a flash sale on Echo Show 5's at half price and based on my favorable impressions with the first one, I ordered a second one. I am using one in my office and one in the kitchen. They were very easy and quick to set up. The quality of the picture and operation have been excellent. I set up the home screen to show my photos which is a nice touch. Voice operation has also been perfect. My only issue has been the sensitivity of the touch screen. On a few occasions, it has not been responsive until two to three tries, and on one or two times, I have had to leave the screen and then return to the screen to complete the operation. I have not yet completed a video call, but will when family members obtain compatible equipment.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome addition to the Echo product line
reviews.reviewText:
I've used the original Echo for several years. It's getting a little beat up, but still works well and has very good sound.
I wanted a Video Echo to support other video devices, such as the Ring Video Doorbell. When the price dropped for Amazon Prime Day, I jumped on this deal. So I will retire the original Echo to another lesser used room.
The Echo Show 5 is my 6th Echo device, if we count the FireTV Cube. So, I am familiar with the setup. But I was not prepared for how easy this one is to set up. Plug in, answer a few questions and good to go! I've watched a movie (Prime), listened to music, did a Drop In, all the great stuff! I do recommend using the Smart Phone app to easily rename the Show something shorter and easy to remember.
Now, I may need to start upgrading from the Dots to more Shows for other rooms. And, of course for gifts, so I can drop in with the family.
I'm definitely happy with this purchase and recommend it for others.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Product with ONE Big Flaw!
reviews.reviewText: I really do like my new Echo Show 5. The functionality of the device is what I expected. The ease of use is like many other Amazon products. My biggest complaint, if you can call it that, is the "Try Alexa..." rotation when the Show 5 is in Clock mode. When it detects motion, the Show 5 puts the time, date, and weather up in the upper left-hand corner, blanks out the screen, and shows a suggestion of what to try to get Alexa to do. This feature is annoying and it almost makes this smart device really dumb. If this were able to be turned off, I'd give it five stars hands down. I followed all the suggested fixes for this issue and none of them seem to work at all. This needs to be fixed and I would say it is one of the best products on the market.

I just wanted to use this as an Alarm Clock, but note that there is no way to disable the annoying "Try this..." suggestion messages (which cause the clock display to be minimized). I disabled all of the annoying "Home Content" but later asked a food question and suddenly "Popular Recipes" got magically re-enabled, causing random recipes to appear whenever I turn the light on (see attached photo).
