I turned it back off, but be careful what you ask for... Alexa's voice is also too bassy in the bathroom (there is an equalizer but it only affects Amazon Music).

Update 10/2019: The latest automatic firmware update seems to have broken the font color on the "Watercolor" display background. The time display is now intermittently red instead of white (see photo). In addition, on some days the full-size clock display doesn't appear at all and instead I just get a minimized clock display and continuous back-to-back "Try this" messages on the screen the ENTIRE day. Dropping my rating to 1 star until these firmware issues are resolved.

Easy and Quick Review: screen is not bad, sound quality is ok, Video function works well, HATE< HATE< HATE the constant ads!
Come on Amazon, I buy a lot of stuff from you, let me opt out or your going to piss of a core customer.

This device is amazing. First of all I can’t imagine our kitchen life without this device. On this device Alexa controls our whole downstairs area. We have plugs for many outlets downstairs and we can easily turn them on and off with Alexa. She sets timers plays music. I mean this AI is great. Then my dog got it.

We have gone a few days without Alexa and my mom life has suffered some lol!!! The world without AI!!! We put the echo in rice as the dog put a lot of slobber inside. The cord is trash. Thank you to the dog for that. However, our pup did not fully destroy the device itself. I am not sure why or how but he didn’t. After a few days of praying and drying in rice she is working! I can’t believe it but she . (we call the device she. We refer to her as basically a household member.)

Thank you amazon for making a great product. Not sure if you do tests on damage caused by animals but this device stood up to our pup!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great improvement over the spot offering all the benefits of the Echo show on a compact device.
reviews.reviewText: I have to admit I've become obsessed with every Alexa device created and have or have owned every Alexa enabled device created. I'm impressed with the Echo show 5 and it currently is being used as a replacement for my Echo spot. It can do everything it's larger echo show devices can do on a smaller more compact screen. It doesn't take up much real estate on my night stand and looks stylish. What I like about this device over the spot is the sound quality is much better. I can take advantage of a full screen instead of a round one. At night the device goes in to a low light mode with just red numbers similar to a traditional alarm clock. I no longer have to tell my device to turn the screen off. I like the sunrise alarm feature where the show 5 gradually emits a warm orangish glow imitating natural sun light as the alarm clock gradually wakes me up, instead of waking up in a startle to a loud blaring sound. I've never been a fan of video chatting, but the fact that there is a shutter that blocks the camera is a nice feature for rhose worried about awkward drop ins in the bedroom. Mine stays on at all times.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it even though it has one design flaw - no battery backup.
reviews.reviewText: Love the Show 5. Use mine as a nightstand alarm clock, ring doorbell/cam display center, and for music. The one design limitation I do find is there is no battery backup, so it’s use as an alarm clock is only as dependable as your power source. I guess you could plug it into a UPS, but would it have been so hard to build in a battery backup that would at least keep the alarm clock feature active during a power or internet outage?

reviews.reviewTitle: A great addition to my Echo fleet
reviews.reviewText: I have an Echo household, with one in every room. The show makes a nice edition. I wanted mainly to be able to see who is at the door via my Ring doorbell from my usual living room seat some distance from the door. It performs that function well, in addition to the normal Echo functions. I keep noticing nice little features, such as when I give a command to turn on a light the control for that light shows up on the screen with a brightness adjustment slider. When I ask Alexa where my stuff is, I get the usual audio report plus a picture of what's coming. There are videos you can watch, etc. It is just a nice little gadget.

reviews.reviewTitle: Time to weigh in on this device
reviews.reviewText:
Now that I have owned the Echo Show 5 for a while, I thought it might be a good time to weigh in on the device, especially since it now sits on a shelf in my closet. I was kind of enthusiastic about getting it, and saw it as a replacement for my Echo Spot, which sits on my night table. With a larger, more conventional screen and a promised uptick in speaker power, I felt that it would be a better fit, though I was not at all dissatisfied with the Spot, which has proven to be the most useful of all my Echo devices (which include Fire tablets, a Dot, a Fire TV Cube, and a 2nd Generation Echo Plus).

I suppose that ones appreciation for the Echo Show 5 will be affected by intended use. While I was satisfied with the devices visual performance, ultimately the device audio turned out to be the deal breaker. The thing sounds awful, on a par with my 1st generation Echo Dot. I spent days tooling around with the EQ settings trying to raise it to satisfactory levels, but was unsuccessful. I actually sent the device back for a replacement, thinking that I received a defective device, only to have the second one arrive sounding exactly the same.

Now, keep in mind that I didn't use the device much for music, and was not expecting high fidelity symphonic reproduction. Mainly, audio is for my communications with Alexa and the occasional podcast before falling asleep. I think it highly unlikely that I receive two devices with the exact same defect, and have concluded that audio is simply problematic on this device.

I eventually returned my Echo Spot to the night table, because its sound reproduction is 10 times fuller and more pleasant than the Show 5. Perhaps I was expecting too much, as the Show 5 is priced significantly lower than the Spot. Keep in mind, however, that in the Echo lineup, the Spot, which I am now using, is not a high end audio device. But it is a lot better than the Echo Show 5, which I now regret purchasing, despite the larger screen.

As soon as I saw a photo of this new product, I knew that it would be a perfect device for my bedroom. I also have the Echo Show 2nd generation, but that larger device has migrated to my home office. The Echo Show 5 was easier to set up and connected more quickly to my wi-fi network than earlier models. It turns off my Hue lights, dims to a night mode, wakes me with a custom alarm and tells me my appointments for the day. I bought this Show at a local electronics store rather than on Amazon because I had a store credit. It is the perfect size if you want a device that doesn't call attention to itself and just fits in with any décor.

I love this product. I got rid of my old alarm clock and had been using my echo to wake me up but hated not being able to actually see the time (you know when you wake up in the middle of the night and want to know how much sleep you can get if you fall asleep right NOW). I did not want to spend a lot of money on a dot or a show. When this came up in my recommendations I was interested. When i was $40 off on prime day I decided to give it a try. I love it.
The sound quality is good, the size is perfect and now I only have one item on my nightstand.
The screen adjusts to the light in the room so it is not GLOWING at 2am and it performs all of the functions that my echos and dots around the house do. It was a nice addition!

We needed an alarm clock. We have EchoDot we use in the kitchen for those bad reception days for over the air FM radio.
Set the EchoShow5 up and set the alarm. Tried to tell it to wakeup, alarm with a radio station. DUH.
Just tried asking it to play "Alexa play 90.5FM" It played 90.5FM
Back to alarm setup. "Alexa alarm at 7am by playing WFIT-FM".
No way.
Jumped on my cell phone, called up the app.
Setup my routines and Show 5 answers for everyone. My Echodot evening schedule now plays in the bedroom.
The EchoDot is superceded by SHOW 5. I can walk into the kitchen and say "Alexa play WQCS" and she responds by playing in the bedroom. Now if I say "Alexa, make EchoDot play WQCS" it plays where I want.

Something amissin the peer-peer logic in these devices.

I understand that this is a compact version, but I didn't expect it to be as small as it is. I was hoping for something that was maybe half the size of the echo show 2nd generation . I'm probably going to return and replace with another echo 2nd show generation.
-- Update--
Decided to return the echo show. Instead of going with 1 2nd generation echo, I ordered 3 echo dots for different rooms in my home since they are half price. To the customer service technician who emailed me because he thought I may have had technical problems with the device, my only issue was that the equipment was like a handheld device and about the size of my Note 9 my cell phone.

I find this Echo 5 to be a bit better than the 10" version. The sound quality is very good, I was surprised
that such a small speaker could deliver such clear and crisp audio. The picture quality is good as well.
My only beef is that it will default to the time when you are listening to flash briefing instead of staying
with what is playing. I know of no way to stop it from doing so.

reviews.reviewTitle: Echo show, not a must-buy but a great addition
reviews.reviewText:
Got mine on Prime day during a huge sale.
The echo show is an interesting product for several reasons:

1. You can watch videos on it. You can either ask Alexa to open Silk browser and browse the internet and watch YouTube or just use the intergrated app to watch Amazon videos. To be honest, I almost never find myself doing this at all. Instead, the screen is nice for looking up recipes or Lyrics. That being said, the screen is more than capable than you need.

2. Camera. The camera can be physically closed so it is definitely safer than some other products. But keep in mind that the camera is only “functional”, not amazing. This is understandable and doesn’t bother me at all, I tried video chat on this thing and it works just fine.

3. Sound quality. As a 1st gen echo dot owner, I must say the new echo devices have some great sound quality improvement. Volume can also be loud for you to hear the m suicide from any corner of the room.

Overall, I say an echo dot/ echo can pretty much do anything that the echo show can do and you won’t be missing a whole lot. However, echo show can be a great addition if you also happen to need an echo device anyway.

I purchased the Echo Show 5 on Prime Day. Setup was simple and fast. I can watch my favorite Prime Movies and Shows while I'm working in the kitchen, down in the basement, just about anywhere in my home that there's a wifii signal. I take the Echo Show 5 outside to enjoy music, watch movies, ask Alexa questions (I was sitting outside with my 88 year old father and he was trying to remember the name of an actress in a movie, so I asked Alexa. she had the answer in seconds - very impressive). The picture quality on this small but powerful Echo Show 5 is crisp and clear. Sound quality is unbelievable. The Echo Show 5 picks up the wifi signal seamlessly from room to room even outdoors. It's a television, a clock radio, a source of endless information - does just about anything from recipes to how to videos. I've even taken it on vacation with me. Possibilities are endless. I highly recommend the Echo Show 5.

Video doesn’t prove video quality because omg! It’s amazing I wish it was bigger 🤣🤣🤣 but love it!
how did I survive without ALL of this!!! Just bought blink cameras as well 🙌🏼🙌🏼🙌🏼 Smart house here I come

reviews.reviewTitle: Not a replacement for the echo or echo dot.
reviews.reviewText:
The unit is not up to Amazon quality. I don’t know what they were thinking. I have to practically yell to get this unit to listen to me. My dot and echo units could heat me if I was just bit above a whisper (in the same room / position).
The touch screen is crap. In today world of capacitive touch, this is as poorly responding as a resistive screen. It misses more touches than it recognizes. It is very very slow to react.
The home automation controls that work on all my echo units usually fail to work at all on this show.
Even for the sale price I don’t feel it was worth the cost. At least I have a camera privacy shield built-in.
I might be able to accept some of o
The quality issue is this would pair to other speakers but as it is I cannot get this to reliably stay paired to a speaker group, and that speaker group cannot be used for music playback in custom routines.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice to have visual as well as voice, but Drop In with Android on the Show does not work correctly.
reviews.reviewText: I bought this so that we could use "drop in" to communicate with my 85 year old father with our Android phones. It worked great for the first few calls and then we could no longer hear him. We contacted tech support and they told us to reset the unit, which cleared up the problem for another few calls and then the audio dropped again. This problem is a common issue on the forums and no one seems to have a permanent solution. I expect it is related only to Android. The other features are nice and it ups the home automation a notch to have visuals also. We replaced the Show with an Echo Dot and "drop in" has worked fine with Android since then. It seems to struggle with voice recognition/clarity over the other Echo devices that I have, but overall, if you are not interested in drop in via Android phone it should be fine.

I LOVE this thing! I have always wondered why there isn't really a wifi alarm clock on the market ( do an Amazon search, you will see). But it just makes so much sense! The time will always be accurate, because it is connected to your wifi, just like the time display on your phone or other devices. Even if the power goes out, it goes right back to accurate time, and no more setting your clocks twice a year for daylight savings time. I am so happy, and it is much more than an alarm clock. I love all the Alexa commands it can do, and I am a big fan of Pandora for my music, and that is just another bonus that I can listen to Pandora on this device.

I bought just one to see how it is, but plan on buying more to replace all my obsolete, antiquated clocks throughout my house. Hoping there will be some kind of deal on Prime day!

This is a replacement for an Echo Spot used in a bedroom. I was very skeptical as to whether this unit would fit as well in a bedroom environment as the Spot did. I am proud to report not only does it fit well the larger screen is welcome. I had concerns it would be to bright at night however the night mode does an excellent job of controlling the brightness during sleep hours. I use this unit with a Bose mini Soundlink 2 it makes an excellent sound system for the bedroom. I would like to see a few more clock face choices you can customize it to some degree more background choices would be nice. I have 6 different Amazon Echos and use them extensively for home control,calendar, routines and whole house music. I appreciate the fact they are constantly updating the software and introducing new hardware.

Echo just keeps getting better. I’ve been a fan since the very first model and I’ve owned several. This is a much better size for the Show and I’ve been very pleased. It fit right into my Echo family.

reviews.reviewTitle: Visuals make a big difference, but the sound is bad
reviews.reviewText:
Going from an echo 2nd generation on my night stand to this, having the visuals and touch screen options are amazing.
From seeing sports scores with optional highlights, the sunrise alarm gently waking me, to the video calling, I am mostly satisfied with my purchase.

With it being small, the sound quality is right there with the echo dot. I miss the bass of my full size echo, but now it's a part of my whole-home speaker set up so I at least have that quality when walking into my living room where it now resides.

Another negative is that the microphones don't pick up my voice as well as the full size echo. But that's only a factor if I'm across the room with the TV loud or music is playing loudly through it.

I considered the echo show due to the speaker quality, but in the end, I can simply use my sound bar for full quality.

Mostly recommended.

reviews.reviewerName: The Shopper Formerly Known as R. Seward
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using the Amazon Echo/Alex since the beginning. I was invited to purchase the original Echo before it's full release (which I did), and have been using it since. I've owned the original Echo, the 1st gen Echo Dot, Echo Tap, 3rd Gen Echo dot, 2nd Gen Echo Show, and now the Echo Show 5.

I love that the Echo Show 5 has a physical camera shutter. IMO every device like this should include one (just for peace of mind).
Second, I really like the "alarm clock" form factor of it. It looks familiar on the night stand, yet it's packed with modern technology.
That said, of all my echo devices, this one has trouble hearing me the most. I often have to raise my voice for it to respond. This is especially frustrating when I'm trying to turn off an early morning alarm without disturbing my wife.

I bought this because Alexa works pretty well with Audible, but it would be better if I could see my titles on an Alexa device. The Show 5 does this. I have 200+ titles so it's not great for the older stuff, but it works. The screen is really good. That surprised me. The sound is interesting, not super natural, but balanced enough for voice and light music. It's annoying that I can't get videos or music playlists without using the Alexa app on a smartphone. I hope they refine the Show to be more capable. The night screen is pretty good, very dark, but not completely dark, and I can read the time. At night, dark room, I think they only show the time, not the messages. The reminder thing is well thought out and you can slide them away with the screen. I've had a Dot for 2 years and the Show is a lot better. The Dot was pretty good for timers and general info.

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazon finally got t right (one little glitch).
reviews.reviewText:
I tried the first gen Echo Show, too expensive and didn't find it useful. Then the Spot. The navigation commands didn't work, background pics were nearly invisible.

When the Show 5 went on sale, I bought it. It will display the time and temperature consistently (the others cycled through a bunch of advertising), it makes background photos visible, it has a 3.5mm output jack for hooking to speakers (which is what I did), and the movie navigation commands I've tried, work. It will also do video calling, although I haven't tried that, and you can manually switch the camera off.

It is the world's best, most powerful beside alarm clock, at an unbeatable price. Only one glitch so far, the recurring alarm that we set and that was displayed on the screen, didn't go off in the morning! How could they fail that part, that had worked so well on all other devices??? We'll try again in the morning.

reviews.reviewTitle: Come on Jeff, keep trying to perfect your Show models
reviews.reviewText: I bought the original Echo Show and now the Echo Show 5. I returned the first one after it could not connect successfully with my JBL Flip 4 speakers. Amazon sent me a replacement. Same problem. Spent literally hours on the phone with several levels of CSRs. I even tried the "Call Jeff directly" option. So when the 5 came out, I ordered it. After another hour with Amazon CSR trying to get all my smart plugs to work with it. I gave up. Maybe Gen 2 or 3 will make the Show as flexible as my 4 Echo Dots. Great concept...bad execution.

Really like the Echo show 5 as a clock radio for the bedroom.

Things I like:
Routines - These give you great flexibility for doing a series of actions and its super easy to set them up.
Auto dimming - The screen goes into night mode when its dark but you can still see the time clearly
Size - perfect for a bedroom
Setup - Super easy
Familiar - As you would expect it works just the same as the other echo devices we have
Price - Well priced

Don't likes:
Advertising - This was a bit annoying but it can be turned off
Dust - to be picky, it does seem to attract the dust a bit, but so does everything.
Portability - I would be nice if it had a battery backup in case the power goes out or to make it portable.

Over we are really pleased with the Echo show 5 and would defiantly recommend it.

Another great Alexa product. I have 2 echo dots, 1 echo, and an echo show all 2nd generation, I also have an echo spot, and an echo auto and an echo tap. Love them all. Got the Show 5 so I could add a screen in my home office and move the full size echo into the master bedroom, and the dot from the bedroom to master bath. Love the show 5. Small enough to fit on my desk in front and under my monitors without blocking my screens. The sound quality is great, the screen is clear, bright and easy to read. Alexa works great and I love being able to play my Amazon music all over the house. A great addition to the Echo family and my family as well.
As for the people who say "Alexa and Amazon are spying on you, listening to every thing we say" all I can say is "who cares??" My wife and I have been married for 25 years, if they want to listen to her yelling at me to take out the trash, mow the grass and to stop leaving my socks in the den and me arguing about us not having sex often enough more power to them. I am sure like me, they have already heard it enough and have moved on to listening to other people!

Oh, I didn't give it any stars for portability because even though it is small enough to take with you, I have an Amazon Tap and an echo auto which I use for my portable Alexa needs.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not Happy with Amazon - Happy with Echo 5
reviews.reviewText:
Interesting headline right? The reason is very simple. I own every Amazon product there is to own and pre-ordered the Echo 5 that was delivered at the end of June. I paid $89 and we get to Prime Day and now it is $40 less. Thanks Amazon for slapping a loyal customer. In the future I will not buy your products until they go down in price. I feel ripped off and taken advantage of. When I called Amazon they told me too bad.

As for the Echo 5, it is outstanding and works well. I use bluetooth speakers with it and it is smooth with no dropoffs. The best thing about it is you can block the camera so I use it in the bedroom. My only small beef is I call it Echo instead of Alexa (my Fire TV Cube is Alexa) and it does not always pick me up the first time.

If you want to buy an Echo 5, wait for the price to drop again (and buy the holder, it really helps.)

reviews.reviewTitle: Basically a glorified clock. An ok product which needs improvement
reviews.reviewText:
Basically it’s an ok product.

When I use the echo show 5 Alexa sometimes has a hard time understanding my commands. Additionally unless you give very specific commands as listed by amazon she won’t understand variations of phrases, like Siri or bixby might. It would seem in order to get her to do what I want I have to memorize commands even if I’m one word off form what the command is is really ridiculous.

Also the App Store or in this case Alexa skills is limited and needs great improvement. Many skills don’t work or aren’t really good to begin with. For the skills that developers are asking money for is crazy. One skill wanted you to pay by the HOUR to use. Unbelievable. When you want to use an app Alexa will talk a lot. I feel like saying I just want to use the skill not have you ask me a lot of questions.

The device is also limited to apps it can link to so no YouTube and other apps you may be use to utilizing on other smart devices. At the very least it pairs to Pandora, Gmail, and Skype which are good functions I would use this particular device.

Also on Alexa app which you need to use with the echo show, the menus offered are a bit disorganized. It should be more intuitive how to use and get around the menus when first using the device. I’m use to apple where everything is simplified and you know how to use the iPhone or iPad easily the first time. It took me a while to figure out how to work and personalized the device to my needs having to watch YouTube videos and read articles. I don’t want to do extensive research when first using a device, that should be reserved more unique features, not just to perform simple functions.

I also saw YouTube videos previous to the purchase that said the speaker was great. The speaker is actually pretty lousy I’m surprised they even said that. Of course you can always connect via Bluetooth to a speaker.

The display of the echo itself is beautiful and it is cool how when you turn off the light in your room the echo show will display a night version of the clock. I also like how you can make personalized questions and answers.

It’s good as a digital display clock to check weather and make alarms, reminders, even recipes as it advertised but otherwise don’t have your expectations too high for such an device. I don’t think it’s worth the $84 or whatever asking price. Sometimes amazon has a sale on this device which is when I feel it’s more worth it. Although I personally believe a device that is so limited and has much room for improve is worth closer to $40-50.

If you’re ok with what I discussed above. With the echo show being a digital clock with a few little quirks than it may be the device for you

I absolutely love this Echo Show 5! It's exactly what I was looking for and a bit more. I have 3 kids, 2 of which are in school. My husband and I work full time plus some- his schedule is the same, but mine varies. We also live with his mother, which is fantastic, as she help out with the kids when our shifts overlap. Our life can get pretty crazy around here. I'm an organized person and like schedules and consistency. I was having a hard time getting the other 2 adults on board with my schedules for the kids, as well as having difficulty keeping the kids accountable for tasks they could accomplish themselves. My oldest is autistic as well, so he needs schedules and consistency, or he has some meltdowns and life gets more crazy for all. We were having problems with getting ready for school on time. They walk to school and I wanted them to learn how to be ready and leave on time, in case I had to work early and no one else was up to guide them out the door. Bedtime has been a struggle for a few months now- afraid of the dark, too early, ect. (I did buy a weighted blanket for my autistic child and that helped too)
What I needed:
-a bedroom clock with alarm for each of the kids' room
-a night light
-a schedule
-some way of letting the kids know what needed to be done when
-didn't want to spend tons of money, but was willing to spend some to get my sanity back

I got it all plus an intercom with video! Bonus!!!
All access to each device on my phone! Bonus!!!

I bought 3 Echo Show 5s. One for each kid room and one for down stairs. I set up my whole schedule for them- morning, afterschool, and bedtime routines under the routine setting. It took awhile to set up- and I had to set up the same routine for each device I wanted to play it on (I did all the devices the same, since I didn't know where my children would be when the routine went off) I was nervous that there was going to be an alarm that went off on all the devices at the same time, but Alexa just says what I they need to do and the words show up on the screen too and then it goes back to what ever was going on (clock, youtube, ect)
The first day, I woke up to the kids getting dressed on their own. The morning proceeded without yelling, or arguing. My autistic child was even ahead of schedule at one point and told Alexa he already completed the task. They were off to school on time. When the evening came around, my mother in law had the kids, as I was at work. Same thing, no arguments about chores, bedtime, or homework. Alexa being the one to set the schedule took the arguing away. The kids knew what they needed to do and they did it.
I love that I can easily change and update the routines on my phone.
I love that I can drop in or announce something to any or all of the devices.
I love that it also communicates with my echo dot in my room.
I love that I can use it as a baby monitor for my youngest.
I love that all 3 adults can access the Alexa app on our phones and communicate with the kids.

Perfect size! Replaced my old amazon tap that I used in the bedroom as a speaker and alarm. This is quite an improvement! Voice commands work well and I do like the idea of using the touch screen occasionally to control devices. Sound is pretty good for a small unit and is works well as a bedside speaker. I’m sold on Echo devices. The complaints I’ve heard about echo have been “mostly” unfounded, at least based on my experience. It does things very well and is constantly learning.. quickly! I would like to see better management of photo’s, the google/nest hub does this very well. I’d also like to see, as everyone would, Amazon and Google drop the restrictions on each other’s services and focus on the customers desire to enjoy improved integration. I do like my echo’s though and the Show 5 is a really nice addition!!

Update: 09/282019: Amazon has advised it is a glitch and engineers are working on it! I have absolutely loved the Show5, until anout a week and a half ago..apparently a software update was done and now the large numbers on the clock face have gone to small numerals in the upper left hand corner of the screen...now I can’t see this without glasses on my nightstand..Come on Amazon...why did you do this?
Original post:
Wow! I have a full-size echo, and three Dots..use them all the time. I decided to try the Show5...I got it today and it is amazing! It’s small, but just the right size for my bedside table. The sound and picture quality are good! My Wyze cams work well, but my Ring doorbell isn’t working, YET..I’m sure it will. Very please with this device!
Update: my two Ring doorbells now work! LOVE THE SHOW 5!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent! Great Picture, Great Sound, Wonderful Device
reviews.reviewText:
I was looking at some of the ONE STAR-TWO STAR reviews, and those people have NO IDEA about this device! You can turn off the ads, you can control the volume , it has equalizer, and TONS of features on this Device. Watch TECH WITH BRETT on youtube, he has 35 minute video where he discusses all the features on this device. I learned a lot!
Sound gets VERY LOUD if you turn the volume up all the way. Brett had 10 inch show next to this device and the Show 5 was VERY loud!

If you don't like the clock, or any other feature it can be adjusted!

My recommendation is look at YouTube videos of the SHOW 5, there are many of them. Learn about the device before you give user review.

Watch Brett's walk through of this device on YOUTUBE! :)

reviews.reviewTitle: This is more of a review of Amazon's ordering process and customer service that of the device
reviews.reviewText:
Amazon offered a bundle of the Echo5 and the Ring 2 for $139. I ordered two of them for two of my daughters and received one. The order got changed to only one of the bundles without and explanation. I contacted customer service and spent better than 30 minutes explaining to them what happened and trying to convince them that I actually did order two of the bundles. Of course they asked me if I had a screen shot of my order showing two were ordered, never occurred to me that I needed to do this. Oh and they had extracted some gift card money from my account that I didn't want to use for this order but nothing could be done about that either. I couldn't order another of the bundle because it wasn't being offered any longer. Finally I disconnected from the chat because I realized I was wasting my time with the so-called customer service support. Then I get a message from customer service asking if I could just order the individual items and they would return the price difference to me as a gift card amount. I placed the order for both devices and got back in to the chat where I was told that they couldn't do anything for me because the bundle was one per customer. Now wouldn't you think that would of been mentioned on the web page and just "maybe" they would of changed the number ordered field so you could change the number ordered from 1 to a higher number? Maybe even pop up a window when you tried explaining that it was one per customer? How long has Amazon been doing this? So I had to go back in and cancel the order customer service just asked me to place.
I've been a very good customer of Amazon (both at work and at home) but this has not made me a happy customer.
I'm pretty sure this review will never get posted on the Amazon site so I'll make a copy of it and spread it around.
Amazon you need to get your act together. It may seem like you are the only game in town but you aren't and apparently you need so customer service training.

reviews.reviewTitle: Overpriced alarm clock? Dorbell cam screen? Recipie lister?
reviews.reviewText:
This Show 5 is basically made to go on a bedside table and be used as a voice activated alarm clock, but that's not how it's advertised. Even if you used it that way, it's not really that good.

I have a *lot* of "Alexa" stuff... Echos, Dots, an auto, and a couple of Fire 4K sticks. I love them all (auto's a different story), but the Show 5 is pretty disappointing.

I have dot in my living room that I use all the time for smart home lights and music. My intent was to replace the dot with the S5 so that I could see my cameras in addition to everything I already do... but it's not a "Dot with a screen". The far field voice recognition is awful. Placed 10 feet away the S5 ignores me quite a bit, and instead the dot from 25 feet away in another side room answers. It's very frustrating to be randomly answered by a dot in the other room. That never happened with the dot in the same place.

Also the sound quality is not great. No sweat, you can pair it to a Bluetooth speaker. Unfortunately, in that that configuration it disconnects from the speaker whenever you use it in a music group and you're stuck back with the poor quality sound again. Again, the dot is a workhorse and happily plays music through the Bluetooth speaker while in a group.

My "solution" is to but the dot back and change the S5's wake word to echo and us it for the sole purpose of looking at cameras. It's OK for that, but not for the price. Also, Amazon really needs to think up some better wake words. In my house the words "computer" and "Amazon" get used multiple times in a day. I'm sure they'd have a legal battle with "OK Amazon" but I'm also sure they have a lot of smart employees that could figure it out.

So basically, I have a mini camera screen and clock that doesn't play well with any of the other "Alexa" devices. , sounds poor, and doesn't understand me. I'm keeping it, but that's the last one I'll even buy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fun but not a good monitor for streaming
reviews.reviewText: I bought 2 of these after reading you can stream Arlo cameras. I need this because I am a sole caregiver and need to monitor the patient constantly. I would have givens them 5 stars if I was only interested in a high-end alarm clock and needed to ask stupid questions like how to boil an egg. As monitors, they fail miserably. Connections can be made to all my Arlo cameras but the viewing lasts anywhere from a minute to 15 minutes before we're back at the home screen with no warning. Checking user group posts, this has been a problem for years that neither Amazon or Arlo is doing anything to fix it. So, I though I'd waste a little more money and try a Wyze Cam Pan thinking it might not have the problem. It's exactly the same as for the Arlo cams. I'll keep the Echo 5's because I love to he "Okay" all the time (another thing you can't get rid of anymore). Also, the scrolling suggestions that still pop up even though I've deselected all the subjects.

I love this! It is perfect for your bedroom and makes a great clock for your nightstand.
I wanted this to use as a baby monitor. I have cloud cams that I use (I am able to name them for what room they belong in) and I am able to ask Alexa to show that room. It will show the camera all night long till I ask Alexa to stop. I’ve only had a problem a few times where I woke up to the camera not on. I realized after it was from either the camera updating or the show. I could not be more impressed with how it works for a baby monitor.
It connects to the ring door bell as well. Great for when you’re to lazy to check the app on the phone and you’re laying in bed watching tv. You can just say “Alexa, show me my front door” and bam!
I have my iPhone calendar linked up to the show. It will show all my upcoming events on the show. I love this feature. My 12 year old doesn’t have to ask me what we are doing every day, she can just look at the show.
It has a nighttime mode for the clock what I personally really like!
You can also set up a personal home screen.
Music plays great. The only down fall, you can only steam amazon music on one device at a time UNLESS you have an unlimited music plan. Some amazon music will show lyrics where you can sing along like your personal karaoke screen. I have videos of my husband and father in law jamming out to our show in the kitchen lol.
It does connect to Apple Music, pandora, XM Radio and more and you can stream all different music providers on each device you have if you want.
You can also connect to Bluetooth speakers along with connecting your phone to the show so you can listen to your podcast through the speaker and not your phone.
There is so much you can do with this little device and I could not be more pleased with this purchase. I bought one for my daughters room too and it works great for an alarm clock and a radio.

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa with a Screen at an Odd Angle
reviews.reviewText:
I really wanted to love the Echo Show 5.

As an Alexa device, it is excellent - great speaker quality (surprising, really) - it easily replaces my gen-1 Echo tower in the living room. The design looks sleek, the different clock faces are awesome - excellent way to incorporate Alexa on a shelf. It does what Alexa/Echo devices do, so I don't try to let the Echo/Alexa ecosystem affect my impression of an Alexa product. If you like Alexa, you'll like this unit. This does everything my Gen 1 Echo Tower did, both the good and the bad.

There are definite pluses to having a screen - we got this at the same time as my parents so our kids can 'drop in' on Grandma and vice-versa. If you have kids and the grandparents are several states away, this is reason enough to buy this device. Other pluses are the ability to ask to "show the Porch" or "show me the backyard" to see my Ring camera displays. Awesome.
The calendar integration is nice - it doesn't do enough to be the 'home dashboard' I would want. I would love to pull in backgrounds from a defined Google Photos album (sorry, Amazon hates Google) and be able to define what shows on the screen at all times. Instead, I get Amazon ads. They are unobtrusive, but still a bit annoying that Amazon gets more say over what I can show on the device I BOUGHT to put in MY HOUSE than I do. Amazon still has a bit of "we are not an evil empire" work to do.

For all it does well, there are things it definitely does not do well. If I want to see one of my cameras, I need to ASK Alexa to show the device. I would rather have the screen just pop up and show my Ring cameras when they detect motion. It's more of a feature request, but having the ability to show which camera when motion is detected would make me buy at least 3 more Echo Show type units without hesitation. Right now, everything has to be a prompt. I would love to not have to rely on my phone to notify me, then call out to Alexa to show me the camera. Frankly, it's a waste of a solid ecosystem.
Additionally, The Echo Show doesn't seem to know it has a screen all the time. "Alexa, play Baby Shark" won't play the Baby Shark video off YouTube. It will play the Baby Shark song from my library. Try explaining to a 2-year-old why the screen in front of her is not showing her the Baby Shark video on the 700th time she's asked for it. #ThanksAmazon

The angle of the screen is an issue. You can buy a stand for it, but I really shouldn't have to. Amazon should have thought about this. Everything else about the Echo Show 5 screams 'really well thought out design' except for the angle. Setting it on an end table? Video calls will be annoying. Looking at anything is straining. It's a 5-inch screen. Bigger screens would be much better, but for what the Echo Shows offer it's not worth the cost of the bigger screen currently. Add a few more features and customization and get over yourself and allow Google integration as well as some other things and it would be worth it. There are ways to turn a Fire Tablet into a glorified Echo Show with a dock, and I think that may be a better option unless you care about sound quality. The Echo Show 5 does have excellent sound quality which puts the gen 1 Echo tower to shame.

Echo devices keep improving, so changes are I will buy another larger Echo Show in the future. But I want the ability to see all my smart home devices and tap to control so I don't have to speak. Can I see all my smart lights? Nope. Not on the screen. I can on the app on my phone but not the screen. Amazon is SO CLOSE to having a true 'Smart Home Hub' but they seem to be held back behind the want to show ads and restrict content from Google. Amazon needs to realize that playing nice with others will get them further than trying to force the ecosystem. and make these devices so much better than what they are currently.

This is a case of,"I got exactly what I asked for, but not what I wanted". I wanted to view security cameras on this, but even tho there is a skill for both my brand cameras, neither system works with the Show. It must be understood that only a system that is especially designed to work with these, will work. Most aren't. So, if your brand camera or system is listed, it may not be compatible. Mine aren't. And they are brand names. So my inteñded purpose failed. I already had the Dot, now basically have two Dots, but one has a screen. It's like having a smart phone that you must leave plugged in, without ability to add apps. We love our Dot, and use it a lot. The Show responds well to us, but we don't have much use for the screen now that we can't see the security cameras. Questions we ask, we don't need to "see" the answer, just listen to the verbal response given. The Show has a little more bass sound than the Dot. The Show software is a little buggy. Even as a clock, it's so annoying when "Try this" resets the screen each time it kicks in. And, yes, I have all screen content turned off and it still runs "Things to try". And the date comes and goes on face. Sometimes it's there, sometimes it's not. The built in camera, along with the Drop In feature may be useful sometime as a sorta nanny cam. The Show has a lot of features that work well for their intended purposes. They just need to stop forcing"Things to try" on customers. It's really a useless feature that if was included on the smart screen radio of their next new car, would really really really tick them off. I won't purchase new security cameras that DO work with the Show for now. So for me, I am disappointed only in that respect (and the Things to try force). It depends on your needs and wants as to whether I would recommend this to you. So that would be a yes and no. It's a good unit for what it does. It just failed for me.

reviews.reviewTitle: An affordable and compact addition to the Echo Show line.
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased it during Prime Day as it was on sale for $50 and I had an additional 10 off from Whole Foods. So just over $40 for a speaker/screen/alexa combo was hard to pass up. Overall I think this device is great, obviously some features are lacking but you get what you pay for. The one thing I am disappointed about is the quality of the camera, even for this 1 MP is very low and makes dropping in with someone almost pointless (not that I'll be using that feature all that much). Other than that, the sound quality is good, videos look great and play with no issues, it was easy to set up, and I've been using it every day so far. Also, do not listen to the reviews saying you can't turn the scrolling or "things to try" off, it's easily turned off by going to the settings on the device itself.

Again, remember you are getting a smaller more affordable version of the show. So when the features aren't what you wanted do not come and complain to Amazon. Everything about the device is clearly listed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wish they'd put more work into voice
reviews.reviewText:
This thing hovers on the point of being really good - but it falls flat with some really aggravating failures.
Many times I will say something like "Alexa, play Good Omens Amazon Prime" only to have it tell me there's no internet.
Ask it about internet and it plays dumb about knowing anything about it. Ok you daffy machine - you use the internet to do your voice recognition. Hard to believe it's down. It would be nice to have the machine be able to run a self diagnostic. My only cure for the "no internet" is to reboot it. Then miraculously it has internet again. Mind you nothing else in the house (and I have over 20 different devices connected) has issues.
Another irritating thing is the constant little prompts to make it do tricks. Hey Amazon - gimme an option to turn this crap off. Most of the "tricks" don't even work. You read it directly off the screen and it says "I don't know how to do that". It's already annoying that you ask me to try it but then you say "whut?" - aggravating like Lucy pulling the football away from Charlie Brown.
Another one. Alarms. Trying to phrase it just right is tricky. I found setting it in the app is much less hassle.
So you decide to sleep in or it's a holiday. "Alexa, cancel alarm tomorrow morning". It says ok then every single time it asks if you want to delete the entire series. It would be great if Amazon could teach Alexa the word "just" - "Alexa, turn off JUST tomorrow morning alarm". End of discussion.
When it works it works well. But I do wish they'd iron out the bugs - it seems as long as it doesn't catch fire Amazon is happy to let you live with mediocre functionality. The little screen is surprisingly good - there, I said something positive ;).

reviews.reviewTitle: A good upgrade from the Echo Dot, but not perfect. Sound and Voice recognition review
reviews.reviewText:
There's other more in depth reviews on what it can do, but I'm be reviewing the sound, voice recognition and screen. Of course having a screen is a big plus, but I find it small at times being only 5 inches. That's what she said!

Sound:

A step up above the Eco Dot 2nd generation I replaced. But it still only has 1 speaker so sound is in mono, not stereo. However, the one speaker is louder and has more bass. Since this is in my kitchen, I often listen to music while I cook or wash dishes. Music in Mono sounds like crap. So I've plugged a stereo Bluetooth speaker via the aux outlet .

Why did I plug it instead of connecting to Bluetooth? Because Alexa can't go into "follow up" mode if it's Bluetooth connected to a speaker. BUT it can if you use the aux cord. Follow up mode is when you ask Alexa a question and it listens to hear a follow up question. This is very helpful at times. For example; "where's the nearest Pizza Hut?" then follow up and say "Call them" instead of saying "Alexa" twice. Even though the one speaker sounds better, what use is it if it's plugged into a better sounding dual speaker stereo?

Voice Recognition:

It picks up my voice good, but I found that the Echo Dot was better. It could pick up my voice from across the room but the Echo Show 5 missed my voice about 30% of the time. I can live with it because now I just walk closer to it.

Screen:

When playing music, it displays the lyrics. When listening to the news, it displays video. When asking for weather, it also shows it on the screen. This is very helpful. BUT since it's in my kitchen and I move around a lot, cooking or cleaning, I'm often too far away to see what's on the screen. How can it be useful if it can't be seen? Being that it's a touch screen is nice though. At 5 inches, its too small. I mean even my phone has a 6 inch screen.

Final thoughts:

I would've never bought this at $90 but on Prime day, I got it for $25 after trading in my Echo Dot 2nd generation. The screen is helpful but unless you're using it as a night stand clock, it's almost useless as it's too small. I could have used my 8 inch Fire tablet as an Alexa device instead. It can act like an Echo Show in "Show mode."

Overall, 4 stars. Slightly better speaker, but slightly worse voice recognition, has a screen.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good alexa integration, fair sound, annoying sleep timer and "try this" ads on screen
reviews.reviewText:
Unboxed this today and found it to be sleek and modern looking.

Liked that I could customize the home page a bit, putting a personal photo on. Very easy to set up to WiFi, then it took about 5 minutes or so to update itself and it was then ready for use.

Sound is fair. Not as good as my original Alexa, and if you are using this primarily for speaker, I'd say move on. Fine for a casual listener, though. To be fair, I do not have the stand, which may affect the way it sounds. There is an equalizer to play with and that does help from the standard settings.

Sleep function is annoying and not changeable as far as I have read. After 10 minutes, if you are not touching the screen, the home screen will return, so if you are using it to follow a recipe, for example, that could get annoying.

The "Ads" (ie, "Try this feature") will go around one time, then you can stop them in the settings. It is annoying that they must show once, but it's not a deal breaker for me.

Voice recognition is very fast and accurate and I enjoy the visual feedback.

Video playback (as in searching for and playing video) is powered by Bing, so be prepared to not get the official music video, but rather whatever the top result is.

It does integrate with calendars from different platforms, (ie apple), but when I asked for when my Dr. Smith appointment was, she said she couldn't find it. It was displaying at the time. So there needs to be some work done there.

The display is crisp and bright, and I do like the way it looks.

Overall, for a small speaker that shows me the weather, time and date and plays some music, it does a good job and looks nice.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great portable version of the Show 10. Love it. Great value for price too.
reviews.reviewText: I've had this for a few days. Set it up like our Show. I've played apps, watched movies (it's on my headboard) when my husband was asleep. I love it. It's going to be out travel Alexa. Sound is really good for size, it had good depth. Picture is great. This took the place of our Spot, which in love it too but it's going in a guest room.
Everything, alarm, weather, communicate with other rooms and my brother who lives approx 20-30 miles away. Love the fact that you can close the cam. Sound is great and screen quality is good enough.

I have it on counter in family room and it works just fine without the optional stand. Screen is clear and easily readable for its size. It is just exactly what I expected. It work well with both my Ring doorbells and my Blink cameras. The only thing I miss over the Echo is when I use the wake word from behind it there is no visual indication that it is awake. I have to issue the command and wait for a response where the echo I could see the light ring around the top when it woke. Other than that, it is a fun addition to me collection of echo units.

I greatly enjoy Amazon Alexa products and have slowly integrated them into my home. I wanted to use the Echo Show 5 as a replacement for my bedside alarm. It functions perfectly as an Alexa device to play music, turn on smart plugs, etc. What sold me on an Echo Show 5 was the manual shutter for the camera. I could care less about devices recording my voice but potentially recording video is another issue.

Setting up an alarm is relatively simple by asking Alexa or manually setting up the alarm through the menu. However, there are some limitations. I want to wake up to my Pandora radio station but this cannot be setup manually, instead, you must instruct Alexa to set this up verbally. Another limitation is the lack of physical buttons such as a snooze, alarm 1, alarm 2, on/off button. Many times I've attempted to dismiss the alarm by swiping up on the screen only to have triggered snooze by accident (this is a little frustrating first thing in the morning). I personally would appreciate Amazon integrating some physical buttons where I can customize their functions.

The only other issue would be the constant ribbons instructing me to try this or try that but this is a well-known issue discussed in other reviews.

Overall, this is a nice device with a clear screen. If you are using for anything other than an alarm clock I would say go for it. Needless to say, I have returned to my old radio alarm clock. Hopefully in the future Amazon will offer a dedicated bedside alarm clock or refine the Show with some physical buttons.

reviews.reviewTitle: Screen Runs Hot & Interface Is Weak
reviews.reviewText: This product isn't necessary, especially for someone that doesn't utilize the video call features. Honestly, I'm not sure that I can access the full Amazon Prime video library through this product. Maybe if I knew what I wanted to watch, I could call up the title, but that's rarely the case with streaming. Similar to the Netflix search void, Amazon's black hole is significantly worse because 1) their options are weak and uninspiring (beyond The Boys) and 2) the user interface and design are still the worst in the game. I don't know why I purchased this. Maybe it's because I like asking about the weather and playing the occasional game of Jeopardy. The constant scrolling recommendations isn't my idea of fun, though, nor is a screen that feels like a car hood sitting out in the mid-summer sun. I don't know if my product is defective, but I actually fear keeping it on every day. If I'm out of the house for more than a weekend, I pull the plug. I honestly believe this product to be a fire hazard and I'm genuinely shocked that this is safe for households. Bottom line: you don't actually need this. It's a glorified clock that talks and plays the occasional crappy TV show or movie.

I am SO satisfied with my Echo Show 5...love that I can turn off the camera...and Alexa when I need to...also...the screen dims perfectly when the room gets dark...no bright light to disturb my sleep...this product is all...and more than I expected...no complaints!
The Prime Days price is great!!!

I started with one of the 1st or 2nd generation much larger Echo Shows which I am pleased with, but I don't think I'd buy a 2nd one for the price, until these new smaller Echo Show 5(s) came out. Bought one 1st for my daughter and she loved it, and just now bought a 2nd one for my own room. Newer software and compatibility with other smart devises makes it a breeze to set up home automation. My original Echo Show was already set up to my Ecobee smart thermostat. I bought smart LED lightbulbs for the kitchen and 2 plain non-color changing bulbs for the master bedroom. Setting up the lightbulbs was pretty easy and once I got them setup with any one of the Echo(s), there was nothing I needed to do with any of the other Echo shows. We used to leave our cell phones plugged in and on all night as an alarm clock, now we just tell Alexa to wake us up every morning and turn our phones off. We have Amazon music for the whole house and both our daughters and us now lie in our own rooms listening to our favorite songs as we go to sleep. No more fiddling with a bunch of buttons, just "Alexa play" and the name of the song or "Alexa wake us up at". It is that easy. "Alexa turn on the Kitchen" or "Alexa, turn on Master Bedroom #1". They are also compatible with and connected to my Arlo Pro security cameras, however I'm still not impressed with how they work together, and believe it to be a flaw with both Arlo and the Echo software. If you are going to get them just for compatibility with security cameras, then I would not recommend them, but if you want to use them as alarm clock, music/media players, intercoms, thermostat controls, and as a hub for a lot of your smart devices then definitely well worth the money. I don't know anything about home automation and had a professional company come out at quote quite a bit more that I wanted to pay and could afford. A few years later, with these new Echos and minor changes in wifi and bluetooth smart devises, I got all the same functions the pros were quoting at less than a 4th of the price that I installed myself..

We purchased this to view and answer the front door from the Kitchen. When the visitor walks up to the door the Echo Show 5 will say motion detected. Then when they press the button on the Ring 2 and it says someone is at the front door. At that moment you speak Alexa answer the front door. The mic is turned on and you can speak to them and see who it is. Lastly you can ask it to show the video from the front door. We love it and plan to buy more. FYI - You need to add the Ring skill to the Echo Show 5 for this to work.

Now regarding the other aspects of the Show. We use it to play music from Prime. It also allows adding skills so it will read to you or work with other smart devices. You can change the screen to display pictures, weather or stock price. You can add more if needed or delete. Just tell it to do so. We also plan on using it with our Ring alarm in the future.

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa is frustrating, stick to Google or Apple
reviews.reviewText: Amazon Alexa has been a complete and utter disappointment. Apparently I have been spoiled with Google Assistant on my phone and a Google Home Mini because using Alexa has been nothing but problems. It hardly recognizes my commands, often plays the wrong songs or searches for the wrong things and freezes up when switching from one task to the next (say going from Prime Video to Spotify). Even as a simple clock, Amazon would rather waste screentime telling me what I can search for or minimizing the time and weather to a small corner of the screen. It's honestly very frustrating to use and I truly recommend folks stick with Siri or Google because Alexa isn't ready for primetime. It does some things right like the weather or play Prime Videos clearly but for everything else it's a frustrating mess of a device. It's now relegated to the bathroom because it's too annoying to keep anywhere where you'd use it more often. I got the Echo Show 5 as a test of the Alexa eco-system and now I will be running right back to Google. Amazon is great with Prime, shipping quickly and the Kindle but this isn't it.

My main use case for this was to replace the alarm clock on my bed and not disturb my sleeping wife. It is at best 2 stars for this. Why?

1) Alarms. If you dismiss a non-repeating alarm you have to reenter it.
2) Alarms. There is no way on the Show to have a list of alarm times (like google hub has) and select the one you want to enable. You can do this in the app, but that is many extra steps. Why not mirror the App alarm list on the show?
3) Alarms. Tapping anywhere on the show causes the alarm to snooze. you must swipe up to dismiss. Very unnatural when being awakened by the alarm. My Goole phone presents two buttons on the screen, Dismiss, and snooze.
4) Alarms. To turn it on, you must slide out, select Alarms, then enter the alarm time. Not exactly a time saver from flipping a switch on my dumb clock (which ahs multiple alarm times).
5) Night Display. Almost unreadable. The screen glows gray from the backlighting, then there is red lettering that can only be read from straight on. That means I must raise my head up to see the time.

I do like the weather display, integration to my outlook schedule (something google does not do), and integration to my Smartthings smart house.

The lack of good alarm clock integration will likely have me taking it back to the store.

Update: I downgraded from 3 to 2 stars because of a new Alarm problem. There is no way from the Show 5 to cancel an upcoming alarm from the device without using voice. You can only do it from your phone. For me, the phone is on the other side of the house. So that leaves me with a choice when I wake up before my alarm. Lie there until it goes off, get up, walk across a dark house, and turn it off from my phone, or wake my sleeping wife. None of these are good choices. Why can't I turn it off from the Alarms screen????

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa has developed a lisp & other audio distortion issues
reviews.reviewText:
Update 9/28/2019
The new unit they sent me doesn't have the audio issues anymore, but now there is a display issue. For a while I could see the large clock on the home screen. Now it just gives me the small clock (not the one I selected) and tells me to try stuff. I have all the rotation and content disabled and I cannot get it to show the large clock without the suggestions.

Previous review
Other review will tell you about the other pros/cons of this unit. But many of us are having audio issues. Intermittently, Alexa sounds very distorted in the high frequencies, so the S’s are annoying loud. Just sounds like something is fried inside. Music played via bluetooth also can sound this way, and sometimes the volume jumps up super high (like trying to fall asleep white noise played via bluetooth). These things make it unusable for me.

Customer service said they have never had this issue reported. But I even found it on an Amazon forum and in the product reviews. They wanted me to send it in for “inspection” that would take 2 weeks. After some negotiating they finally agreed to send me a new unit and waived the “whatever extra service” fee. I am very skeptical that the new unit will not have the same issue. I’ll update this review after I get it.

Here are some of the ways other customers reported the same issue:

-there were multiple times when I started to get something similar to static from the device, kind of a distortion. It made Alexa sound like she had a lisp, and music was noticeably distorted.

-The biggest issue with the Echo Show 5 was sound distortion - random and intermittent.

-Recently after listening to music, radio or Spotify for a few minutes I notice distorted sibilance on speech and music. It is as though high frequencies are severely distorted. The only solution to stopping it was to unplug and restart the echo. It was then fine for a while but has started to do the same again.

-Sound is fine for a time but then starts to distort.

-I have had this happen a few times during night while I have it playing Rain Sounds while we sleep. NOT a good way to get woken up, let me tell you!

-I even exchanged mine for a new unit and the same thing happens.

reviews.reviewTitle: Finally an Echo with a screen and a camera I can physically disable.
reviews.reviewText:
I've been wanting an echo device with a screen, but didn't want a camera for vague paranoid reasons. The first thing I did when taking it out of the box, was slide the cover over the camera, and it became, basically, the perfect bedroom Echo device, and clock. It's not too big, the screen adjusts brightness really well (though i would prefer it get slightly darker, and maybe have the colors more configurable on each screen), and it presents information well.

We also disabled the random feature information that pops up, but it was nice that we could make them disappear.

We do wish we had the little animated dog image clock that it shows in the demo video, but we couldn't find it. I bought one when they were announced, and then bought a couple more when they were discounted on Prime day, upgrading a couple of our Echo Dots.

reviews.reviewTitle: I wish it supported more video options
reviews.reviewText:
To be clear, I think the MSRP of $90 is way too high for this. There was a promotion where I got two of them for $70, so at roughly $35 each, that felt like a much more reasonable price.

I've found voice controlling things with it to be a bit finicky. I had to disable an Alexa skill for my TV since any time I tried to play something on it, it would by default try to play it on my TV, and then say it couldn't do it.

Navigating videos takes some practice unless you want to use the touch screen to scroll through things.

I really wish I could use services like Plex and Vudu on it. As of writing this, Amazon Prime seems to be the main video source (no surprise). If I say something like "Alexa, show me -whatever- on youtube" it will bring up a variety of dailymotion links.

Speaking of video, I found that I have to use really precise wording with it. An example would when I tried to watch the movie Flash Gordon. I initially used the words "Alexa, watch Flash Gordon" and it then decided to play an assortment of Queen related music instead. Using the wording "Alexa, show me Flash Gordon" bypasses that and will actually show me Flash Gordon related videos. I encountered this issue with a few other things where I would use "watch," and it would instead try to play music.

As an experiment, I just asked it to "Show me a muffin recipe" and it provided a bunch of videos. If I say "Alexa, list muffin recipes" it will show the same videos, but it will also say the titles of the first four. After that, if I select one, it will show me the recipe as well as an option to start where is breaks it down into pages. Scrolling is still needed to see all of the text, but you can ask Alexa to "read step."

Traffic. I have several addresses in the Alexa app, and it seems to only want to show distance between my home and work (nothing about traffic). If I want to visit a relative, it is unable to show me anything (just to be clear, these other addresses are in my Alexa App, and I'm using the names I gave the addresses). If I say "Alexa, show me traffic to -specific address-," it will show me the distance. I haven't figured out if it can show me a local traffic map or not.

You can find Google Home Hubs on sale for a less than the MSRP of the Echo Show 5, and they seem to have a lot more functionality. I don't exactly regret getting my Echo Show 5s, but I would have been very unhappy with paying $90 each.

Ordered a couple of these. One for the kitchen, one for the bedroom. I especially like the physical shutter close slider for the bedroom camera. I was able to make a call to my sister in-law who has one of the original Echo Show's in just a second. The sound and clarity are impressive. Our kitchen echo show had some audio distortion though. I web-chatted with Amazon support to explain. They had me do a little troubleshooting and reset back to factory settings. A couple of hours later it happened again. I chatted with them again. No questions asked, they gave me the return info and said they would send another one out. It arrived the "next day!". Sent the old one back -no cost to me, and voila! Up and working again. Like I said, great product, great service! Would definitely recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good as an enhanced desk clock or counter top add-on. Not so much as a nightstand clock.
reviews.reviewText:
Update 3: Ugh... this thing. It has a mind of it's own. Now, after any interaction with ANY Echo device, it moves to another screen and away from the clock. That is the primary function of this device. If I could go back and smack my thumb off of the order button for this, I WOULD. What really pisses me off is that I traded in a 1st gen Dot and crippled some of my Dot accessories to get this thing - thinking it would replace those accessories. That in itself was a painful experience because they claimed they never received my trade-in when tracking said otherwise. Had to fight a $5 charge on my credit card. Down to one star for the whole mess. Hoping "Dot with Clock" will finally fit the bill.

Update 2: I have added 2 LAYERS of blackout film just to tone this thing down for use on a night stand. If my room had more ambient light in it, it would be fine, but that's not the case for me. Having to treat the screen like this negates all the other functions I wanted it for - namely seeing my cams from the bedroom after hours AND a bedside clock. I have higher hopes for the "dot with clock".

Update 1 (after thought): this device could benefit great from an OLED screen. Not so much for color or clarity, but more for the ability to turn off black pixels. While not blindingly bright, the edge lit LED still has a noticeable glow in pitch dark room, even on a fully dimmed night mode.

Original review:
I like this little ...thing... . It’s perfect as a nightstand clock. I don’t rely on alarms much. Having to interact with Alexa for alarm settings may be a burden to some. The most unexpected alarm feature is snooze. You just tap the top of the device to snooze any alarm- like a traditional clock, but no actual snooze button. The settings take a little tweaking. Overall, I turned off every screen element except weather.

My bedroom is quite dark all the time, so I turned off adaptive dimming. Otherwise it’s very dim all day and can barely be read. And because I did that, I also set night mode to be scheduled instead of adaptive. In the dark room, it was always in night mode.

I tinkered with Prime video and asked for a recipe just to see thode other functions. If you don’t mind watching videos on a 5.5” device, this might be ok for you. Don’t make it the primary function. Video calls to other echos is fine for clarity. But- there is one quirk... the camera placement. It’s so far to the right that anyone who uses it appears WAY off of center to the viewer on the other end. That feels like a massive design flaw that somehow slipped past the final QC.

At $90, it’s overpriced. I paid about $35. I bought on Prime Day, and also had a trade-in that got me 25% off and a $5 store credit. Being honest, this is a 5.5” android tablet strapped to a great sounding speaker. The function is there as long as you’re clear on what to expect. Buy it, but buy it on sale.

This is a solid Echo paired with a medium iphone-sized screen. Looks like an alarm clock. You can cover the integrated camera and that's a good thing. The set up menu works by swiping menus and is a bit clunky. I was able to turn off a bunch of notifications EXCEPT the "ask Alexa to ..." so that was annoying and disappointing. I was able to turn off the auto-dim features which is useful if you use it in a hall-way with little light. The screen savers are very limited and I found only one that I liked ... where are all the artsy photos that could be adorning the crisp screen of this handsome device? For those of us who view amazon photos on an iphone or computer, the option to display family photos is surprisingly bad with some photos being displayed way smaller than the screen? I had the feeling that voice recognition was ok but not great. Here is why I returned it - I wanted to be able to use my Arlo cams to display what is going on outside. Unfortunately, It took at least 10 seconds for the video feed to show (count to 10 ... that's a mighty long if you'd like to see who is in front of your door ... and that is only if the Echo Show understood me on the first command). In contrast the "motion-detected" Arlo skill is announced almost instantaneously on the Echo but does not require a screen. We had Alexa's since the beginning and this one is not quite prime-time as another reviewer said.

I have been reading through some of the reviews and I have found some consumers don’t invest enough time into reading the product descriptions and they have high expectations that the product just cannot possibly meet. Then they write poorly conceived and negative reviews. Since Smart Speakers are a new Tech genre you cannot expect it to do all things. Especially things it was not designed to do. If you are reading this. Take the negative as well as the positive reviews with a grain of salt. This type of product will fill different needs for different people. What I like you may not and what you like I may not. That being said. It works as advertised. It is not as loud as my Echo Shows 1 & 2 gens. But I didn’t expect it to be. Why? The size. You cannot fit large speakers into a small device. However, it works for me. I can hear it just fine. I like that there are Clocks to choose from. This is still not an option on the 1st & 2nd gen Echo Shows. It has a physical shutter for the camera. Also something the other Echo Shows do not have. Both of those things are pluses in my book. The size is better suited for a nightstand. On my nightstand I used to have my 1st gen Echo Show, then I replaced it with a 2nd gen Echo Show, now I have replaced that one with this new Echo Show 5. As for the “Try This” tips and tricks on how to use the Echo that appears at the bottom of the screen. For some seeing that is a problem, for me I don’t stare at my screen nearly enough for it to bother me. I glance at it to find out the time, the temperature or see one of the pictures I have uploaded to Amazon Photos. Occasionally I will open the browser and watch (mainly listen) to YouTube.

I used to take a Echo Dot with me hen I travel, but since getting this. I have used it to travel with. When it goes on sale again. I’ll buy another one and use it as my travel device. Eventually my plan is to replace all of my Echoes without a screen with Echoes with screens. I bought mine on Prime Day and I don’t regret my purchase. You are get a bang for your buck with this device.

I use this as an alarm clock and i love it. Im glad that the camera has a slider to cover it with. Especially since i rarely ever use it.

The screen looks nice, the speakers sound great, and it has a nice non-slick base that keeps it in place. (Which also seems to have a magnet in it so attaching it to stands is super easy.)

I wish there was more options for, or 3rd party alternatives for the clock faces. They look nice but there is not a lot of variety. Although you can connect it to amazon photos and use your own pictures instead but that can be a bit off putting at times as it doesnt pull of the picture frame look all that well. It definetly just looks like a screen. But it does have an auto brightness detection feature. And at night it doesnt stand out to brightly.

Although I did find all of the sort of alexa ads it displays a bit annoying. Especially since they are on by default, but i appreciate being able to turn them off. But even then it still shows a slide providing basic examples of what to ask her.

In the end, it definitely feels like an amazon product with the way its marketing to you. But if you take the time to disable all of these "features" it works great as a voice controlled alarm clock. And the sound quality on this thing is surprisingly good and punchy.

I recommend it on sale... but probably not at full price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Glad I picked this up! - Not as glad as I was when I first bought it.
reviews.reviewText:
EDIT on 9/11/2019: So I've had this thing a couple months now and while it works well as an Alexa it also seems to suffer the same fate many other Alexa devices have with the alarm clock. When you set a weekday alarm, you better be checking and verify that it says the alarm is set on the right side. That will once in awhile fool you causing you to be late for work on the day when your boss comes to town and wants to go to breakfast with you. Thanks Alexa! It's equipped with a 'snooze' feature but its even more useless than the alarm function because it only works about a quarter of the time with no real pattern to it. This is a known issue as it's been plastered all over the Amazon forums for years now with no fix in site but hey, I just got an email that Alexa can now tell me a barbecue joke, so I guess that's a substitute? Pffft.

So I picked this little guy up during Prime Day figuring if I hated it I wasn't out near as much money as normal. Already having a half dozen Alexa devices I knew what I was getting into but was intrigued by the screen. I've had my eye on the Echo Spot for awhile now but never pulled the trigger waiting on this guy. I'm glad I waited. The ability to to customize it is great and I'm sure they'll continue to evolve it as time goes on. It looks like an alarm clock on my night stand and with the ambient light auto adjustment features it isn't annoying in the middle of the night. Setting alarms and more importantly snoozing alarms without needing to knock everything off the nightstand is fantastic! I listen to a LOT of music on my Alexa devices so sound quality is important to me. The sound is equivalent to an Echo Dot 3rd gen which is great for the price.

Pick on up! You'll be glad you did!

reviews.reviewTitle: Cool, useful in ways, but it's a love / hate relationship with this thing! Dumbest AI on the planet!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought the Show 5. Great little screen, good decent sound, customizable in certain ways, so I like it... to some extent.

But I also hate it.

My issue is really with the Echo software and AI, not so much the Echo 5.

It's useful: I use it to set morning alarms, countdown timers for when I'm cooking, to turn on and off and dim my lights, to define words, to do conversions for money and temperature, to perform calculations, to check value on a stock or Bitcoin, and that's mostly it. So it's convenient in those ways (when it works). I'd like to spend some time figuring out what more I can do with it on the daily (or weekly) that would benefit me.

But the thing I CANNOT STAND about the Echo is that it probably has some of the dumbest AI (Artificial Intelligence) on the planet.

The word that's supposed to trip it in order to listen to your commands, as we all know, is "Alexa." But there are times when it will trip on words that don't sound anything like "Alexa." And the room I have it in is always quiet, so it should be able to hear me no problem. Today, I was conversing with someone and said the word "unacceptable" and it tripped, thinking I said "Alexa." I tried it two more times, and it did the same thing. It then proceeded to recite some poem about someone I have no idea about. I'm thinking what in the green Earth is wrong with this stupid thing?? And how does "unacceptable" sound anything like "Alexa"??

A number of times, it's tripped on other random words. One time, it did this and then proceeded to produce a raging fart sound over its speakers. Can you believe that?? What garbage! I didn't command it to do that! I guess it was just reflecting what it often is: CRAP. I unplugged it at that point and later plugged it back in to reset it.
