Seriously... what knuckleheads are programming this stupid thing?

I've said a number of things that sound nothing like "Alexa" and, stupidly, it kept tripping every time I repeated those words to test it.

Other times, I say "Alexa" very clearly and it won't trip at all. So it trips when it should not, and fails to trip when it should -- often enough that I'm motivated to write about it. What is wrong with this thing??

It can't seem to find information that should be easy to find. For example, I was watching a documentary about Bill Gates, so I asked Alexa, "When is Bill and Melinda Gates' wedding anniversary?" and it proceeded to tell me when Melinda's birthday was. Say what??? What does her birthday have to do with their wedding anniversary?

Bloody stupid. Naturally, I had to turn to Google to get the answer.

Another time, I asked Alexa (on Fire TV) to do a search for the movie "Tall Girl" that just came out. It responded "This feature isn't supported on Fire TV" thinking I told it to "call girl." I tried it two more times, each time with the same result. I do voiceover work and there are few people who can enunciate as clearly as me. Yet, this thing is still too dumb to tell the difference between the words "tall" and "call." Seriously, Amazon??

Yet another time, I asked it to turn on "Nightstand" (one of my lights) and it failed to do so, while responding "I can't do that with Christmas lights." I'm perplexed, thinking "when the heck did I say 'Christmas lights'?? How do you get 'Nightstand' mixed up with the words 'Christmas lights'??"

Just today, I asked Alexa where downtown Stockton is located in the U.S. (It's in California.) Alexa's response? "I don't know that."

SMH!!!! Again, I had to turn to Google to get the answer. So I've learned that if you want any sort of information at all, go with a Google device to get the answers you need.

So, while it's been useful in certain terms, it's the dumbest AI there is. Hands down.

I find myself muting the mic often so I don't have to endure as many of its flaws.

Look, I realize that people like Elon Musk and his past written manifesto have warned humanity of AI's ability to potentially wreak havoc in the world by growing in intelligence to a degree that surpasses that of humans. And industry incumbents like Bill Gates and the late Stephen Hawking agreed and warned of the same. However...

...this threat is absolutely NOT found with Amazon's Echo AI. To say that it's AS dumb as a box of rocks would be an insult to the box of rocks!

The Amazon Echo has a long way to go before it's truly useful and doesn't make mistakes every day of its existence. It's basically a dumb servant. Emphasis on "DUMB."

I would love to see Alexa's IQ increase to a number higher than the length of my shoe string. It would also be great if it had true voice recognition... as in, mine responds ONLY TO MY VOICE, and not the voice of my friends, and people on YouTube and on TV saying "Alexa" and making this thing trip all the time. I'm tired of having to mute audio sources or my Echo every time "Alexa" is uttered to keep that from happening.

And lastly, Amazon, let's not have both "Echo" and "Alexa." Please pick a name and stick with it. Just name it "Alexa" and get rid of the "Echo" moniker. Alexa is the name you give it by default to trip it (when that manages to work), and people mostly refer to the device that way, anyway.

reviews.reviewTitle: An alarm clock, A photo booth, A News station, and so much more ! !!
reviews.reviewText: There are already so many technical reviews on the internet, so I will skill all specs related reviews. This is my first Alexa device and I love it so much. I don't have too much preference on the audio quality, but it is pretty good and enough for your bedroom. I like how convenient it is, I can get time, weather, news and play music, podcast, make a quick call, turn off the light without stop doing my morning routine, all you need to do is say "hi" to Alexa. If you are a busy person in the morning, you will find it so helpful to get all you want while doing other things simultaneously. I especially like the small size and screen, it fits my desk or bedside table, it just looks like a stylish Alarm Clock, another good thing is you can display your photo on the background. And the DiveIn function is nice, when you want to check what your dog or cat is doing at home, it will be useful too. Make your home smarter with this little clock.

reviews.reviewTitle: Pretty cool, but just dont use it enough
reviews.reviewText:
So these went on super sale for Amazon Prime Day and I bought a ton! Figured we could replace a few alarm clocks, set one up in a different room or two, etc...
We had an Echo Dot and rarely used that, but figured maybe with an Echo Show, the fact that it displays the time and weather and such, would draw us in a bit more. Fact is, we just much rather pick up our phone and search/click/buy things ourselves.
These have a ton of potential but if you're not willing to sit there for hours to learn all of the neat tricks it can do, it probably isnt worth it. Unless you get these for dirt cheap like we did, then ya got yourself a fancy alarm clock.
The motion detection is pretty neat except when its dark in the room and youre trying to sleep. The screen can get a bit bright. I think there are options to change that, but the default setting is bright.
We connected all of them in the house to play music at the same time. A cool feature when cleaning the house or going from room to room doing chores. The sound these put off is pretty decent.
The video chat we used once and again that was only while we were sitting down to learn the ins and outs. Facetime on our iPhones is a much better quality and experience in my opinion so using the video chat probably isnt a reality for us.
I rated it 4 stars because it is a good piece of technology, its just not for us.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best New Smart Device on the Market, Rely on Reviews at your own Loss.
reviews.reviewText:
Many tech magazines reviewed the Echo Show 5 ahead of the initial release and is what convinced me to pre-order two. I am still learning new things daily about this device. I'm a bit shocked that there are so many low ratings for features that can be altered, or by the misinformation in many reviews.

The "5" in name of the device is for the size of the screen (5"), in case you were wondering.

These devices do not come with in-depth manuals, so a lot of the features are discovered through trial and error, and curiosity. The so-called "ads" (technically banners) can be completely turned off if you customize your home screen.

The clock senses darkness and light and the brightness auto-adjusts, but can also be customized. The idea is that the clock goes very dim during sleeping hours, and "begins to rise" with the sun. This is so cool - as it really does start dim and gradually gets brighter as the morning comes. But you can turn that off too.

You can also ask Alexa to go completely dark, if that's your preference, and she will.

It also senses when a person is within range and active. In other words, at 2:00 a.m., if you are up and being interactive with Alexa, it recognizes that, and stays up with you (the display stays brighter). When you conk out, the display begins to fade dimmer.

Video quality: If one wants to watch movies on their cell phone, they will probably love the same feature here. Most of us have televisions or laptops to stream videos. I did watch an episode of the Brady Bunch on it, and I didn't need to see the picture to enjoy the memories, but the picture quality was damn good.

You can upload your favorite photos (for Home screen or to cycle through like a digital frame), but be warned the quality on the Show 5 is much better than most cell phone pics, that it draws out the lack quality in some pictures. Have a few handy to swap out for this reason alone. I went back to the built in display offerings, which are much richer in color and detail.

As built, this wins hands down over Google's Smart clock, which is basically just a clock. Yet, Amazon combined the best of the Spot and Show, and the Echo Show 5 was born. That alone is no 3 star product.

Alexa can hear me just as well as through the Echo Dot. You can set a preference of which device will be the main device, if there are others nearby. Though Alexa gets a bit confused if too close together. I finally moved my Echo Dot to another room altogether.

Prime music with lyrics works great on this device. The font is large so that you can sing as you read along.

It sounds best if left on the nightstand. I tried bringing it closer to my ear in bed, listening to an audio book. Reduced quality this way. It needs that 360 space around it, like a Bose Wave.

Kindle / Audible books are better listening on this device. The audio sounds are adjustable (bass, treble, mid), using the app. Much better than through the Dot.

Mainstream and acoustical music is better than the full size Show. The loudest rock music does sound a bit better on the full size Show.

As a clock, simply placing a partial hand over the top will snooze the alarm for another 9 minutes. No button, it simply senses the proximity of the snuggler's touch and goes into a 9 minute snooze.

Like a regular clock radio, there are buttons for the volume up and volume down. You can still ask Alexa to adjust the volume, or use the app. But old fashioned folks are used to manual up and down buttons and Amazon obliged.

The slider to shut off the camera gets ignored by me a lot. Maybe I'm not that paranoid, but it can be done.

Voice purchasing is better with the Show than with the Echo Dot or Plus, since you get to see visually, the item(s) being purchased.

Voice purchasers, using Alexa only, get further discounts than shoppers online. I saved an additional $30 on a Ring Doorbell 2. Online during Prime Days was $139.00, but by voice purchasing through Alexa, the price dropped to $99.00. Well worth it.

If you want to surf the web, built in web browsers offer Amazon's new Silk browser and Firefox. The good news is there is a microphone to listen to your search so no manual typing is needed, unless that's your preference.

The cool factor is definitely here. I wish I had purchased a few more during Prime Days. I paid about $75 with a two-fer discount at its' inception, but at $49.99, I really think there is little room to complain, if all it did was perform like a glorified clock. I kind of feel sorry for my Dots, because they know I prefer to interact with the Show 5.

For $89.99, this clock / device is well worth the price just for what it does, even if certain features were permanent (WHICH THEY ARE NOT). For $75, a real bargain. At $49.00, that's a better than Black Friday deal, and I would do it all over again but not make the mistake of buying only one more.

I've advanced in tech years more than I'd imagined possible, and not ashamed to admit it. Just do yourself a favor and do not read too much into the reviews posted here by reviewers with hardly a month in of owning this device. A lot of smart people put a lot of effort into making this device exceed expectations, and they succeeded. And I still don't know all there is to do with the Show 5!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Not ready for prime time - It has issues - and I've had 2 of them so far ;-(
reviews.reviewText:
I've had 2 of these so far - both returned and am waiting for the 3rd to arrive, hoping it will work properly. The issues I've experienced are:
1. The screen is not uniformly bright - if you use your own photo for the background, the center is brighter than the four corners. I also have an original full-sized Echo Show and it does not have this problem - it's unique to the Show 5.
2. The screen randomly goes all BLACK and the clock digits and temperature become RED. Stays that way until I say the wake word, touch the screen, or just randomly eventually goes back to displaying normally. This happens during the day and at night, in a bright room and dark. Amazon customer service doesn't know why this happens - that's why #2 is being returned.
3. The screen becomes very hot to the touch. Maybe this is why the screen goes BLACK with RED digits? Who knows - again, my older original Show does not do this.
4. The voice recognition is not as good as my Echo Dots generation 1 and 3. The Show 5 frequently doesn't not recognize the names of my Alexa-automated lights, even though all of my dots understand them just fine.

I think the Show 5 is not yet ready for prime time and needs more development work. Too bad as I really wanted a clock version for my bedroom (I currently have an Echo Dot in my bedroom and it works great!)

Got this half off on Prime Day which made this a very sweet deal. I was sure to check the product comparison between this and its Google sister Nest Hub and although they tipped in favor of the Hub's larger size, I wasn't looking for a giant screen to put next to my bed. I don't have a TV in my room for reason. Sandstone is a nice off white color which blends nicely with earthy colors if you're looking to accessorize your room. The screen is about the size of a large smart phone and the setup is as foolproof as I've ever seen. I have 2 Echo Dot's that I also purchased on Prime Day for cheap and I don't know if the Show shares network info with them because I basically turned it on and it was ready to go. (That sounds wrong. Don't worry, it was all perfectly innocent.) Its functions are basic, not like having an iPad or a smart phone to play any app you wish. You have access to everything being an Amazon Prime member hands you. Sound quality is pretty good for non-audiophiles especially when I piped my Music Unlimited across all my Echo devices. If you want to rock a party, this is not the device you're looing for. The clock is smart enough to dim during the night to a dull amber with a black background and brightens its display as the time ticks closer to your selected wake-up time. The only thing I could wish for is to be able to use Netflix and for Amazon to get eco-friendly and realize I don't need every little thing wrapped in plastic.

reviews.reviewTitle: Ditched the alarm clock with no regrets
reviews.reviewText: I was that guy. The guy who still had a clock radio on the nightstand. I had to manually set the alarm each day. And yes, I'd forget sometimes, which is a royal pain. I could have used my phone I suppose but it never felt right. So when I saw the Echo Show, I thought that I might have found the right replacement. I already had an Echo Dot in the bedroom. But the speaker sucks (sorry) so I bought one of those speaker/battery combos. It worked well for a while, but the wake word didn't work as well (probably because the dot was dropped into a speaker case) and eventually the speaker itself stopped working (it was pretty cheap). So the Show looked to solve two problems. And to date, it has done a great job. The speaker quality is much better than the Dot. I do not feel the need for an external speaker at all when listening to music. I know a lot of people have complained about the promotional messages on the screen, but you can turn them off in the options. I love being able to ask Alexa to set an alarm for every weekday. I never have to worry about forgetting to set my alarm. I like the option to wake to music or the cool feature that starts the alarm very softly and gradually increases the volume for a gentle wake up. The voice recognition also seems improved over the Dot. I don't have to talk as loudly or slowly for the Show to recognize exactly what I want it to do. I have a lot of Smart Home integrations so having a good Alexa receiver is important to me. All in all, I'm super satisfied. I don't think I'll be using the camera so having the physical shutter for privacy is great. I just leave it shut. It's a super-charged clock radio replacement. I can't imagine ever going back.

We have Echo devices all over the house. A show in the kitchen, a first-gen echo and far too many dots to count. When these went on sale for Prime Day I snatched one up.

I was using a dot in the bedroom for playing my nighttime books and sounds and for morning alarms, but I missed having a clock. At less than $50, the Show 5 was a steal.

First, the Show 5 hears really well. Even with summer time fans, I didn't have to yell at it like I did the dot.

Second, the sound quality if far better than a dot.

Third, it really does adapt to the room lighting well.

I'm sure I haven't used all of its features, but for what I wanted the Show 5 was great.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bought this to replace my alarm clock
reviews.reviewText:
I was looking for a alternative to my current alarm clock. The one I had was sound machine with outdoor temp reading, indoor temp reading, and radio built in. I had the Alexa dot also next to my bed which I found I used more for music and radio as I don't get a great signal for radio in my basement for my local station. I had looked at the higher priced Alexa enabled clock radio that was out there last year but at $150 plus dollars didn't want to spend the money.

Along comes the Echo show 5 on Prime day for $49.99 and I thought I will give it a shot and see. I read some of the early reviews about how it had ads and people didn't like it for various reasons.

Upon opening the Echo Show 5 I found it to be the perfect size to not take up much space on my night stand yet was big enough to read without my glasses on. Setup was simple enough, plug it in and follow the prompts. It recognized my account and all i had to was enter the wifi account and password from the prompts on the screen. It did do a few updates after connecting to wifi that took a couple minutes and had a few tutorials it showed on the screen after.

My initial complaint was the screen was not bright enough and when I asked Alexa to brighten the screen she didn't understand. I figured out quickly though that the screen if you touch it has a way of dimming or brightening the screen easily.

The clock has many different settings for clock faces including a feature where you use your own pictures in the background.

With all Alexa devices it was as easy as saying "Alexa set alarm for 145 am" and when the alarm went off to say "Alexa shut alarm off." It shows the outside temp and with my recent purchase of a new wifi thermostat I can ask what the temp is in the house and set the temp up or down from the Alexa.

I also bought the Ring Pro doorbell which I have not had the time to set up yet but will update review when I connect it and use the show to view the camera.

Overall I'm wishing now that I had purchased a couple more of these for other rooms in the house to use at the Prime Day price.

I own the original Echo, a second gen. Echo Dot, a third gen. Echo Dot and a second gen. Echo Plus. I still use all of them, and they've all been worthwhile purchases. I just received the Echo Show 5, and it's really poorly executed in both hardware and software. Even though I bought it at the sale price on Prime Day, I'm pretty sure I'm going to return it. If I'd paid full price, it would definitely go back.

The screen has very poor viewing angles, which causes significant color shift if you're looking at it from partially off to the side. In addition, the screen seems to have poor backlight uniformity which causes a vignetting effect.

After executing a command, it takes way too long to return to the home screen. I discovered you can tell it to "go home" and it will go back to the home screen immediately, but this is an additional command that shouldn't be necessary. After I turn a light on or off, I would like it to return immediately to the clock display since I intended it to replace my alarm clock.

When I tell the Echo Show 5 to turn on a light (a Philips Hue bulb), it will show the intensity at 90 percent or less even though the light is at full brightness. Similarly, when the light is fully turned off, the intensity is shown as 10 percent or more. I've tried manually adjusting the percentage, hoping the device would learn the range of the bulbs, but that didn't work. And again, it takes way too long to return to the home screen.

The sound has a muffled quality and is subpar. This might be partially due to speaker placement. I didn't expect a miracle from an inexpensive small device, but I actually think my third gen. Echo Dot sounds better. Perhaps playing with the equalization might help somewhat.

As others have said, the constant suggestions from Amazon about what commands to try are annoying. I've played with various settings, but I can't get completely rid of them. I'm pretty familiar with Echo devices, and I don't need that taking up screen time.

After reading reviews of the Echo Show 5, I really expected something better. This is the first Echo device I've owned that's been a disappointment. I don't know whether the full size Echo Show has some of the same issues, but this experience has made me reluctant to try the larger size.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is my new alarm clock. Love it, but wish I had better control over the clock...
reviews.reviewText: I've been using my phone with a clock app to see what time it is at night, and also to use as an alarm clock. I wanted to have Alexa do this instead, so bought the Echo Show 5 to replace my phone. On a good note, it does the job, and more. On a bad note, I wish I had more control over the clock. Two problems: Yes, they have many clock faces to choose from, but the night mode is not the best - I have to turn up the light output to see the clock numbers (especially at dusk), but in so doing, the "black" background also turns up the light output, so I'm adding a lot more ambient light into the room at night, and I didn't really want that. I can turn down the light output, but at dusk, the red numbers on the screen (night mode) are barely visible. I wish the "black" background was really black vs. gray, and that I could increase the red numbers light output without also increasing the "black" background light. Either that, or just give me better control over the color of the night numbers (I'd be OK if they were just white - something with more contrast than red/gray. Hopefully, this is one of the fixes that they can do as Alexa improves - giving me more choices on the night mode contrast and light output so I can see the numbers but not add a lot of ambient light into the room. Problem #2: One other thing I'd like to see improved - the ability to set an alarm on one Echo device from another Echo devise. For example, I'd like an alarm to go off at 6 am in the bedroom, but my wife is already asleep, so I can't really go into the bedroom and speak to Alexa to set an alarm, because I would wake my wife up in the process of setting the alarm. Instead, I would like to be able to ask Alexa while in the kitchen to set an alarm in the bedroom... Wonder why they didn't already make that improvement... Otherwise, we love this - the alarm works well, and I can set routines as I need, as long as I am free to speak in the room before my wife has gone to bed...

I have one Echo and three Echo Dots in my home, so I figured I would buy this as an addition since it had a screen. I like that it is a small screen since I don't need anything huge. I mostly wanted this because of the clock since I don't have one visible to me in my bedroom and sits perfectly on my nightstand. The small footprint while having a decent screen is great.

So far it has been a nice upgrade and addition to my Echo device family. It works just as well as my other Echo devices, though I think the sound quality is slightly lower than my Echo Dots and lower than my Echo.

It was easy to set up and customize to my preferences. While I do agree that the "try this" messages that pop up on the screen are a little lame, it doesn't really bother me. I'm not constantly staring at the device, so it's sort of whatever. I realize it can be annoying for some people and there is a way you can (sort of) turn them off, though you can only turn off the constant rotation of them. Every time you interact with the device (waking it, when it detects movement or lighting changes, etc.) a "try this" message will still appear. I don't see the big deal with this as it doesn't impact the functionality of the device.

Overall, I'm really happy with this, but I don't feel I need more than one of them. It's a nice variation of the Echo devices and I'm glad I bought it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Needs work for use as a nightstand clock
reviews.reviewText:
Cons -
sound isn't as good as echo dot 3
It cannot hear you as well as an echo dot 3
Brightness controls are erratic or insufficient
Sunrise feature is half baked

Pros
You can see your ring video feeds
It can play videos
Looks nice in the room
Displays your photos

The echo show 5 is an OK device. I got it for $23 after an echo dot 2 trade in and that is about what it should be priced at $25-30.

As a nightstand clock it is not a great device. It's either too bright, or too dim, and the auto brightness and night mode features are either too aggressive, not aggressive enough or downright don't work. At night I have to lower the brightness to 0% then enable the additional night mode feature to turn it down further. At that point its at the brightness any nighttime led clock should be at. The problem is in the morning you can't see it at all when it's that dark. So you have to manually turn up the brightness. The auto settings are awful as explained above.

The sunrise alarm, where it lights up and gets progressively bright to gently wake you up is too aggressive as well. It starts off too early and is too bright. I wake up instantly 15 mins too early.

Each of these problems could be solved by allowing manual manipulation of brightness schedules as well as sunrise schedules and brightness. If I can tell my echo I want it to be at its lowest setting starting at 10pm but at this brightness at 9am that would be great.

If you could set the level of brightness for the sunrise feature and the time before your alarm that it starts it would be great.

As it stands if you want it as a nightstand device I wouldn't recommend it.

It also isn't as loud as the echo dot 3 nor can it hear you nearly as well. I can whisper to my echo dot 3. Sometimes I have to raise my voice for this to hear me.

Putting the speakers in the bottom was a curious decision as well. It muffled the sound. Why not the sides or the top?

reviews.reviewTitle: LOVE my Echos...The Echo Show 5 ... Not so much.
reviews.reviewText:
Let me start by saying I love my Echo devices! I have 2 full size Echos, 4 Echo Dots and a full size Echo Show Second Gen. I thought this little Echo Show 5 would be perfect for my studio, but alas, I decided to return it due to a few glitches. It does have good voice recognition and a great sound for such a small smart speaker. It played fine with my music.
There's a few reasons why I've decided to return it.
1. The screen gets REALLY hot! I've seen a few other reviewers say the same thing but this concerns me.
2. The size of the screen is a little smaller than I would like. I found it a little difficult to see across my workbench.
3. The most important reason is because it will just stop playing during my flash briefings. It does the same thing when I use the "Stream Player" app to watch the news. I know it isn't the fault of the app because it plays beautifully on my full size Echo Show. It will just stop right in the middle of something and return to the home screen. I can't get it to play for more than a few minutes before it just drops off.
I decided it was best to return it and wait for the full size Echo show to go on sale again. I think that would be a better fit for my studio. I feel terrible giving it a bad review, but hopefully they will be able to fix these problems in the future.

reviews.reviewTitle: Is this better than a normal Echo? Yes. But not a crazy amount.
reviews.reviewText:
I've had an Echo for a couple years now and use it primarily for home automation and music. Alexa isn't a smart assistant like Google (for instance, you can ask Google a ton more questions and get answers, or you can add "and" to string commands together, which Alexa can't do). Games are blah. What I wanted though was to be able to view my home video cameras from EZVIZ, which is supposed to work. It does. But slowly.

If you say, "Alexa, show me the garage." She will go to a loading screen for EZVIZ and then probably 20 seconds later you can see the garage. So, let's say that you hear a noise and want to see what happened. You won't be able to. You would be better off going to see the noise yourself. This has to be updated. I thought this was an issue with my old devices (you can do this on Fire TV stick) but even this new version of the Echo takes a while. Plus you have to unencrypt the video to get it to show on this. Yuck.

What else is this good for? Showing a clock for one. Seeing some of the lyrics for music you are listening to. But overall, not a crazy improvement over a normal Echo.

What made this worthwhile for me was the price on Prime Day. $50 is a pretty good price for a cheap Echo. I got two and use them as alarms in my kids rooms. They have physical buttons to block the cameras as well as the button to turn off listening (which I hope actually works). You can say, "Alexa wake me up at ..." and you can use music or have two alarms. Whatever. This is actually something worthwhile for my kids. It also plays music for them to go to sleep (including white noise.)

So it's not revolutionary. It does work great with all my smarthome stuff. It's limited. But at this price it was worth it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great little device people are just too picky and expecting too much!
reviews.reviewText:
People are expecting WAY TOO MUCH now a days. This little device is great. Does it show you ads like how to cook meatloaf and say “Alexa tell me about prince Harry” yes but it also shows the time, current weather, temperatures, and if you have an alarm set shows the alarm. It has my background picture saved. Also has a dimmer/screen saver type thing to where when room is dark so is it. There’s a whisper mode, and she controls everything just like the other devices. Now sometimes do I ask her to
Turn off my lamp and she says she doesn’t understand what I’m looking for yes but come on I simply ask again and she does it OR I roll over and do it myself lol. It’s a 5 inch screen so if you’re expecting 3D movie theater quality then I’m sorry you’re going to be disappointed but video calls work fine and I “drop in” on my sons rooms and my kitchen all the time and can see and hear both rooms just fine. Honestly it’s way better than the $250 baby monitors I have (yes I still have the monitors up kids are 7 and 3 and Alexa doesn’t alert me to them moving or something happening in their rooms over night😁). Mostly this little device is great. Plays games perfectly, can read lyrics with no problem (I’m 34 with LASIK done 2 years ago so can’t speak for anyone with poor vision lol). Her alarm is loud and wakes me up every morning with no problem and best of all she takes up less real estate on my shelf than the echo show I had in there which is twice the size (I love it too just big for where I had it). So this little gal is great if you’re not expecting it to everything NASA does on a 5 inch screen.

Sounds like this device was dropped into a box of tissues, and closed the lid. Yes, I turned the Bass and Mid-range all the way off, and the Treble all the way up. It made no difference at all. I wonder if the speaker has glue or a seal on it as a defect.

I prepaid for this device and received in on the first day. Sadly, I was not able to review it in the first couple weeks! Here it is PRIME day for roughly half of what I paid a month ago.

This is potentially a terrific device. I am giving it only 3 stars for these reasons:

1. Background photos: The Show lets users select their own photos as Background, with the photos rotating. Users can also specify how many seconds each photo is displayed on the screen. The problem is the timing process works only for slideshows (when the user says "Alexa, start a slideshow ..."). It does NOT work for background photos. With background photos, each photo displays for several minutes, which is much too long. There is no way to change this timing.

2. Slideshow photos: For privacy reasons, I keep the microphone turned off most of the time. But this causes a red bar to be displayed on the bottom of the screen, even when a slideshow is being displayed. The red bar ruins the slideshow. The red color clashes with my photos, and also takes up some of the already limited space. The only way to get rid of the red bar is to turn the microphone on.

So this is the dilemma: Keep my privacy but ruin my slideshows. Or have nice slideshows while also letting Amazon hear everything that goes on in my house.

I want to point out that the red bar is completely unnecessary. When the microphone is off, there is ALSO a red light displayed on top of the device. Users do not need both of these indicators. The red light is more than adequate for communicating microphone status. There is no need to ruin slideshows.

I -LOVE- the Echo platform. Compared to its closest rival (Google Home), Alexa seems "friendlier" (possibly because of the wake word) and the app is a lot simpler.

I ordered three of Echo 5's because they're the PERFECT size for a desk, night stand or something to sit beside the couch. I also have an older Echo Show and the newest Echo Show. I wanted all of my Echoes to have screens so no matter where I am in the house, I can (theoretically) stream a security camera to it if necessary.

The biggest problem with the platform is that the ESP is just plain awful. ESP is the feature that has the closest Echo respond to your voice. That's the theory, anyway. Reality works differently. I'll talk to the Echo in my living room and the one in the kitchen responds. I'll talk to the Echo in the kitchen and the one twenty feet down the hall will respond.
That's only mildly amusing if I'm just adding something to my grocery list. It's extremely frustrating if I'm trying to turn off an alarm, set a timer or view a security camera. It's not amusing when I'm asking the Echo two feet away to show me the porch camera and the Echo far away in another room streams it instead.

The cause of the issue isn't having too many Echoes. I also have multiple Google Homes and they've never had this issue. I don't have an open floor plan and there are a lot of walls separating each Echo. The Echo's ESP detection just isn't very good.

If it weren't for the Echo's complete lack of ability to recognize when I'm two feet away and respond accordingly, this would rate a solid five stars. However, since the Echo twenty feet away and in another part of the house routinely responds to my commands, I have to give it two out of five stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor sound quality, voice recognition issues & limited screen make it less useful
reviews.reviewText:
Last year I received an Echo Spot as a gift to use on my nightstand and I really liked the addition of Alexa to my bedroom. I've been adding a variety of smart plugs all over my home and the ability to control lights by voice has really sold me on making this part of my home's infrastructure. My only complaints about the Spot were the screen is a bit too small to use for video playback (whether streaming or looking at the feed from my security camera), as well as read the time when I have my glasses off at night. The Show seemed like a great upgrade to get a bigger screen without sacrificing much more of my nightstand counter space.
So, I setup the Show and at first I thought it was a good fit. Got it on my home WiFi without a hitch and it integrated right in with all my Echo devices. After a few days of use issues with the Show 5 became apparent, however.

1. The viewing angle of the screen Amazon designed the Show 5 with is somewhat limited. When angled directly at me I could see it pretty well, but is I moved too far left, right or up the picture drops off in quality rather quickly. I would have it turned toward my head while slept so I could see the time at night when I woke, but when I got up I would have to turn it so I could read it at all, then remember to turn it back the following evening. While standing it was somewhat of a lost cause, but it made me realize while there are so many third party adjustable stands for the unit.
2. The mics for the voice recognition just did not seem as responsive as the Spot's. From just on the other side of my bed it had problems picking up voice commands spoken in a regular tone of voice, causing us to have to shout at it just to recognize commands, on more than a few occasions.
3. The sound quality of the Show 5 is very bass heavy, which might be fine for music, but made it difficult to understand when I listened to speech, like the news. I adjusted the EQ in the settings and ended up turning the bass all the way down, which helped, but never made speech quite as clear as on my Spot. Right before giving up on the Show 5 the audio from music playback even started to get crackly and garbled. Not unlistenable, but obviously of poorer quality.

So, it was a failed experiment. The form factor of the Show 5 is certainly appealing. Size is good and the control work well. I appreciate the ability to close a shutter over the camera, especially. Still, it needs a revision. I've seen wireless speakers with much better sound playback quality and I know better LCD screens can be had to provide a better picture. Please, Amazon, try to make improvements to a Show 5.1 model and I will definitely give this another go!
Until then, both Show 5s my household bought have been returned to you.

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazon needs to tell the truth!!
reviews.reviewText: I bought this device specifically to video call with my grandmother. She lives alone in Virginia and I live in California. I even had internet installed at her house just for the use of the echo show 5. All advertisements say you can Skype or video chat. FALSE! I called Amazon "customer service" the first time and after being on the phone for over an hour, trying a million different things, I was told I needed to buy another Amazon echo show to be able to two-way video call. I told him that was deceitful because the commercials and the box says Skype and easy video calls. But, I believed that guy and spent another $90 buying myself a show 5. I'm not rich but I love my grandmother. Anyway, today after I set up my device and made the call to my granny it still didn't work! No video for me to see. I had her try everything I knew before I called Amazon "customer service" again. So, I called and after 45 minutes on the phone with some women named Claudia I'm still not able to video with my grandmother! Claudia had me factory reset my echo that I literally took out of the box and connected less than 30 minutes prior. She was not helpful at all. I told her at least 4X it was my Grandmother but she still kept referring to her as my mother. I explained the whole story at the beginning of the call about us being cross country but this woman obviously didn't care enough to remember that fact. She was unable to fix the problem so I now have $200 worth of echo show devices plus I signed a year long contract for internet service that's not going to be used and I STILL CAN NOT VIDEO WITH MY GRANDMOTHER! Amazon lies! Horrible Terrible Awful "customer service" I want all my money and time wanted back! *NOWHERE ON THE PACKAGE OR COMMERCIAL DOES IT SAY YOU MUST HAVE A SMART PHONE TO ACCESS THESE VIDEO FEATURES!! WHAT A LIE AMAZON! SHAME ON YOU

reviews.reviewTitle: It works as expected, has a nice screen, listens pretty good.
reviews.reviewText: I have a 1st Gen Echo & some 1st & 2nd gen Dots around the house. This is my first Echo Show. I feel that generally the Gen 5 Show does a better job at actually listening and understanding what I am saying. The screen is bright, crisp, and responsive. One of the reasons I wanted it was so I could monitor my security cameras (Nest integrated) and that works - but it times out after a while, which is annoying, but understandable. The things that disappointed me... turning off some of the more annoying default features like "Trending Topics" were not necessarily easy to find, and even thuogh I did successfully get "Discover with Alexa" turned off - she still persistently flashes "Try blah blah blah" up on the screen... which - I could really do without.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Screen, Easy Setup -- Might Have Found a Bug w/ Blink XT2 Cameras Though...
reviews.reviewText:
I snagged this pre-sale, mainly because I wanted a larger screen in the master bedroom, so I could view my front yard + front door cameras. I already had an Echo Spot in-place, so that's there for comparison.

Really, no issues whatsoever @ setup, usage, etc. All are done really well and it was a breeze getting the device onlin.

THE ONLY ISSUE I've found thus far is, I have multiple Blink XT AND XT2 cameras -- note the difference between XT and XT2.

On my Spot, I can ask Alexa to show me the Front Door camera -- which is an XT2 camera w/ audio streaming -- and it proceeds to show me the camera in an expected amount of time (showing 'Buffering...' for a second or two, while it connects).

On the Show though, it NEVER shows me the Front Door XT2 camera -- it never gets to the 'Buffering...' screen my Spot gets to, prior to displaying the camera feed.

This is unique behavior vs. my original XT cameras, which do NOT stream audio. With these, on either my Spot or Show, it shows me the camera stream within a few seconds, no 'Buffering...' on either device.

So there appears to be something *unique* about the Echo Show and the Blink XT2 cameras. It's not a deal-breaker and Amazon's history has shown that issues like this, tend to get noticed and addressed pretty quickly. If I haven't seen an update/fix to this after a month or so, I'll report back.

Other than that, it's well-worth it for the screen size.

My Use - I purchased this for work. My hopes are to use this for CBS all access during football season! Working in IT I work a lot on Sunday and yes, I have plenty of screen space on my computer but they are being used for work related task. This device fits under my screen perfectly! Not only will it allow me to do what my main plans are, I can use it for music while working, my calendar, and other business related task!

Pros
1.) Good screen for the size. It's bright and vibrant. It's clear! I like the screen

2.) Size - I don't have room for a huge show or even a tablet on my desk so the size here is perfect

3.) Decent Speaker - Speaker is fine for an office environment. It's not like I'm jamming out!

4.) Leaves phone for other task. No need to use my phone for music or TV and so on

5.) Easy setup

6.) Price! - Cheaper than buying an iPod touch or something. That was my second option!

Cons
1.) I wish you could do more through the touchscreen vs having to talk to it. Talking to it isn't bad but being able to select apps on the touchscreen would be better in some situations

2.) Amazon Channels doesn't work so that means as of now CBS All Access won't work. Bummer

Overall - For my use, I'm very happy with this. It works great and hopefully CBS all access will have football again this season but if not, oh well, I still enjoy it!

EDIT: Amazon Channels doesn't work on this device so no CBS all access and fire recast doesn't work unless on the same network. Still a great device and enjoying it!!!

I purchased this show5 for my kitchen, I already had a dot but wanted to get a screen for timers and recipes. The biggest issue is that it doesn’t connect to the Amazon Basic microwave. Yet why still give it 5 stars? The answer is that I have such confidence in Amazon that I’m sure this will be resolved soon. Obviously if you want fuller sound and a larger screen get the bigger unit. I have some kind of Echo unit in every room of my home, I think I use the kitchen unit the most. My stove timer is completely antiquated because of the echoes, spelling words, recipes, asking the time, turning on lights how did we live before?

A few days later the microwave now works with is Echo. You have to admit no grass grows under their feet.

reviews.reviewTitle: These will make the echo speakers obsolete in some cases
reviews.reviewText:
For certain use cases like bedroom night stand or a home office these are really a step up from the regular echo speakers. Especially if like me you have a smart home with connected devices like blink or wyze cameras or an adt security system. The price is more affordable than the full echo show and the sound quality is really good. I am an early echo device adopter and already had several echo speaker devices but this echo show 5 displaced some of them. I bought two echo show 5's with one of them replacing a first gen echo speaker in my bedroom and the other displacing a second gen echo dot in my home office. For other areas of my home I dont spend enough time there so an echo speaker device is fine. I didn't feel the need to buy the 20$ adjustable stand

If you have blink or wyze cameras, with a little knowledge of adding alexa skills, you can just tell it, "alexa show my patio camera" and it will display on the echo show. Very cool. The display is adequate and about the size of a modern day smartphone. The 230$ for the full echo show seemed too expensive for me so Im glad they introduced this less expensive alternative. I'm not sure what ads other reviewers are complaining about. So far I have not seen them. Just alexa suggestions in the the lower part of the screen when the device isn't doing anything. They are not obtrusive and can be easily ignored if you chose to. These are usually the "you can ask alexa to do this" type of things and they don't bother me

reviews.reviewTitle: Has it’s use in small space for someone with great vision
reviews.reviewText:
We have two of each Echo Shows gen 1 & 2. The 2 is hands down my favorite echo device! I’m definitely more of a visual person. We have the Google home hub and imo doesn’t have much on the Shows (not even a camera...really?) except for the smart home control. The Show has made some strides in that direction with this but not much. Heavily lacking and disappointing interface for people with a lot of devices to control. A person, Frank, on an amazon forum pointed out the accessibility option which I actually find more useful for my mom and others wanting simple touch control without drilling down three or four menus and scrolling.

So the 5...hmm. I watched some online video reviews before purchasing and thought “wow, his hands are large”. I used the view this in your room feature see photo and after receiving the actual product realize that was way off! I’ve attached actual photos with iPhone 8Plus and XR alongside the 1st and second gen Shows.

My final thought on size...I thought it would be bigger. That’s what she said! Sorry, couldn’t resist a chance to reference the Office. It kind of reminds me of being a kid and ordering Sea Monkeys from the back of a comic book. Waiting on the mail carrier in heavy anticipation every day, finally getting the package, opening it and thinking this it it?! I spent my allowance on this.

The good news...super small footprint so perfect for a small space if you have really great vision. The sound is surprisingly good for the size!

I’m fun sized for a human so normally I subscribe to the thought good things can come in small packages. This definitely suits a small space. Plus, the screen is optimized for video content versus the black bars you get on the sides of the others.

If you’re one of the lucky ones who got in on the slick deal for this...you will be happy. I didn’t and am a little bummed my Whole Foods coupon got applied to this instead of my router because I’m still contemplating at the prime day price. I feel the fifty I dropped for another first gen on woot was a better deal. Albeit the footprint on that device is so much larger which bothers me too because why. I was lucky enough to pick up both gen 2s at a Benjamin each which I feel well worth it! Sound amazing, small footprint and great screen. Can’t beat that 2nd gen Echo Show in my mind.

reviews.reviewTitle: I want to love this, but it's just so bad.
reviews.reviewText:
It's perfect size and form factor for a desk or night stand, it's too bad that it's just a bad device. Horribly lagging when trying to use touch, freezes and reboots itself regularly. When you turn the screen off (night stand device, so every night in my case) the audio get's distorted, this happens on every one of min and a factory reset only provides a temporary fix and getting a replacement unit develops the same issue. The Ads. Holy... the ads. And they are just so stupid too. No alexa, I don't need help making freaking popcorn, I don't need ads on how to make popcorn. Multi room audio seems like it can't keep up with the other echo devices, constantly just stops playing on my echo show 5s while other echos are able to continue playing. Wish I could give this a 0 star.

Update: Amazon spam called me because of a bad review, score down to a -1 from that. Then I let them replace both of my defective units, and the new ones came with the issues the returned ones had, 5 out 5, this is just a bad product, -2 stars out of 5.

reviews.reviewTitle: The microphone is garbage. Even at 2 feet away.
reviews.reviewText:
Cute how amazon does the ratings; I can’t just give it 2 stars, I have to rate 3 different categories and one is “Alexa Integration.” It’s an Alexa device. That’s like asking me if my Tesla works well with the Tesla UI.

I digress. We bought this for the bedside so we could control our smart home lighting (SmartThings) and check in on our security cams (Ring). I was hopeful I could watch Hulu/Netflix on it as I fall asleep (I do that with my phone on a cradle currently so I don’t disturb my wife with the TV).

Smarthome: It works as well as any other Alexa. There is a response lag but after 5 years we are used to it. It should let me change the home screen to on/off and slide controls for my lighting. The cool picture and retro clock is neat but with a device that can do so much they’ve really limited the home screen.

Ring Cameras: Maybe a little faster than the Firetv sticks and cubes we use. Works well.

Hulu/Netflix- not available. Should
Be. It’s capable of it. Dumb.

So why 2 stars? Because the key component to any voice assistant is it’s ability to hear you. The microphone(s) in this thing are terrible. My firetv Cube, dots, and full latest generation echos all have great microphones. This thing is terrible. It’s 18” away from my head and I have to turn my head and look at
It for it to respond. My wife, who is 3’ away from it in a quiet room on the other side of the bed has no shot of activating it.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'd rather have my dot back.
reviews.reviewText:
I decided to purchase the Echo show 5 because of a deal that involved sending amazon back a working echo dot, and upgrading to the new echo show 5 at a fairly steep discount... essentially half price. My plan was to move my Echo Show (original) from the BR to the office, and place the new show 5 in the BR. The GF doesn't like the cameras on the echo devices, so the physical shutter is a big selling point (for her). This change involved a complex plan to shuffle around the majority of my devices (the device being sent back came from the laundry room) so that, in theory, every device was getting an upgrade.

Unfortunately, the plan fell apart as soon as I heard the echo show playing audible. It's terrible. Nothing but reverb due to the size and orientation of the speaker. I can't fall asleep listening to that!... and thus, we return to the initial premise. My echo dot gen 2 might have been junk, but it wasn't hurting anybody(in the laundry room), and I only paid $20 for it (plus another 10 for a plug-mount enclosure.) Now, I'm out nearly $50, and considering swapping the echo show 5 with an echo dot gen 3 which I swear has better sound...

I don't use the touchscreen that much anyway... grumble, grumble... facepalm.

I have been waiting on this...I wanted a small smartclock to sit on my nightstand to:

.show me the time
.play music with my other echos
.show my camera's (ring)feed
.physical camera shutter (don't want tape)

This guy does it all. I originally wanted a echo spot, but it was a little too small and the camera didn't have a shutter. That and the sound quality was not all that great. The Show 5 is perfect in size, the ambient light sensor is great and it supports the near field recognition so it plays well with other Echos in the same room. And to top it all off, the speaker sound quality is great! Glad they included physical buttons for volume as well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes a nice smart alarm clock with one drawback
reviews.reviewText:
Recently added this to my Echo collection. I used it to replace the Spot on my bedside table. For this use, I think the Show 5 is better than the spot, but in part that is because the display is larger and I don't need my glasses for it. Otherwise, it works pretty much like the Spot. It also works like my Show 2, only smaller and therefore cuter. I can't really comment on the sound, since I have only used the alarm sounds so far, but that (and her voice) are "boomier" than the Spot's.

My biggest disappointment in using it as an alarm clock, is the the lack of ability to set it for different times on different days. I am off on Fridays, and have an early meeting on Thursdays, and there is no easy way to account for that. Even one of my cheap smart plugs has the ability to specify days of the week. (To be clear, I can specify all weekdays on the Show, just not Monday thru Wednesday or just Thursday). It seems like this should be fairly easy to implement, and in that case it would change my rating.

I will admit that I got this during Prime Days, for a much better than list price. I'm not sure it'd be worth the current list price, but I'd actually consider getting another one if the price drops again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Despite it's small size, it packs a punch!
reviews.reviewText:
I've been a long user of Alexa products, from the original bluetooth speaker (ECHO), to having about 8 Dots around the house and a Spot as an alarm clock. I didn't like the form of the Show, but this Echo Show 5 is just the perfect size for what I need in my media room. And it's working so well, I am thinking about going through and changing our some of my Dot's for more of the Show 5's. I like it that much. The sound is nice and warm from it, with a nice thump at low volumes. Take the volume too high and the bass dissipates and you end up with something a little more tinny sounding.

However, the screen is intuitive and easy on the eyes. I have it set to blend in with the countertop that it's on, so it's really unobtrusive. Really like the design of this one, it makes a lot more sense to me. Although the slider for the camera on it cheapens it a little for me. It's not quite as elegant as I would have expected, especially from the quality of the earliest Amazon Alexa products, the slide switch is a bit plasticy, and not extremely aesthetic when the camera is covered up.

Voice integration with all of my Alexa enabled ecosystem is perfect, the voice field, even with movies blaring in the room is exceptional, and overall I'm really happy with my Show 5.

I've only had my Echo Show 5 for a few days but I'm really enjoying it. I have not gotten into everything it can do but eventually I will. I used to use my cellphone for my alarm and my iHome/ iPod to listen to my audio books. My iPod had gotten old and ragged. The bottom of the screen somehow split open and the home key fell out, so getting an audio book to play was a bit of a hassle. Now, all I do is tell Alexa to show me my audio books and they pop right up. This little gadget has replaced both of those devices. I can get the weather before I leave. It's just so much more convenient to be able to say a command and have Alexa do it versus physically grabbing a device and finding it yourself. I think the display screen is a nice size, especially for a bedroom. You have different options to customize it with different backgrounds and colors and what clock you want (analog/digital) and so on.
So far I really like my Echo.

Update: 09/15/19 - I still haven’t gotten into everything it can do but one problem I’ve noticed is it takes a couple of tries to get audiobooks to play. I love for my audiobooks to put me to sleep and for some reason it takes a couple of tries to get them started. If I tell Alexa the name of the book to play the book will pop up but she will say “Sorry, I’m having trouble playing that right now.” Not sure why. It takes a couple of tries but eventually it will play.

So far, this is a great addition to the house. The reason gave it 2 stars is Alexa's voice. It has great sound when playing music, etc. but when Alexa responds, her voice is very base and muffled and hard to hear. I replaced an Echo Dot and noticed right away that the voice recognition isn't as good...

Other than those 2 things, I would give it 5 stars. I imagine they will be working out those 2 bugs.

EDIT:
After leaving the review, Amazon development team contacted me withing minutes to get further information to improve their product. Amazon has some amazing customer service. I have absolutely no doubt they will resolve the minor issues soon. Don't hesitate to purchase one of these voice enabled devices.

reviews.reviewTitle: This little screen is very helpful
reviews.reviewText: I love my Echo Show because it allos me to ask Alexa to show me the front door when someone Rings my doorbell, It also displays the date and time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Mic pickup is poor, no YouTube, and features worth using forces surrender of privacy.
reviews.reviewText:
So we own 5 echo devices. Echo Original, Echo dot 1st gen, 2 echo dot 2nd gen, Echo Cube and finally, the Echo show 5. I can conclusively say this has the worst mic pickup out of all of them.

As far as features go, being able to set a photo as the background is nice. I setup a slideshow but in order to do so, I had to upload photos to Amazon's cloud. To do this you have to give Amazon permission to access your camera and there was something disturbing about seeing thumbnails of all my photos on the Amazon website before I even selected which ones to upload. This "feature" felt like a way for Amazon to make an access grab to personal images on your phone.

The fact it can't play YouTube basically turns it into a glorified digital clock. The only thing I found the screen useful for is when I asked for how to say something in another language and the Echo show actually displayed the words on the screen.

The speaker is okay, I give it 3/5. It is not as good as the original echo.

All in all, I got this in Prime day for 50$. Unfortunately, without YouTube, an Alexa with a screen is and incredibly tough sell as it locks you out of practically every tutorial/cooking/streaming video there is.

Subjectively stated, an echo with a screen is a silly purchase due to limited features and the sacrifice you have to make (privacy wise) to use them. An echo without a screen will serve you just as faithfully.

I recently bough this item, and it didn't work properly. The screen was frozen when trying to watch a video, the audio was defective too, and Alexa didn't follow commands. Amazon didn't offer a replacement or help to fix the defective new Echo Show 5, eventhough I'm an Amazon Prime member. They only offered me a refund, instead of trying to fix the problem. I never had that experience with their customer service before...

I love Amazon echo devices but this is a very early stage echo show. I love how it can play you tube (if you set it up right) and I love how I can connect to to me wifi security camera. The speaker is fantastic and I love the touch screen. Also its great that the lyrics show during most amazon music songs.

The issues I had are, first, it feels hot all the time for some reason, the "show front door" skill for camera lags when starting as well as droping in from cell phone. If you dont use a wifi camera like ring, or WYZE I feel its pointless.

Feels pricey for what it can actually do but I bought it for my wife for her birthday and she does like it.

Also important to note. The echo show and the newest echo dot can not be places in an enclosed area like a kitchen counter with cabinets on top. It does muffle the sound and the music terribly. Moving it to the edge of the counter away from the wall with over head cabinets helps the sound quality 100%.

I also wish the weather would have more options when sliding through the main screen, right now its just a little icon on the first page, I with it scrolled through weather like the echo spot. Also I wish the design would look a little more modern instead of a clunky looking alarm clock.

Overall we do like it but I feel it has a long way to go still and hopefully gets major updates.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love my Shows. We now have one Show 5 and 3 original Shows.
reviews.reviewText: I bought the Show 5 before I got a great deal on 3 of the original shows. I love them both. I had an Echo Plus to use for a hub, but I watered a plant on the windowsill one day and flooded the Plus and ruined it. I had to change all the bulbs around the house because none of them would work without the hub. I was disappointed that the 5 wasn't a hub. But now I have my originals and our lights are working again. My Echo addiction now has an echo in every room of our three story house and a bunch of useless dots gathering dust. Every year with how cheap these devices get I find myself upgrading to newer ones and retiring the old ones. I put one of the original Shows in the kitchen and moved this one to my room, it's great as an alarm clock and all I have to do is tell Alexa to shut off the screen and it goes dark. I wear glasses and can never see a clock without them, so I love being able to ask "what time it is" in the middle of the night. I use it as a visual intercom and for reading audible books, weather, news, music, white noise (fan sounds) and everything I use my Echo's for but this one has a screen and a camera that you can shut down with the slide of a button.

I just purchased and set up two of the new Echo Show 5 models. One for my primary residence and one for our second home. I purchased them on Prime Day and got two for the price of one. I set both of them up on the nightstand next to the bed by replacing the alarm clocks there were at those locations previously. They make a great alarm clock replacement. You can set a variety of alarms and even have the option of repeating each alarm daily, only on weekdays, or not at all. This works especially well for me since I routinely forget to turn the alarm off on weekends and get rudely awaken early on Saturday mornings. The screen on both are a nice addition to the regular Echo Dot that it replaced. Now when I play something on Amazon Music, the screen actually displays the lyrics. Also, the display shows a number of things and even gives hints on things that you can ask Echo or have it show you. The only drawback to me is the sound quality of the speakers. I purchased the latest Echo Dot and the speakers on it seem to have a slightly fuller sound. However, one of the great things about the new Echo Show 5 is that you can turn off the camera and also mute the microphone if you're concerned about having your device hacked and someone taking pics or audio of you in your bedroom. However, if you need to, you can unblock the camera and audio and use it to do video calls with family members who also have some type of Echo Show. All told, this was a nice upgrade to the four Echo Dots that I had previously purchased.

reviews.reviewTitle: Same Alexa and very good sound + video in a compact size
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this Echo5 to add to one of my bedrooms, I Already own Spot, Echo, Show, Sub, Tap, & Fire Cube so very familiar with its operation. I love the size and the screen, very clear and matches the Shows clarity. Screen is large enough for viewing short videos but would not try to watch a movie. The sound is very good, better than Spot 1st edit, nice lows and mids freq. The sound matches the show but not better than Echo. easy to uselike all the Alexa devices. I noticed that some times it does not hear me and have to repeat. I went through voice training several times but just does not hear well but not a show stopper. it still functions well. I would buy again but if I wanted a better/larger video Ibstill prefer the Show. still, very good product and price especially if you want video snd audio.
ADDED SECOND REVIEW: After a month of using Echo 5 I find it is just Ok, good price for what is does. I will call it the economy model. It has some quirks, especially understanding my requests or questions. I prefer my show (2nd edition). It picks up better when further away and generalky understands my voice. If I were to buy another, the larger Show is my preference. Again, not bad but Im spoiled by the Show.

I wonder if I just happened to get a lemon, considering all the high ratings. No one would rate the device I got 4 or 5 stars. I'm only giving it 2 stars because I got it on prime day with a trade up discount.

Sound quality is absolutely abysmal. Even around halfway up it crackles and has a static sound like the speaker is blown out. It's slightly worse than the first gen echo dot.
Voice recognition is also bad. I've owned a first gen echo, first gen echo show, several echo dots, and an echo auto. My rating of 2 stars for voice recognition is assuming those others are 5 stars. I've never had much trouble with Alexa before (obviously or I wouldn't keep buying them) but with the show 5 I have to make my requests about 3 times on average.
Video is fine. It's a phone sized screen that will never be as close as my phone and I'm not trying to watch the battle of winterfell in 4k so I'm not so worried about detail. It's more of a clock than a TV and the video is plenty good for that.

So I hope others have better luck than I did, because for me this was a definite step backwards as far as sound quality and voice recognition both

We purchased the Echo Show 5 for our dad for Father’s Day. We already had the first generation Echo Show which we love, but seeing how compact the new Echo Show 5 was and many of the new features like being able to turn the camera off and the microphone, it’s so compact, but nice we purchased two more for our home. We now have one in the living room, and both bedrooms! It’s nice when we are working or away we can use the drop in feature to check on things at home. It’s an added layer of security and money well spent!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great upgrade to a Echo spot (If you desire the bigger screen)
reviews.reviewText:
Comparing this to an Echo Spot is probably not the best comparison, because there are better reasons for deciding on one over the other. If we look at these two units from a feature stand point they are identical. There are a few things that the Show 5 does better than the Spot in my opinion and they are:

1 - Better sound
2 - Better privacy mode (Camera lens cover) / Easy to see indicator of active / inactive
3 - Larger screen.

Do you plan on watching videos (or looking at device cameras) but also want great sound? (Go with the Show 5)
If you are confined on space but still want the same features the spot is great!. (not a disappointing second option at all)

I Feel, It really comes down to preference, or application, more than what is better. Spot and Show (5) are both very good units. I personally find the sound better on the show 5 (mini) and the camera privacy feature seems to be more thought out and obviously screen size. Which is why i sided with the show.

And with Amazon Prime day its is a great time to stock up on both. I have around 12 units (Yes at least 1 or more of each item that Amazon makes) and they all have a place in our home somewhere or another. Spots and Shows are great options and if you could get both i would recommend doing so.

The above ad copy for this device says, "Check weather and traffic as you head out in your new city." It says this as it refers to the screen, I believe.

To me, that implies maps, such as Google Maps, AccuWeather, or their competitors.

You get no maps.

Why put a screen on this and then fail to show maps?!

The estimate of how long your commute will take fails to consider road construction, or (I'm guessing for these next two) accidents or flooding. So it's WAY off if there's construction, etc., even if it's occurring at a regular time for the last 3 weeks, and already happening when you ask.

It's ability to do anything is very basic. For example, you can't ask it to turn on lights for 3 minutes. You can't get it to turn lights to anything but the most basic colors (like a box of 8 crayons). If you ask anything even *slightly* complex, it will misunderstand and either do something else, or tell you it can't do that yet.

The skills are just as simple, or at least the ones I've found.

This system has potential, but it's unfulfilled.

Maybe a later version will be worth getting?

I am really disappointed in this purchase. Such hype for an item that almost seems useless. The only thing I have seen on the Show, is the time and weather, nothing else. Tried everything, but to no avail.Re-connect, restart, reboot, change networks, until I could scream!!! If I can't get it to work by the end of the week, back it goes, along with the other extra Echos and shows I bought. Sorry! Can't give a good review if you can't base it on anything viable!

The Echo Show 5 has some useful and enjoyable features, well publicized so I won't restate them here. The features work as advertised. Sound is surprisingly decent from the Echo's own very small speaker. The screen is bright, sharp and nice to have. Two things about the Echo Show 5, although not deal breakers, could stand improvement. First, streaming sound to an external speaker via Bluetooth cuts the Echo Show's own speaker off. I would prefer that the Echo's own speaker would continue to work. Second, the Alexa app updated today. Despite the fact I have a new higher-speed modem and high-speed Internet, the download and install progressed at the speed of grass growing in a near-desert area. The app varies in size up to a whopping 95-plus megabytes, and I suspect my Kindle had to ingest the whopper. While I haven't done anything but finally get past the download ordeal with the newest version, my past experience with the app is that it can be painfully sluggish, depending to some extent on what you're trying to do with it. Plenty of room for improvement there, both in slenderizing and speeding up. Please.

The Echo Show 5 was worth trying with the Prime Day discount. All I have to say is WOW. Easy to set up and use, with all the Alexa features, better sound out of the box than expected, and working well as a very nice clock radio/alarm clock. You can even watch Prime Video on the little screen. I'm a week into ownership and am using it more than expected. Amazon is winning in the smart home category - love the Amazon ecosystem and this Echo Show 5 is a worthy addition.
The echo show was great until an update came out that doesn't allow you to leave the clock up on the screen.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect as a bedside Alexa device!
reviews.reviewText:
This is my 3rd Echo/Alexa device to purchase and I actually bought due to a trade-in deal on Prime Day. Otherwise, I wouldn't have tried this out - SO glad I did! This little device is my new favorite bedside tech. Better than any other alarm clock/radio/whatever!

First - with the new "routines" for Alexa, I can program it so that when I wake up and say "Good Morning" my lights come on, my tv turns on (thanks to Amazon Fire TV Cube), and the Echo Show will actually show/tell me the weather forecast for the day. I can also say "Good Night" from my bed and the Echo Show follows a similar routine and turns off all my lights and devices, but turns on my porch light. Those 2 life hacks are ALONE worth purchasing this!

Second - as opposed to the original Echo devices, this has a small screen (hence the "show" name). In the background, it displays my pics from Amazon Photos so it basically acts as a digital photo frame as well as all it's other functions.

Third - I didn't rate the Motion Detection because I have the low tech cover switch always on meaning I don't allow the camera to see anything. This is just my own personal choice, knowing those cameras can be hacked and you never know who's looking in on you (yes, I'm paranoid) I just keep the camera covered - and I love that I don't have to use tape or something like that, the device comes with it's own little camera cover switch (not tech, just a simple physical cover you move back and forth with your finger.

Overall, if you love your other Echo devices, you'll love this one just as much if not more. Take advantage of the "echo trade in program" if you get the chance and get the rebate money to apply towards a new Echo Show 5. You won't be disappointed!

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it but could use a clip
reviews.reviewText:
We have this device in the kitchen and it is amazing. At first I thought it would be too small but it is actually the perfect size for the kitchen counter. It is easy to move out of the way and you can always ping it for questions.

I also enjoy the fact that it works flawlessly with your Ring doorbell to see who is at the door AND with our Blink cameras to see who is on our property. Just make sure you have the devices names differently.

The only thing I would ask for is that it had some kind of clip or magnet to clip it underneath the cabinets when we are working on a meal and have the counter top full of ingredients and appliances.

Let me start by saying I am. A huge Amazon/Alexa fan. Between myself and my daughter (2 households) we own 4 dots (3gen 2s one children's). We both owned the Alexa echo 1st. Gen.  She has an echo show, and I just bought this echo show5.   I got a great deal on it on prime day (Yay Amazon)... Part of that deal was trading in my original echo(gen1)... I could kick myself for doing that. I want my original back!!! My husband and I spend most of our time in living room and figured we'd like to go with a screened echo. It's not a big room (10x15) our gen1 worked great. It sat in a corner and responded to our command's fine.  It filled the room nicely with music. (We're older so don't like it too loud) The 'new'show5 sits on our fireplace in the middle of the room.  I think it's hard of hearing! It constantly gets our command's wrong.  My shopping list can be atrocious; often times I have no idea what Alexa heard so my list is garbled and I end up guessing what it is I told her. The camera is useless unless I stand right in front of it. It points at the upper part of wall and ceiling. (Fireplace height is about 4 ft.) It can't be adjusted so I bought a stand, which is pretty useless to.  Stand only leans slightly forward and back(great veiw of ceiling)  I was hoping to be able to drop in on dogs.  No luck.

I think this particular model should be advertised as a bedside unit.  It might be the only use it's good for! 

In the future I will not be trying out any new "upgraded" or new Alexa products until reviews are in. Amazon, can I trade you back for my old one?

Seems decent if you only want a digital clock. Sound quality is very poor. I would not recommend listening to music on this speaker. I tried it with spoken audio and was just as disapointed in the quality. I found the setup to be very confusing. Some things you set up on the clock if you can find the menu and some thimgs you need the Alexa app on your phone. Screen is very small and low resolution. I wouldn't recommend it for video. Limited services support video anyway. I did not see an app for anything but Amazon video.

It is a good clock. Alarm feature works. Seems overpriced considering how underwhelming its other features are. Alexa continues to be inferior to Google as a digital assistant. I would not recommend this device and I will probably return it.

Amazon's ecosystem isn't worth the limitations you have to deal with to use it. The build quality of all of their products is vastly inferior to offerings from companies like Google, Apple, Roku, and the like. The only advantage Amazon has is they can deep discount this Chinese junk to undercut their competitors.

So.... I was excited that one of the paragraphs in the Echo Show 5 touted the new privacy features. I can disable the camera, and turn off the mic so Alexa isn't listening in the bedroom. Great because I wanted it as a clock radio.

Now I understand that this is mostly an Alexa device and its expecting to hear me asking it questions, so has a mic, etc. I understand that it needs a way to tell me at a glance that, hey, the microphone is off, Alexa can't hear you, but...

Its the thick ( to me ) red line across the bottom of the display that is now always on the bottom of my 'clock radio' that is driving me crazy. I wanted a nice little device that just showed the time, sitting on the matching color shelf, and I get... This.

This red line across the bottom that won't ever go away just because I want some privacy in the bedroom. Its not like it doesn't already have an icon in the lower right that says its muted AND a red lit button on top that says its muted. I feel like I'm being punished for daring to mute Alexa.

My solution for now is to just put something in front of it. Sigh.

I have been using the Alexa Dot for a couple years and loved it. I decided to upgrade to this version for the purpose of the screen. I love it even More! Has everything I was used to with an visual element as well. It comes with a good sounding speaker however I still have mine wired to a computer system speaker set up with heavy base. Sounds so much better! I use this unit in conjunction with different smart plugs and lights to control my home. It is nice being able to turn on and off appliances with my voice as well as turning on lights and changing the color of them with voice commands. Alexa never lets me down with her Internet wealth of knowledge. Well almost never… There are some things she just can’t seem to figure out yet. We will see if she improves over time. I know there’s other smart home device systems out there but as a huge Amazon user this seems like the way to go. I do so much of my ordering through Amazon as well as the Prime Video, Kindle and audiobooks. This just ties everything together so nicely. Very pleased! And the size is perfect. Large enough to see the screen but does not take up a lot of room. I also bought the additional stand for it to go on which is a huge plus for my situation/location that I have it set up in. I would definitely buy this again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Too glitchy and problematic to be useful
reviews.reviewText:
